Home Mush Mush Advice Ask the SDF!
This discussion has been marked as resolved (or the issue has been well-discussed).
This thread contains Announcement(s) from community representatives :
[On 09 November 2013] Hello mushlings! This post and thread should [...]
On november 9, 2013
Annette

Hello mushlings! This post and thread should help clarify what is reportable/sanctionable or not. If you have any questions regarding the rules or which behaviour you could report, please, ask here.

If you have a question regarding a sanction you've received or wish to speak to us personally, send us a message.

Rules of English Mush


When reporting rule breaking on your ships, please, you must type in a reason for the report! In If you leave it blank, the judges have to pick through the whole ship's logs to find out what went on.

We've found a glitch in reports where a reported private message of any kind (to your self, blank or with others) will send in a blank report. We have the logs but the judges don't know why the report was made so it's very important that we do not report private messages of any kind, find a random post in main chat to report, if you have to. Do not report PMs. We'll let you know when this is fixed!

In addition, do not just type, "Griefer". More information will only help us.


Anonymity
Many find anonymity to be one the best features of this game and chose to keep anonymity at all times. There is no Twinoid fame in Mush, no long time member hero worship and you are free to role play the character you've chosen without anyone knowing who you really are. Because most of us do want to keep our anonymity and not know the identity of others on our ships, we strongly suggest everyone preserve anonymity because it's more enjoyable to play that way.


Spreadsheets, other tools, and external communication
We won't be sanctioning for spreadsheet use. That said, there will plenty of time for total organization in private ships when they come. Spreadsheet encouragement on public ships is often futile as not everyone will use them and remember, the mush can see them as well and destruction of important documents is a valid mush strategy. Lists can also lead to tensions as the super organized might pressure the under organized. You can post your link once and please, don't expect new players or those who would rather stay in game to use these tools.

A note on IRC use - while it's very convenient it's use is discouraged on public ships. No one will be sanctioned for using it nor scolded on the forums (/me puts her whip away) it must be used very carefully. IRC logs cannot be used to contest a sanction because like screenshots, they can be tampered with. All pertinent information gleaned from an IRC conversation must be summarized in game. This is the only way for the SDF to see the evidence of the ship's happenings.


Inactivity or Idlers
Inactivity (new players, players not communicating or playing) will not be sanctioned, do not report them. We do not want to sanction new players who might not be engaged. Learning to work around these players is part of our game. You *can* succeed on as ship that has many deaths and/or a fair number of inactive players. Luck and team work amongst those left will be in order but it can be done. Thoughtful communication and patience can go a long way.

There are a couple, very specific, instances of inactivity or perceived inactivity which can be reported. If there is proof of idling for XP farming without actually playing, this can be reported. Proof though would include an admission of this type of activity. Widespread idling for XP gain isn't happening and it shouldn't be assumed that someone inactive is engaging in this activity. Over reporting this will result in a sanction for the unnecessary reports if there isn't solid proof of this behaviour.

The other type of inactivity that can be reported is surrender or giving up. For example, a player has had a disagreement on the ship and stops playing. This is not allowed, ships must be played out.


Ships filling slowly
There will be the rare times ships might take longer to fill, when this happens we will expect "neutral play". Which means, we don't do anything that specifically will help either team. As an example, killing hunters is acceptable as a mush goal can potentially be to live longer as much as it is a human goal. What's not acceptable is finishing anti Mush research, holding or hiding the Mush Sample, apron, weapons and other items and you may be sanctioned if found doing so. It is at the discretion of judges in this matter, if they feel the game has been spoiled for humans or Mush, they will give a sanction.

We encourage you not to advance anti-Mush research so that whoever is selected Mush (which could be you!) will have a fair chance at winning. Neutral research examples could be - Ultra-healing Pomade or the NCC Lens. We've also asked Blackmagic to consider having the Mush Sample (needed for anti-mush research) spawn only after the ship is full. Until then, though, this is our best solution.


Mush Tests updated Jan 29/14
While Mush tests are allowed it is not just to kill someone who refuses to take one. The player might not have AP, might not want to be sick if the test would make them so or the player might just not want to partake in the test because they don't like them. Refusing to do the test alone is not a valid reason to kill someone. If this is the only evidence you have that someone is Mush, it's not enough and could be seen as an unjustified killing which will net a sanction.


Remember, Mush is a teamwork game! You can't actively work against your team be it mush or human! If you play as a human and you sabotage the humans (killing for no reason relate to the advancement of the human cause, taking both showers apart, cooking all the rations and letting them spoil, etc) this is griefing and it will be taken very seriously. If you are mush, you cannot denounce your fellow mush or impede the mush cause, you must work as a team.

Have fun!
Mush mods. Peanutz, scout, Spazticus and Impet
On november 24, 2013
DanielMercury

Ok. quick shot. When a behaviour of an human should really be considered report worthy?

For example, if a ship has Jin Su human who moves it while pilots are out, and he's warned about that, I think that's reportable. Someone who just eat a ration while not hungry and for no serious reason it's not, unless he pretty much eats anything in sight repetitive times.
Also being human and holding fundamental items without giving them back (like the apron) for more than a day and being active about it should be right?

I read the rules but still feel the line in the sand is too confusing.

Also, regarding killing humans, say one report another for a murder between humans, where is the point where the SDF considers the kill "legitimate" as the victim was clearly suspicious and looked like a Mush?
On november 24, 2013
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

The line will always be confusing, because it's impossible to draw a clear-cut line. Very often it's impossible to give a definite rule that would apply in all situations, for example we can't say "humans are forbidden to kill other humans" or "a Mush can't kill another Mush", because there are situations in which it's acceptable. If a human kills at random or never explains, then of course you can report them. If they kill because the victim was clearly suspicious, then there's no reason to report them. But in between, it's harder to tell. You can't report all the humans who kill other humans just because they were dirty or were in the wrong room at the wrong time. If they give a reason (preferably before the murder, but they can also justify their action afterwards), it's not griefing, even if the suspicions were not really justified. But if someone starts killing 10 people based on stupid suspicions, then maybe they can be reported, or killed. Or both.

It's also hard to make a difference between incompetence or griefing. Or just honest mistakes from experienced players. Some people don't read the discussion, so even if you warn the commander repeatedly to be careful when he moves the ship, he may not read it. If he does it several times and kills several pilots that way, you can report him. And you should probably kill him too.

It's the same for important objects, it's difficult to know if it's deliberate or not. I've had near disasters on several ships because someone had taken the medikit, and yet they were all experienced people and certainly not griefers. It's even more difficult at the moment, because there are lots of beginners who don't realize how important some objects are, and who don't read everything. Once I had a Gioele who took the apron and never returned it, we killed him because he'd had it for more than a day, but we didn't report him because we didn't know if it was deliberate.
On november 24, 2013
Annette

Hi, Danilo.

It depends if these are accidents or the actions of new players who don't know better or if they're actual attempts to hurt their team. If Jin moves the ship while someone is out and it's not an accident (no apology, doesn't seem remorseful, or gloats) this is reportable. If it seems like someone is eating food and not spending AP, this is reportable as well. Holding items is hurting the team, so it's reportable. There's no time line, did they hold up research while they had the apron?

You can kill human players who are clearly and actively hurting the team. Does the crew agree that the ship will benefit from this player's death? Did you weigh consequences (morale loss, AP loss of the player you want to eliminate, resources it takes to kill someone) and decide as a group that without this one player, you could go farther? They don't need to be mush but they do need to be hurting the team.

If there's a suspicion of griefing, to me, there's nothing wrong with reporting it. Abuse of the reporting system would be reporting for absolutely no reason or you report someone for one simple swear word. These reports are not necessary.
On november 25, 2013
DanielMercury

Ok, question number two, I'm pretty sure of this fact but I didn't find any clear answer anywhere and I don't like to just guess something has to be logically right.

Say I'm a Mush, the crew finishes the serum, and in a genius and totally non-inspired though they use it on me, turning me back into human. Can I denounce then my Mushy friends or I have to shut up to not be denounced?
On november 25, 2013
EdgyVenison
Danilo

Ok, question number two, I'm pretty sure of this fact but I didn't find any clear answer anywhere and I don't like to just guess something has to be logically right.

Say I'm a Mush, the crew finishes the serum, and in a genius and totally non-inspired though they use it on me, turning me back into human. Can I denounce then my Mushy friends or I have to shut up to not be denounced?

I found it hard to grasp.
Easier translation :
You were a mush and turned back to your human form after the crews gave you the retro-fungal serum. Are you allowed to tell the other human crews the identity of the remaining mushes?
On november 25, 2013
Annette

This one is tricky. I hadn't played as a mush until just recently, when I did I learned how cool it is to be part of a small team, working against the odds. You are insular and sometimes suspected. You defend one another and work very closely in private. I felt warmly toward everyone on the mushy team. So, given that we're human (irl and after we're cured) I can see how this is not a simple situation and I dread the day I'm in it!

It's not hard to find the motivation to survive, to kill hunters, fix the ship, find resources to work toward an ultimate goal and glory. What's harder is the nuances in the mush hunt because you do have to kill individuals, even when they are mush. It's complex and this is part of what makes the game so great.

Given this, we can't enforce one way of acting in this situation over another ~ do what feels right to you, but remember, communication can really help your cause. Explain why you hesitate to out your former fellow mush if that's how you chose to play it. Of course, this won't necessarily save you but it can't hurt.
On november 25, 2013
Annette

Because this is complicated I want to add a note ~ within the freedom to decide this yourself, the option to give up all of your fellow mush is allowed, of course. No one will question your humanity.

On november 26, 2013
Calib

There seem to be a lot of "Do" and "Do nots". Is there a list of actual in-game behavior rules anywhere or is it all "unwritten laws"? I think I missed the list if there is one. If not a list clearly posted in English would be useful as a rule of thumb thing.

The "don'ts" are really just fleshing out what's considered to be "abusive provocation" and "playing against your team", Calib.
On november 26, 2013
Rain

Regarding cured mush... If I were mush and got cured through no fault of my own - the crew was smart and figured it out, but I wasn't the only mush... Well, now I'm human, I'm on the human team, wouldn't I be actively playing against my team by not telling them who the other mush trying to sabotage the human mission is?
On november 26, 2013
Annette
RainRegarding cured mush... If I were mush and got cured through no fault of my own - the crew was smart and figured it out, but I wasn't the only mush... Well, now I'm human, I'm on the human team, wouldn't I be actively playing against my team by not telling them who the other mush trying to sabotage the human mission is?

Yes, Rain. But, it's not black and white. We are sanctioning for pretty serious violations and the game is nuanced. Can you not see the motivation to protect your friend? How possibly hard that would be to out someone you just possibly spent days with on the same team? Play it how you would like to, but, we're not actively going to sanction those who don't want to play it that way. If you chose not to tell who the mush are, how long do you think you will live? It's up to the ship to decide your fate, to a large degree.

This will help us use the serum wisely and with thought as well. All that said, if there are complaints these cases will be looked at very carefully. It's not a simple issue and will be treated with care. Also, adding, this hasn't come up yet and doesn't come up often in the other games as well. I thinks this conversation is largely theoretical.
On november 26, 2013
spacekadt
ScoutAlso, adding, this hasn't come up yet and doesn't come up often in the other games as well. I thinks this conversation is largely theoretical.

It's also worth noting that you need one dead mush to even make the serum. A ship that's organized to make the serum in time to even convert a mush back to human are probably going to be organized enough to make the serum before other mush are converted.
On november 26, 2013
[1757645]

I'm curious if the neutral play for before MUSH selection also applies to Chun. She always knows she is playing for the humans. Should she also play neutral, or can she get what could be considered a headstart for her team?
On november 26, 2013
Annette

Chun doesn't have to just do research, she has the option to play neutral as well. It's not so much knowing you're human, it's keeping the ship in the condition it starts in for fairness for both teams.
On november 26, 2013
Rulesy
Cantine Cook

I think a lack of penalty for inactivity is ridiculous. I'm sure you've discussed this at length but this is a step backwards, die2nite has only recently tried to fix the same problem after 3 years! Every single person I've talked to outside of my d2n team has complained about it and I know at least a couple that won't bother to play again because of the issue. Sure, you can eventually work around it, but why should we put up with this all over again? If people don't want to play, being sanctioned will not affect them. I'm not talking about an instant quarantine but a friendly (possibly automated) "WAKE UP" PM wouldn't hurt the first couple of times. Will you reconsider or has the inactivity plague jumped ship with the Mush?

I don't think the "Ships filling slowly" rules are likely to be adhered to. Those coming to this game from die2nite know exactly how many players won't read these forums or the rules, and even if they do, only the experienced players will have a clue which actions are truly neutral. If you want such rules in place, they really all need to be enforced by the game, likely in the same way as the spawning of the sample. Maybe the stuff would still spawn early but you simply couldn't pick it up or access it? Doesn't seem too difficult to implement and will save a lot of confusion (and reporting).
On november 26, 2013
Annette
RulesyI think a lack of penalty for inactivity is ridiculous. I'm sure you've discussed this at length but this is a step backwards, die2nite has only recently tried to fix the same problem after 3 years! Every single person I've talked to outside of my d2n team has complained about it and I know at least a couple that won't bother to play again because of the issue. Sure, you can eventually work around it, but why should we put up with this all over again? If people don't want to play, being sanctioned will not affect them. I'm not talking about an instant quarantine but a friendly (possibly automated) "WAKE UP" PM wouldn't hurt the first couple of times. Will you reconsider or has the inactivity plague jumped ship with the Mush?

We can suggest these things for sure but Motion Twin, I think, likes for us succeed in spite of less than ideal conditions. So, the inactivity issue isn't a blind spot, it could be intentional. We did discuss inactivity and had to get clarification from the developers as to what we were to do. That effectively stopped discussion and we want with the their wishes. Not to through MT under the bus or anything...

I don't think the "Ships filling slowly" rules are likely to be adhered to. Those coming to this game from die2nite know exactly how many players won't read these forums or the rules, and even if they do, only the experienced players will have a clue which actions are truly neutral. If you want such rules in place, they really all need to be enforced by the game, likely in the same way as the spawning of the sample. Maybe the stuff would still spawn early but you simply couldn't pick it up or access it? Doesn't seem too difficult to implement and will save a lot of confusion (and reporting).
We can't enforce which is why these are suggestions and not in the rules. And, we're here to educate and help with whatever we can do to keep the game fair.

The rules posted in the Discussion forum are "official" the blue posts like the one in the first post of this thread, are clarifications and suggestions.

On november 26, 2013
[1757645]

I was thinking more in line with taking the MUSH sample to the Lab as Chun than I was researching.

I know we're trying to be fair to both the humans and MUSH, but if anyone would be trying for a serum for the MUSH, it'd be Chun. (While everyone else would be more concerned about not being shot to pieces.)

Usually when I start a game though, I look around the ship for where things are, contact Sol, shoot down ships, and whatnot. I'm sure they could change the way some things work to make it more fair. Have the MUSH sample spawn only when MUSH are selected, have research and NERON projects on lockdown (NERON can't do research when it's waking people up.) And a few other things.

Because technically, shooting down fighters IS a human thing. MUSH are perfectly fine with allowing the ship to be shot to pieces.
On november 26, 2013
TradeFederation

I don't' know why you would not encourage it, but it makes perfect natural sense for Chun to play hard human right from cycle 1, because that IS her role, and if you know the game, you will immediately know what side you are playing on with Chun. What usually happens is it is not an issue, since Chun is kind of the 'low ability kid that gets picked last for the team'. The fact is, Bronze Chun is in for a boring game with no natural skills, because they almost have to take Mankind's Only Hope, which confers no benefit, only avoids a catastrophic penalty. Also, its 2013, so can we get a gender neutral tag for that skill ? "Humanity's Only Hope" works just fine. MUCH better would be to make that a passive ability, like Ian's pacifism, or Faluca's antisocial, and give Bronze Chun an actual skill choice. It would sure make that character more fun to play. It would also help the game play better, because if Chun is among your 3-4 inactives, the depression spiral is almost unstoppable when all 4 die at once.


I have a solution to the inactive problem. Let players put the drooling inactives back into cryostasis after two days, then let new players 're-animate' them. That way, every ship will have the chance to have a full crew (eventually). Its so forehead-slappingly obvious a solution, I can't believe the designers didn't think of it. The game is just MASSIVELY more fun with a full crew, Mush and Human, and if you lose the shrink, or the pilots, or Chun to inactivity, its almost unplayable from that point, because you are down so many essential skills and morale points


Also, sometimes the Mush popups don't make any sense. If I, Mush captain, give a mission to my Mush ally to "Kill All Humans", why is there a popup telling me to stop aiding my ship, when no aid to the humans is happening, because the recipient is not human ? Could we get an option to turn off the Mush aiding humans popups, because all popups in websites are REALLY annoying if they happen during normal play, and there are SO many instances where a Mush might not be able to spend every last AP Killing All Humans, and might need to 'play along' with the crew a little. In fact, being in full 'sabotage mode' 100% of the time is a good way to get very dead very fast, as a Mushling, and deception is part of what it is to be Mush. Well, unless you want us all to just press the 'Mutate' button, Hulk out, and rush Chun on cycle one...

Annette

Honestly, Vyxzuw, no one is going to mind if Chun takes the Mush Sample to the Lab. What you describe as the first things you do, that's what most do, research isn't going to be furiously worked on in the amount of time (a few hours) it takes to fill a ship. Like I've said in multiple posts now, we've suggested the Mush Sample spawns after we're full. But, shooting down hunters is an environment thing, not so much a human or mush thing. Mush victory can mean many things, no matter what the tool tips tell us.

TradeFederation, like I said, it's not about anyone's "role" it's about keeping the ship in good shape. There is no inactives problem, we are intended to work around them. Yes, I know the tool tips are sometimes not helpful and the judges and moderators know this when looking at cases.

Let's keep this thread to specific questions. There are plenty of other threads regarding tool tips and inactivity.

Putting inactives back into sta
Nasus
Will I be sanctioned for playing the MAD Kube?
Sort of depends on what and how much you play it. If the ship is out of O2, and you are one of two players left, knock yourself out. If you are Frieda and the team needs a new planet to go to and you are wasting all you AP on it, then that's another story.
Scout
Honestly, Vyxzuw, no one is going to mind if Chun takes the Mush Sample to the Lab. What you describe as the first things you do, that's what most do, research isn't going to be furiously worked on in the amount of time (a few hours) it takes to fill a ship. Like I've said in multiple posts now, we've suggested the Mush Sample spawns after we're full. But, shooting down hunters is an environment thing, not so much a human or mush thing. Mush victory can mean many things, no matter what the tool tips tell us.

Yeah, I figure the 'neutral' play thing to mean: Act as a MUSH would act when they are pretending to be human. In other words, do your job, and no more. (And from a RP standpoint, the ship doesn't suspect that MUSH are really a threat yet, so why work on anit-MUSH research, when the ship is being shot at by hunters.)
On november 26, 2013
Enfilade
NasusWill I be sanctioned for playing the MAD Kube?

The Kube is a trap - it doesn't stop you from sinking all of your energy into it, it has a low chance of success, and winning only benefits one person. It's essentially a lottery that rewards you with a small shot of glory for spending your most valuable resource on it. Vyxzuw's point about playing it while waiting for the ship to blow up is a good example of when it's perfectly fine to play with it. Likewise, a newbie trying it out isn't a hanging offense, though the person should be warned of its uselessness. Almost any other use of the thing is a waste of time and resources.

ScoutYeah, I figure the 'neutral' play thing to mean: Act as a MUSH would act when they are pretending to be human. In other words, do your job, and no more.

My stance on this is that before everyone wakes up, I am "unassigned." I am potentially human and potentially mush, and thus I cannot guarantee that any actions I take pre-game will not betray my assigned allegiance. I do make exceptions for shooting down hunters, though, because that earns glory and keeps the ship intact so everyone can play (a destroyed ship means no one has fun).
On november 26, 2013

Efilade, you quoted me up there saying something I didn't say. Not that what they said is a problem! But, I think it's important our words are attributed to the proper person.

XD There are no rules around the Kube though, of course, your shipmates might not appreciate AP that could be better spent being wasted on it.

It's hard to tell if what the others did is provable suicide, we can only work on what's in the logs so we would have to see them to form an opinion.

Calib
I suspect the rest of the crew has decided to suicide by inactivity. All our technicians are either dead or inactive. One of the crew is saying this means we can't win. I'm on a ship right now with no technicians, not one. We're just plugging along, doing the best we can hoping for possibly day 10. It's not over in the least, it's not a 20 day ship by any means but we're hanging out, getting to know each other and basically having a good time.

We don't know the inactives are suiciding so it's not provable therefore not sanctionable.
On november 28, 2013
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

On november 28, 2013
Annette

Hi, Darjus! You have to decide if Ian is mush with your shipmates and what to do with him. It is against the rules to make deals with mush, the spirit of the game is as mush, you are ruthless and wouldn't even entertain being saved or cured. Mush do bad things that are sometimes not entirely obvious. They are required to work with the other mush against the humans, but, you will often not know what they are doing at all. To me, it sounds like your crew needs to do some more investigating in the mush hunt!

On november 30, 2013
[7896759]

Is it against the rules as a mush to expose another mush in order to gain trust from the humans?
On november 30, 2013
spacekadt
BobGoldIs it against the rules as a mush to expose another mush in order to gain trust from the humans?

It's almost never ok to expose another mush.

It is occasionally ok to kill another mush if it means saving your own hide. It's not ok to kill another mush just to gain trust and be all "look at me, I'm human! I killed a mush for you!"
On november 30, 2013
[6826491]
BobGoldIs it against the rules as a mush to expose another mush in order to gain trust from the humans?

My understanding is that intentionally exposing another mush is playing against your team. But killing (or helping to kill) a mush who has already been discovered (either through their own ineptitude, or by investigation) is acceptable.

In other words, you shouldn't intend to expose them or sell them out in any way, but if they're already exposed, and are going to die...you might as well use the opportunity to gain some trust from the humans in that case.

On december 1, 2013
Meadow

You're free to play on both with one account - however you must obey their rules of speaking French and in addition, all of their FDS regulations too.

On december 9, 2013
[68111]

Apparently there's this trend around: a player joins a ship and doesn't pick skills or move. Logs on again next day at same time, which you can see because they get rudely awakened and maybe receive one of the titles back. Same thing happens next day and goes on until they starve or punch whoever is in the room and get killed by the rest of the crew.

Can we get these kind of players sanctioned so that to have them out of our next ships or do you consider them "inactive" and part of the game"?
On december 9, 2013
npfan

If you believe someone is only logging in just to keep their title, go ahead and report that player since that is considered playing against their team.
On december 9, 2013
[68111]
npfanIf you believe someone is only logging in just to keep their title, go ahead and report that player since that is considered playing against their team.

I believe they either try to get the rewards for most cycles spent on ___ or just enjoy the fact that the rest of the crew will have to play with one less player.

I don't know why they do it but it's in expense of all the other players on their ships.
On december 9, 2013
Annette

They are considered part of the game, yes, Fragile. There will always be inactive players and the important title holders lose their title when truly inactive or their jobs can be hacked.

There are cases where the title holders is just active enough though to not lose their title and is not doing their job at all for days or lose it and gain it back often and in effect it is disrupting the progress of the ship and you've discussed it thoroughly with the members of your crew the title holder can be killed.

You must weigh the consequences of this action - killing an innocent new comer (did you try to communicate? don't assume everyone knows how to play let alone how to find the chat windows - PM them, engage them, offer help - remember, the judges will see you trying), morale loss, loss of potential future AP, AP and weapons to kill with, potential ill will with the rest of your shipmates if they weren't sure about the decision, etc.

You cannot kill Jin because he wasn't around in early in the cycle to move and you want to move now, etc. This action must not be taken lightly.

But, is Eleesha drooling in the corner? Just cover her up and tuck her in.
On december 9, 2013
[68111]

Scout I think you didn't cover my biggest concern. They are not exactly inactive.
*They log in once a day to check if they are still alive or should join a new ship.
*when they log in, they don't leave the lab, they do nothing, most of the times just sit there or sometimes they get aggressive and punch people in the lab.

Annette

On december 9, 2013
BerZerg

I would appreciate an official answer from the SDF on this one:

What steps does the SDF take to maintain its integrity, objectiveness and fairness when one if its members is involved in a reported event?
On december 9, 2013
[6826491]

If it's a judge, they don't participate in providing a ruling on the case, though they may participate in discussing further details about the incident. That applies regardless of whether they were the one to file the report, or the reported player. Further, if they recognize that they were on that ship, they leave it up to the other judges to provide their rulings, and the Mods take over from there.
On december 9, 2013
BerZerg

Hi Spazticus, how are you? I appreciate your answer, but I really would like an official answer from the SDF.
On december 9, 2013
npfan

He is from the SDF.

As Spazticus said, if a judge or mod was in same the ship as the people involved in a case, that person is to recuse himself or herself from the case. There is nothing codewise to enforce this though, and anyone who feels he or she was judged unfairly can appeal to the mods.

To be fair, if both SDF mods happen to be on the same ship and you antagonised both of them, all I can say is trust they are acting in good faith.
On december 9, 2013
[7922882]

If a member of the Mush does not communicate with you at all despite private messages and messages in the Mush channel, performs actions in favor of the humans (removing already installed cameras and placing them in areas that hurt mush play, scanning planets) is this reason enough to report for not playing for their team?
On december 9, 2013
spacekadt
VectorIf a member of the Mush does not communicate with you at all despite private messages and messages in the Mush channel, performs actions in favor of the humans (removing already installed cameras and placing them in areas that hurt mush play, scanning planets) is this reason enough to report for not playing for their team?

Report them and let the SDF take a look at it. But yes, if a mush is not assuming the role of mush, that's sanctionable.
On december 9, 2013
Annette
BerZerg

I would appreciate an official answer from the SDF on this one:

What steps does the SDF take to maintain its integrity, objectiveness and fairness when one if its members is involved in a reported event?

Complaints are anonymous, the judges don't see the name so they can be totally unbiased. Moderators do see the names but we do not judge on our cases nor do we tell the judges we were are part of report we've made.

Because we do see the names, we must go with what the judges decide. Even if it feels unfair, that the judges should have been more punitive (we might, since it was our report after all) this is the very reason we do not change a thing.

We are privileged as moderators with these abilities and must be almost more than fair in our actions.
On december 9, 2013
BerZerg

Thank you, Scout. Answered to my full satisfaction.
On december 9, 2013
[7922882]

For future reference, Spazticus was right and is also a part of the authority. Not sure what people have against him around here lately, he's a great contributor and source of knowledge.
On december 9, 2013
BerZerg

This guy is the best leader I have ever met on a Mush ship and I wouldn't have to think for a millisecond before deciding to serve under him again. I don't say that easily. My reply had nothing to do with him. Let's please leave it at that. I'm content with the answer I got.

On december 11, 2013
Annette

Hi TheIncredible. We've talked about this but for those who might have the same question, you can't report a ship after you've entered your last words and hit "okay". Those ships without reports at all are not visible to anyone but admins/devs.

On december 11, 2013
TradeFederation
AlyarinWould it be against the rules to convert someone to Mush, then immediately kill them and take Anonymush?

Why would you WANT to do the 'kill them' part ? Wouldn't it be better to tell the new mushling to try to kill the most vulnerable human when they are at full AP instead ? The net effect is the same after they attack, and other humans waste all THEIR (not your) AP and get dirty killing your ally, all the known (at that time) Mush are dead, and maybe one or more humans as well. Are you in that much of a hurry to end the Mush hunt ?
On december 11, 2013

There are times you can kill Mush as Mush justifiably but this is a topic I think for a stand alone thread in the Discussion forum.

On december 12, 2013
[1384452]
TradeFederationWhy would you WANT to do the 'kill them' part ? Wouldn't it be better to tell the new mushling to try to kill the most vulnerable human when they are at full AP instead ? The net effect is the same after they attack, and other humans waste all THEIR (not your) AP and get dirty killing your ally, all the known (at that time) Mush are dead, and maybe one or more humans as well. Are you in that much of a hurry to end the Mush hunt ?

Let's say, Eleesha accuses Mush-Finola of being mush. They get in a fight, both get badly wounded. Eleesha has been active mush hunting and was spored twice. Finola uses her last AP to spike Eleesha and convert her, then takes anonymush. She tells her mush buddy to finish off the newly converted Eleesha so that the bar at the top shows one dead mush.

New Eleesha mush gets killed and the player list says that there's 14 humans, 1 living mush and one dead mush. Mush-Finola becomes a hero and can claim that Eleesha was framing her. Mush-Finola gets to convince the whole team that she was not a bad guy. Because otherwise why would a mush try to kill her?

It's a classic strategy, called "throwing your ally under the bus". I had a friend playing mush who actually converted suspects from the Eleesha list with the intention of killing them afterwards to cover up for an alpha mush on that list.

This is not entirely hypothetical. Someone told me that they almost pulled this off and was afraid it might break the rules. I don't know if Alyarin was on that ship, and it nearly happened on my current ship.
On december 12, 2013
[6826491]

Killing a fellow Mush who has been positively identified as Mush by the human team, is not playing against your team. However, killing them when they have NOT already been outed, or outing them so that you can kill them, IS considered playing against your team. "Throwing them under the bus" is only acceptable in very specific circumstances, OR if the Mush team agrees to sacrifice one of you beforehand, as part of your overall strategy.

If the one you kill didn't agree to it beforehand, or if they were outed specifically so you could kill them, they're well within their rights to report you for it. If the human team caught them in the act, then you're free to join the hunt, because they're dead anyway.
On december 12, 2013
kreton

If someone did this to me I would always report it.
On december 12, 2013
[6826491]

If they outed you, or outed you to kill you? Sure make a report. If you were outed through human investigation or being caught in the act, then your fellow Mush can safely turn on you, in order to take some of the suspicion off of themselves. That's the big difference, however.

They can also attack your human assailants, as a Mush on my ship just tried to do. Of course that might also lead to both of you dying, as it did on my ship.

On december 12, 2013
kreton

I would do it however it happens, if I'm alive yet I would maybe out them If they kill me.
On december 12, 2013
[6826491]

They won't get sanctioned for killing you, IF the human team discovers through investigation that you're Mush, and they assist in the hunt. They can even be the one to deliver the final strike. In fact, if they refuse to help kill you, they might then be suspected of being Mush, too. That's why it's considered acceptable, in those specific circumstances. If the Mush plan is to let one of you get discovered, and the person to be exposed and killed agrees to that beforehand, that is acceptable as well. Nothing about these specific scenarios is suggesting that a Mush is playing against their team.

It is very different than being killed by your fellow Mush without reason. It is also very different than turning someone for the purposes of killing them. Do you see the difference?
On december 12, 2013
spacekadt

In the specific case as laid out above, I'd absolutely call that a valid kill under the category of "furthering the mush goals". You've now ingratiated yourself into the human team and made them trust you and made them believe there's one less mush on board than there really is.

In this case, Eleesha isn't really an ally so much as a decoy.

It's a fairly difficult strategy to pull off successfully, but when it works, I'd call it valid.
On december 12, 2013
Cleef
spacekadt

In the specific case as laid out above, I'd absolutely call that a valid kill under the category of "furthering the mush goals". You've now ingratiated yourself into the human team and made them trust you and made them believe there's one less mush on board than there really is.

In this case, Eleesha isn't really an ally so much as a decoy.

It's a fairly difficult strategy to pull off successfully, but when it works, I'd call it valid.

I agree with you. If Eleesha has been converted and the exchange of attacks between her and Finola suddenly stops, (for the sake of the so-called-playing-against-your-team). They'll be both suspicious. Eleesha can't call for a cease-fire. Her integrity will be disfigured. Finola can't stop attacking, the humans will be on their way to back-up Eleesha. It's either one of them or both who should sacrifice for the sake of the Mush's success.

On december 12, 2013
[6826491]

In that specific scenario, sure. I can see the validity in having to follow through, or else risk discovery. But I also acknowledge that such instances would be rare.

On december 14, 2013
Calib

I'm having a possible greifing issue.

Our Eleesha was inactive for almost an entire day, but kept checking back in to do nothing. This was right after a coalition she had been in was broken up by ship leadership due to unneeded deaths and wasting precious time when supplies are getting low. She ignored all calls to do research and planet finding and just puttered around in bed.

After all that inactivity she only moved out of the bedroom when I asked her to get up so I could have the bed. Please note that I was next up on her chopping block yesterday before the "stop the killing!" order was issued. The rest of the crew intervened. I very nearly died!

Eleesha got up at my request, then ran to the nearby dorm and killed the leadership who said "stop the killing!" and is now idle out in the open.

I suspect it's greifing spurred on by being angry out of character due to "having her job made useless" by the ship leadership deciding that there shouldn't be any more deaths until we sort out the oxygen issue combined with "we're dying anyway, I'll do whatever I want!" attitude.
On december 15, 2013
Calib

Ok, she finally started talking instead of just murdering everyone she can find. Yep, Roleplayer on a ship gone mad. Disregard the previous post. Thank you for reading!
On december 15, 2013
[7918569]

Action liberties in roleplay
On december 15, 2013
Annette

lol, all good, Calib.

ividyon, I replied in your thread!

On december 17, 2013
[1384452]

What are the limits on swearing and profanity in the game?
On december 17, 2013
[6826491]

Provided it's not used excessively, or used to flame someone, it probably won't see a sanction. Context matters, of course, and each incident is treated separately, depending upon the judges who are looking at the case. If however you're asked by one of your crewmates to tone it down a bit, and you persist, one of your crew might still report you. If say, half your posts consist of a stream of profanity, you might very well expect a sanction, RP be damned. How it affects the crew is a factor, and if it's considered excessively negative, that might be the result.

There's no hard and fast rules, aside from the rather general rules of respecting Netiquette and avoiding abusive provocation...so here's what I generally go by: Swearing once or twice because 19 hunters just appeared, and your pilots just cleared out a dozen hunters last cycle...well, that's rather understandable. I wouldn't sanction someone for that, if that's the sort of context involved. Basically, occasional swearing can be okay, in proper context.

Excessive swearing, swearing AT someone, and/or abusive insults, are not so acceptable; sanctions could be involved there, if it's reported.
On december 17, 2013
[1384452]

So no playing Sylvester Stallone type characters, even if you don't swear/insult other characters? I'm just curious about what kind of profanity has been reported, to gauge what the player base expects.
On december 17, 2013
Meadow

In my time at the SDF, only repeated insults have been reported. I've also intervened into a case of racism once because such things is not tolerated.

As for now? I don't think much has changed for that.

Swearing once or twice at no one in particular won't land you immediately in the Quarantine box though. There are tough moments in ship anyway.
On december 17, 2013
[6826491]
MrMuzSo no playing Sylvester Stallone type characters, even if you don't swear/insult other characters? I'm just curious about what kind of profanity has been reported, to gauge what the player base expects.

As I said, respecting Netiquette and avoiding abusive provocation are in the rules here.

Beyond that, every case is different. Most of the cases involving language (that I've seen) are directly related to swearing at someone, along with insults. I was personally involved in one case where one player on my ship started out with a string of racist profanity after killing a few hunters, followed by insults and threats to kill another player when he was asked to tone it down a bit. That was what I had reported him for, initially. He then proceeded to grief the ship along with another player later on, and really, the griefing was a far more serious offense.
On december 17, 2013
Annette

What Spazticus and Meadow say is correct. It's all dealt with case by case and context means a great deal. Even if Stallone type RP isn't directed at someone else, it might be deemed excessive if there's a lot of swearing. I can't say I know what type of character we're talking about here, though, not really up on the Stallone thing.
On december 18, 2013
[7973638]

I'm assuming we ask staff related questions here. Is it possible to suspect someone for joining games for the sake of getting XP through cycles and be inactive? Is that bannable? For the record, the user had high level skills.
On december 18, 2013
[6826491]

If they join just to go inactive and farm for xp, there's not much the SDF can do about it, unless they specifically admit they are farming. It can be seen in a similar light to someone who asks to be killed, so they can go jump on another ship...games have to be played through to their conclusion, and surrender/suicide are not allowed.

If there's another rule they are clearly breaking, you can and should report them. But inactives are a part of the game, as frustrating as that can be for the dedicated players.
On december 18, 2013
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

If you only suspect it, it can't lead to a sanction. But if you think there is proof that their inactivity is deliberate, you can report them.
On december 20, 2013
[68111]

I've always wondered how quarantine works. How many reports does it take to get quarantined and if you get quarantined, will it take as many times to be reported to get quarantined again?
On december 20, 2013
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

I'm not sure I can answer your question precisely, because the admins don't wish to give too many details that could be used by griefers to avoid quarantines. But for the first quarantine, it depends on the number of points you get. It can take several little sanctions, or it can be faster. After the first quarantine, you keep the points on your record, so one report can be enough to get quarantined again.
On december 22, 2013
[1384452]

Shared Astropad. Ship IRC channels. Shared spreadsheets. Other forms of out-of-game communications.

Fair play? What about on ships where there are no more mush?
On december 22, 2013
spacekadt

The general consensus has been that they're gonna happen, whether they're "against the rules" or not and really isn't worth sanctioning.

With one exception: If you're using any of these tools to specifically get around the game's limitations, that is sanctionable. Don't use it as a way to drop your walkie talkies for an extra inventory slot. Don't use it as a way to talk to others when you have a torn tongue or your mush channel is all jammed after that research is completed or anything along those lines.

I'm sure scout or peanutz can correct me if I'm wrong on the above, but that's what my memory says about the discussions.

Personally, I don't think it should ever be a means of *primary* communication. There's no question IRC is easier and faster and am the first to admit I've used that method to poke a friend that was on my ship (mostly in beta... haven't been on many ships with people I know since launch) to say "hey joe, go check out this thread on the ship. we need to do this asap!"
On december 22, 2013
Annette

No correction, Spacekadt, just confirmation, thank you for laying it so well!
On december 23, 2013
MacMal

What should I do?
On december 23, 2013
Annette

On december 23, 2013
[1384452]
spacekadtThe general consensus has been that they're gonna happen, whether they're "against the rules" or not and really isn't worth sanctioning.

I mean the question more as a spirit of the game thing, not so much about being punished for it. With Die2Nite, out of game communication was fully allowed, even encouraged and promoted. But it seems that it's not the same with Mush.

Thanks for the answer, though. I find using IRC as a quick way to say "What needs to be done?" or dealing with spammy communication like asking which bed is free or someone pushing Terrence around.

.

I joined a new ship just to find that out and secretly pumped all the AP into it when others weren't looking (read: all the time) for several days straight. So, I accumulated 43 dumped AP into the damn thing and it still doesn't budge (though it said it's possible to solve it after spending 26 AP)! I get it that it's a troll trap already, but the question is still open: is it possible to solve it? If not, I'll never ever touch that thing again.
On december 23, 2013
Cleef
ZelgadisQuestion: is there a distinction for solving the MAD Cube or not? I joined a new ship just to find that out and secretly pumped all the AP into it when others weren't looking (read: all the time) for several days straight. So, I accumulated 43 dumped AP into the damn thing and it still doesn't budge (though it said it's possible to solve it after spending 26 AP)! I get it that it's a troll trap already, but the question is still open: is it possible to solve it? If not, I'll never ever touch that thing again.

It's possible to solve it, others solve it in just one try, depends on the random number generator, depends on your luck, or depends on your patience, like what you did. But the sad truth is, you don't get any distinction for solving it, just a title Pointless Player in the honours page after your voyage ends.

On december 23, 2013
[2401411]

Once you solve it, You have gained 5 glory.
On december 26, 2013

On december 26, 2013
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

That's because he did something wrong on previous ships.
On december 26, 2013
spacekadt
sperbiOn our ship right now a person was quarantined (just a cycle after filling of teh ship) AND he hasn't done anything wrong -:-

They did something REALLY wrong on a previous ship or have done enough things wrong on previous ships that they built up enough points for a quarantine. Unfortunately, that means they automatically die from whatever ship they were in... but if someone got quarantined that quickly, you might be better off that way.
On december 26, 2013
sperbi

i don't know how it works, but just a minute before he was dead he wrote me: "it seems someone has reported me just now without a reason." so it seems to me that someone on our current ship has reported him although he hasn't done anything bad...
On december 26, 2013
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

That's impossible, because judges only see complaints once ships are finished. And you should be careful when you hear someone say "I have been reported without a reason". Sometimes it's true, but often there are very good reasons.
On december 26, 2013
sperbi

so you mean the judges have banned him just at the time when he was on my ship and it has nothing to do with a person who has reported him falsely? or do you mean that the complaints of the previous ship were "certified" by judges and so it needs only a false report to quarantine him...?
On december 26, 2013
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

I mean that if he was banned, it's because people on a previous ship (or previous ships) reported him and the judges decided to sanction him, which means that it wasn't a false report and that there were good reasons to report him.

Of course false reports aren't enough to quarantine someone. Complaints are read by the judges who can see everything that happened on the ship and know if the report was justified or not. In fact, a false report can lead to a sanction or a warning for the person who sent the complaint.
On december 26, 2013
sperbi

ok, thank you for the explanation :-)
On december 27, 2013
Annette

In the very first post of this thread I've clarified some very specific and rare situations where idlers farming for XP can be reported. Once actives gone idle or quitters as well can be reported. Also, I clarified a bit about IRC use. If you have any questions please let me know.

On december 27, 2013
Chandra

It is hard though to tell when someone is idle farming though... it would be nice if they could just be reported as idling, and require you to not be idle to get exp...

No. It just means a very active laboratory crew has pushed research as a priority. It isn't exactly a smart idea considering the very same crew who are conducting research could end up as Mush, but it isn't reportable behavior at all.

Antispore gas is not neutral play at all...
On december 27, 2013
[7922882]

That isn't a rule nor is it reportable or sanctionable. Maybe people are helpful, may set up cameras and give newbies tips only to find out they are mush later on. It is totally by choice to do what you want before Mush are chosen. Not against the rules or reportable.
On december 27, 2013

On december 27, 2013

On december 27, 2013
Annette

Reports for the 5 people who worked on the Antispore Gas (as an example) will be rare unless there's a very vigilant reporter and as far as I can tell, no one has reported this so far. It's also pretty obvious to most that if this is indeed done and they are picked as Mush, woops, that wasn't very smart because now we can only get two spores right off the bat and will be discouraging this and not working on the gas themselves next ship.

What's more common is holding the Mush Sample, or other items before Mush is chosen and if the judges look through the logs and see you've held the Mush sample for hours on end and have moved around, seeing you have no intent to drop it (not just a forgotten Mush Sample while laying down etc) they may deem this as "spoiling". The key is, did your behaviour spoil it for the Mush or humans? If it did you might be sanctioned.
On december 27, 2013
Meadow

Neutral play is encouraged before Mush are selected. As Vector said one post before his last one, it could backfire potentially on yourself and it is a bit more fun if the Mush have a fighting chance too.

On december 30, 2013
[7922882]

Here's a tip for people who find playing only 1 game too slow:

www.mush.vg - French Mush

www.mush.twinoid.es - Spanish Mush

If you can read some spanish or french, you might try playing on the french or spanish mush. They both can be accessed using your one universal Twinoid account, that way you can still play more than one game but you aren't breaking the "only 1 account" rule!

Just make sure you take the time to translate what people say, you won't get far in-game otherwise.
On december 30, 2013
spacekadt

I'm not a mod and I can't make official recommendations, but unless you speak the language, I highly suggest you don't do that.

Communication is key in Mush... and if you can't communicate without google translate, you're going to drag your ship down. Nevermind that you'll almost certainly get reported and sanctioned.
On december 30, 2013
Annette

If you use a translator you will most likely not be sanctioned if you try and do not speak any language in game that is not the official language of the Mush version. If you do find one Mush ship at a time slow it is an alternative. I don't see how that is though, I find my English Mush ships are pretty darn time consuming as it is!

When I played one French ship with a translator I found it so incredibly draining. Be prepared to spend a great deal of time translating everything and then wondering if you have it right. Then, when you communicate you will have someone say "this is google translate right?" and while you shouldn't be reported for that it IS a burden and imo takes away from game play.

Chrome has a built in translator which should translate the whole page but I find it works 10% of the time and is virtually useless.

[7922882]
spacekadt

I'm not a mod and I can't make official recommendations, but unless you speak the language, I highly suggest you don't do that.

Communication is key in Mush... and if you can't communicate without google translate, you're going to drag your ship down. Nevermind that you'll almost certainly get reported and sanctioned.

I appreciate the advice space but I have to respectfully disagree. All the ships I have been on so far for spanish/french mush have been very understanding and helpful when I explain I am not a native speaker. I take time to translate everything and ask questions if I am uncertain. Many times players are happy to help. It does take a lot of effort but worth it for me this holiday season when I have lots of free time to play more than 1 game at a time! It helps me learn different character roles a lot faster too.

If we can be welcoming and understanding of people ESL on English Mush, there is no reason a foray into the other Mush language versions cannot be similarly successful and positive.

On december 30, 2013
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

It won't be a problem as long as you try to speak clearly and to understand what people tell you. We had many problems a few months ago because we had a lot of players who did not speak French at all and refused to speak anything but English or Spanish. This was of course unacceptable. Others tried but they did not understand anything, the other crew members did not understand what they said, and they ended up being griefers (some involuntarily, others on purpose) because they didn't have a clue what they were supposed to do.

But if someone tries to understand and be understood, then there is no problem.
On december 30, 2013
spacekadt

*shrug*

That's counter to what I've heard from someone that used to play French Mush. He was using google translate and was asked by the ship to just speak English and someone would translate for him (he was doing ok with the understanding bit, it was the converting English to French that google failed at spectacularly). After the ship ended, he got a T&C sanction for speaking English... at the request of the ship.

May have been one of those outlier cases, but I still think if you can't communicate *clearly* (and I don't consider relying entirely on google "clearly", having some understanding of the language so you can fix google is at least better) then you probably shouldn't do it. But we all know what opinions are like

for those not familiar with the saying opinions are like assholes, everybody's got one!

On december 31, 2013
[2401411]

Is it considered griefing for killing or trying to kill someone just because he/she played the MAD Kube?
On december 31, 2013
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

Yes. If it was playing the mad kube was griefing, then there would be no mad kube at all on the ship.

Maybe there are some situations where killing (or reporting, or both) would be justified. But killing someone "just because they played the mad kube" isn't justified at all.
On december 31, 2013
[6826491]
PantheonIs it considered griefing for killing or trying to kill someone just because he/she played the MAD Kube?

I know your original question involved a Chun who did this; I also have to respectfully disagree slightly with Peanutz on this, but only because I've had a griefing Chun before...Did they just use it once or twice? In that case, I'd probably sanction any player who killed someone just for that. Attacking Chun in a case like that could be reported for griefing, unless literally everyone agrees killing her is for the good of the ship (and I know some Chun players have actually griefed ships before, leaving their crews with few to no viable alternatives.)

I once had a Chun in the beta, who never communicated, held onto the Apron, took up the Medlab bed (thus she was almost never in the Lab,) ate rations as often as possible, and used almost every AP she got on the Mad Kube...every day. Now for THAT, I would call it a justified killing, additional morale loss be damned. That ship didn't make it very far, in any event...the damage had already been done. But this case involved far more than just using the Mad Kube. That was the first griefing incident I had encountered in this game, but it was also before we had the SDF set up.

Even if she didn't take Last Hope on your ship, killing her involves inevitable and immediate morale loss, so you must very carefully weigh the circumstances, and the damage to the ship...or else you might be reported for griefing. I should note that in almost all circumstances, a human player killing Chun = griefing. Chun being a griefer is rather uncommon.
On december 31, 2013
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

Oh, but I totally agree with you. I know there are griefing Chuns (which is a kind of double griefing, since they have to be killed, thus depriving the ship of one of the most important crew members), and in the case you described, killing or reporting seemed justified.

But Pantheon's question didn't give any details, and that's why I specifically quoted the "just because she plays the mad kube" part. If it's the only reason, if she does her job, and if she doesn't play it repeatedly, then killing her is definitely excessive, especially as it is Chun. But even playing repeatedky isn't necessary griefing or a cause for killing, since that thing is supposed to be played several times unless you're lucky and get glory the first time.
On december 31, 2013
Annette

Yes, killing Chun just because she used the MadKube=bad, killing Chun for griefing=okay.

On december 31, 2013
[7918569]

I'd like to request a thorough re-sorting of the Mush rules. They're pretty great, and this is not about the rules themselves, but there's several key problems:

1) The in-game help gives you a set of REALLY basic rules that could be interpreted in many ways. Instead of immediately giving a link to a more detailed explanation, it gives you... a lore pamphlet about the in-game SDF faction. Once you're through that, there's finally a forum thread link.... to the French forums.

2) The SDF Rules, Explanations, Quarantine! is well-named and likely to be found by players who look into the forums (though that can't be expected of everybody), however it takes too much time explaining things about Judges and the SDF, instead of first explaining basic game rules. There is a section about the game rules, but it pops up way too far down in the text.

3) The most useful explanations of the game rules cannot actually be found in the in-game help or in the Rules thread... they're found here, in a thread called Ask the SDF. This needs to be addressed, because... how should new players know this thread has anything to do with rules? How does the name of an in-game faction tell a new player "yes this is where I should read up on game rules"?

Ignoring the problems in the in-game help window, it would help to:

- sort the Rules thread to put the actual rules at the top
- move info from "Ask the SDF" to the Rules thread
- make the rules thread a global forum announcement

This is an extremely vital issue for new players, because I've just had a Chao on my ship who knew the game pretty well (opening the basic communication threads etc.), but hid a Blaster before Mush determination, simply not knowing about the "neutral play" rule because the explanation is hidden in some obscurely-named forum thread somewhere. This lead to him taking a beating from the crew, although I think he tried to play well.

I hope you understand my concerns. Can this be done?
On december 31, 2013
Annette

We're working on the link to the English rules, it was brought to Motion Twin's attention week 1, so, it will get done. But, their rules are the same as ours, anyone rule minded could translate that it very quickly. While, it's not ideal, it's no excuse for rule breaking. Global announcements aren't something moderators can do - our best is a sticky, which we have.

Second, the guidelines at the beginning of this thread are what NOT to report and information. They are also suggestions and clarifications, not required reading.

Third, your Chao hiding a baster on your ship doesn't really point to needing a whole over haul of all the things. Sometimes people who hide things get a small sanction if the judges feel it's spoiling the game for the others. This doesn't necessarily mean that the rules are unclear or hard to find. It just means someone is wanting an unfair advantage and was caught doing it. I'm watching this and seeing that a small sanction actually works, the vast majority don't do it again.
On january 1, 2014
[1384452]

Chao hiding or holding the blaster could very well be neutral play. Both mush Chao and human Chao have a good reason to want the blaster. And both mush and humans are going to be afraid of him using it.
On january 2, 2014
Annette

We talked about Chun holding stuff, I never thought of Chao doing it fairly. It still puts the other team at a disadvantage if anyone holds anything pre Mush chosen I think. I don't think it's black or white, Janice seems pretty punch happy in that scenario as well (unfairly punchy) heh.

Different topic, I added a bit in the first post here and it is in the Rules post as well - just a reminder everyone, when reporting rule breaking on your ships, please, you must type in a reason for the report! If you leave it blank, the judges have to pick through the whole ship's logs to find out what went on.
On january 2, 2014
[7922882]

I'm getting sick of people who complain that no one can do anything before everyone is awake without it being "unfair", "cheating" or "bad play".

People complained on a recent ship that I started research before everyone woke up. It is a choice I made to begin research and push it as much as possible. I had just as much of a chance of being a Mush later and screwing myself over as anyone else so it was a gamble that I took. And it paid off this time but maybe next time it won't. And if you want to go further and look at it in terms of team play or roleplaying, technically everyone is a human at the beginning of the game before all crew are out of cryo, so you are playing your role exactly as you should because for all accounts in that moment you are human.

Point is, it isn't against the rules or bad play. Bad play would be if I hid the mush sample or sabotaged things before the start of the ship. End of story. If you disagree you are foolish. If the developers did not want certain actions to occur pre-game they would lock them from occurring. Just like how they don't assign titles until everyone is awake, so that BIOS settings aren't changed and the ship can't be moved before everyone is awake.
On january 2, 2014
[7742291]

You can kill people pre-MUSH assignment. Developers don't want it. Your argument is invalid.
On january 2, 2014
Rain

Actually, I'm pretty sure if you try to hit anyone before mush are assigned you get a message saying 'There's no need for this now.' Or did I dream that up?

On january 2, 2014
Infinite_Smile

can a kill a noob for the sake of the team? noob that wakes up after ages of sleep, takes a commander title and does a lot of stupid and dangerous actions?
On january 2, 2014
Annette

This was discussed earlier in the thread, Kraxon, so I'll paste the response:

http://twd.io/e/0MDL0g/78
"There are cases where the title holders is just active enough though to not lose their title and is not doing their job at all for days or lose it and gain it back often and in effect it is disrupting the progress of the ship and you've discussed it thoroughly with the members of your crew the title holder can be killed.

You must weigh the consequences of this action - killing an innocent new comer (did you try to communicate? don't assume everyone knows how to play let alone how to find the chat windows - PM them, engage them, offer help - remember, the judges will see you trying), morale loss, loss of potential future AP, AP and weapons to kill with, potential ill will with the rest of your shipmates if they weren't sure about the decision, etc.

You cannot kill Jin because he wasn't around in early in the cycle to move and you want to move now, etc. This action must not be taken lightly."

On january 5, 2014
spacekadt
PantheonWhat is spoiling?

spoiling the game for others. usually means you did something minor that could have or did "ruin" the game for others.
On january 6, 2014
[7922882]

It could also refer to cooked rations, alien steaks or fruits 'spoiling'. They start to spoil over time if the Neron Food Destruction settings are turned off. Consumables can give you various illnesses if eaten when spoiled.
On january 6, 2014
npfan

On january 7, 2014
spacekadt

Report it. The judges will go through the logs and see if there's any suspicion on his part for any reason and take it from there.

As far as reporting things goes - if you have a legitimate concern that someone's griefing or breaking the rules, report them.

As long as you're not spamming reports for things that obviously don't break the rules, you'll be fine.

On january 8, 2014
[7911730]

A guy wanted to report me for posting quotes by famous personalities in game while relating it to the current situation (Nothing irrelevant like Spamming)... Is this acceptable by the SDF?
On january 8, 2014
[6826491]

If it's deemed excessive or disruptive (and yes, I know those terms are subjective, in this context) then you might get a warning. However, if it's in context, not flooding the chat, and it isn't disruptive...you may well be cleared if it's reported.

In lieu of asking for more details, I suggest you play it safer and tone it back just a bit. If the person still wants to report you after that, then we'll look into it.
On january 8, 2014
spacekadt

As long as it's not spamming, you should be fine. Just keep it in moderation and it's completely fine.

On january 9, 2014
Pyrrhus

Out of curiosity, how did the SDF Administration team come to be? You all seem to have been players for a very significant period of time, going as far back as Mush Beta, so it definitely looks like the SDF Admins aren't primarily chosen from non-players or solely for administration purposes. Are there Twinoid employees who also moonlight as SDF admins as well?

Also, how close is the relationship between the Twinoid Development teams and the SDF/Admin team/s? Do the SDF largely keep to themselves, or is there an active link and dialogue between them?

Thank you for your time, and apologies for the many obtuse questions.
On january 9, 2014
spacekadt

Shortly after the game went live, there was a call for SDF applications. The moderators (who were known and trusted players with a history in various MT games) selected the team they wanted to work with from the applications they received.

The SDF team and the moderators are just players with an interest in and love of the game that happened to be around at the right time and happened to be picked for the team.

Just to be clear, though, SDF members are *not* admins. There's absolutely no relationship with MT other than "we like the game and want to help make it better".

The SDF team does have a little bit of a dialogue with devs/admins when necessary, but it mostly funnels through the mods. The MT team is pretty much always busy with whatever new project they're working on (or updating) so it's better that things get funneled through the mods since it's less distraction and more likely to get answers.
On january 9, 2014
Pyrrhus

For clarification's sake, what are the differences between the SDF team, Moderators and Admins? I've come across a lot of different terms applied for different things multiple times, and it's somewhat confusing.

Also, relating to XP farming and not SDF, is XP gain ended for those who become inactive in a game?

Thanks again, Spacekadt and SDF Team!
On january 9, 2014
npfan

SDF = Mods + Judges
Admins are the admins.

As far as I can tell, XP gain continues even for those who become inactive until they are no longer in a ship.
On january 9, 2014
VertigoProcess

For a little bit more detail on top of what npfan said.

SDF= Judges. They judge the cases and are players.

Mods= Moderators. They watch over the forums and the judges. They're like the SDF teams parents. They are also players.

Admin= Administrator. This is epoq. He actually works for MT over in France. He did the translations and what nots for the game. (fun fact he also runs the english MT twitter feed and is fun to talk to via twitter).

Dev= Developers. This is blackmagic and some others that I don't know off the top of my head. They also work for MT in France. They actually designed and coded the game.


Edit: please don't spam these people I just mentioned above >.>
On january 9, 2014
[1384452]

Are we allowed to buy food from the vending machine to prove to others that we're not mush?

Also why does quarantine take place on live ships? It seems to harm the ship to lose an important member. Shouldn't those people just be quarantined before they get onto a ship or at least have their ship jumps delayed if they're racking a lot of penalty points?
On january 9, 2014
Rain
MrMuzAlso why does quarantine take place on live ships? It seems to harm the ship to lose an important member. Shouldn't those people just be quarantined before they get onto a ship or at least have their ship jumps delayed if they're racking a lot of penalty points?

Because complaints are processed at the end of a ship, and people who commit the sorts of things to get quarantined for probably die long before then, they've had ample time to jump onto a new ship before the report is processed... potentially more than one, if they're the sort to get killed off immediately. In general though, you're probably better off with them killed before they strike, doubt quarantine is done lightly...
On january 9, 2014
[6826491]
MrMuzAre we allowed to buy food from the vending machine to prove to others that we're not mush?

There's no reason why you can't do that. Though some devious Mush might even try to get around that, by buying it before the game starts, and saving it in case they get tested. So to get around that, use the Food Test to your advantage, Consume a fruit/pill/coffee first, then the vending machine consumable in a way that's logged... And then immediately do something to help the ship. That's what I often do. That proves your humanity and your dedication to the team.

As for the quarantine part of the question: If someone (say, a griefer) dies early on, they can join a new ship days before their previous ship ends, and the report(s) can be judged. While it might not be entirely fair for their current ship, the quarantine can't be delayed until the end of their current ship. Consider that a griefer might wait until say, Day 9, and then start a killing spree, or make a harmful return to Sol. Stopping them with a quarantine hopefully prevents them from causing further damage to their current ship.

99% of the time, you're better off without someone who has earned a quarantine. They aren't guilty before being proven innocent, they earned that quarantine. They can appeal, if they feel they were wrongly quarantined, of course.
On january 9, 2014
Annette

Been afk a good part of the last 18 hours, come to read this thread and you guys have looked after it all so well!

I agree with Spazticus on the last issue. It's better not to have these people on your ship anyway. I can't say too much (as per Blackmagic's wishes) but you won't become quarantined for 1 infraction, but I can't say how many it could possibly take. But, the point is, it's indeed not done lightly or for beginner mistakes.

On january 13, 2014
Annette

Hi everyone, posting here as well as edited the first post in this thread.

We've found a glitch in reports where a reported private message of any kind (to your self, blank or with others) will send in a blank report. We have the logs but the judges don't know why the report was made so it's very important that we do not report private messages of any kind, find a random post in main chat to report, if you have to. Do not report PMs. We'll let you know when this is fixed!

sperbi

In the current ship I had the idea to hide knife and grenade right at the beginning. I thought I could prevent an early killing spree of mush. It was a coincidence that I read a thread in the forum where it was mentioned that my action is a reportable action. So I picked these objects up and dropped them again. Of course, some hours later when mush were chosen Chun, Janice, Hua, Eleesha and Paola were killed by one of the mushes with these weapons... :/ After that the people aren't writing lots of things anymore, I think the motivation to play further is really down.

You see-all of this could have been prevented just if I had hiden these things at the beginning! And be honest, isn't it super stupid to leave all these deadly weapons just lying around at the daedalus if you know that soon there is awaking an alien form which has only the intention to kill you all? ....Yeah -.-

So-if almost noone was in this room (and only at that time it makes sense) I should be allowed to hide these weapons, it is the best way. Taking them in your Inventory before mush were chosen is also reportable (btw an action I see on lots of ships) and additionally it makes you suspicious.
Of course as soon as mush were chosen you should inform at least Chun where all of these hidden weapons are. So if the human side is needing that weapons they know where they are.

Yes, there is that possibilty that the person who has hidden them is chosen as mush - that would be an advantage for mush, but the probability is only 1 of 8 cases... In 7 of 8 cases the human side is protected and mush have to play properly : earn trust to get the information where the weapons are or converting people (maybe who know where they are) or have at least search for them.

Isn't it the intention of the game to play sneaky as mush and not just right away: "Hey, here am I, but you are doomed now, hahaha"

Yeah, right, just after mush are chosen it woould also be possible to take these items and hide them/take them in your inventory if you are Chun-but Chun is a character who was inactive in lots of my games...
