On january 20, 2014
Annette
Nicholay

My question is as follows. If I want to have this Excel sheet turned into a site-based app, who should I go to and is it okay to, in the meantime, spread this sheet via the use of hosting sites as is? Are there any precautions against virus-dangers I should know about?

Thank you in advance.

Hi, can Excel sheets spread viruses? :o We don't have "official" apps or a directory for English Mush so there's no approval process for tools. Can you transfer the formulas to a Google Drive spreadsheet? That way there's no hosting or downloading needed. If you can't or don't want to use Google Drive and you host from your own site or a third party, I suppose people will have to weigh the risks of downloading from a potentially unknown source. There's no rule against it, just user beware.

Andre, the judges will have to work it out as best they can, no one knew that reporting this way was causing the glitch until just recently so the judges are somewhat used to it heh. But, it's terribly inefficient which is why we're trying to get the word out on it. Thanks for the heads up and extra info, I bet it has helped that case, the judges read this thread. (Quite a few anyway! )


ShuDog

I have a slight problem, which has turned into a slightly less slight problem after reading this thread.

Discovered a player labeled as a multi-teamer. They went through the tutorial and are currently silent but there's the icon on them. Do I report them no matter what?

And just now, I found out about the glitch with the PMs. So now do I have to send in *another* report? I'm afraid to send both reports now, because then the judges will get 3 from me, and I just started this ship. However, I was threatened in a PM for no real reason, so I'm concerned about this situation. It was a really short PM, and I think speaks for itself, so will the blank message at least be attached?

Shudog, unfortunately, you won't be able to report the same person more than once on a ship (I have no idea why that is, probably for the antispam aspect) For the threat, you can ask someone else to report this player (if it's the same one you've reported already) using a main chat post to report, be it that particular player's post or something random, as long as it's explained the judges will figure it out.

On january 21, 2014
Annette

There's been an update to the guidelines and it will be added to the rules as well.

Ships filling slowly *updated Jan 21/14
There will be the rare times ships might take longer to fill, when this happens we will expect "neutral play". Which means, we don't do anything that specifically will help either team. As an example, killing hunters is acceptable as a mush goal can potentially be to live longer as much as it is a human goal. What's not acceptable is holding or hiding the Mush Sample, apron, weapons and other items and you may be sanctioned. The judges are left to use their desecration in this matter, if they feel the game has been spoiled for humans or Mush, they will give a sanction.

We encourage you not to advance anti-Mush research so that whoever is selected Mush (which could be you!) will have a fair chance at winning. Neutral research examples could be - Ultra-healing Pomade or the NCC Lens. We've also asked Blackmagic to consider having the Mush Sample (needed for anti-mush research) spawn only after the ship is full. Until then, though, this is our best solution.

The pink bit is new. The judges feel games are being spoiled for others with too much Mush Sample holding and hiding and I agree. We can all help our ships by making it clear that this is a sanctionable offence as many of us post up tips and threads in a helpful way, this can be added to those even.

On january 21, 2014
Secondary

On january 21, 2014
Annette

You shouldn't do Anti-Mush research really Andre and only humans can use drugs so it's not neutral. Ideally people will maintain the ship by killing hunters and do not much more but unless Mush research is excessive (research is completed) AND reported, no one can do anything about it.

On january 23, 2014
Adamsor

I couldn't find that information anywhere else so: Do SDF points decrease over time?
On january 23, 2014
Annette

No, they don't Adamsor but for small infractions it takes quite a few to build enough for a ban.
On january 23, 2014
ShuDog

Not all griefers grief all their ships. We also had someone quarantined who was otherwise a model crewmember, in the middle of several vital projects. It kind of screwed us over, several days into the ship.

I mean, that makes no sense as a dis-incentive... why would a griefer care if they hurt their future ships? They're *griefing*. If they learn their lesson and they're helping their current crew, all it hurts is that crew. Including, perhaps, the players who pay money because they have a great working team with productive team members.

I'm sure this is a philosophical "faith in humanity" thing, but in practice the sudden-ness of quarantine is designed to hurt more than the griefer.
On january 23, 2014
spacekadt

The problem is that reports don't come through to the judges until after the ship has ended... and there's really no way to change that.

1) What if a judge happens to be on the ship in question? Now that judge knows who the mush are just by looking at the overview.

2) Many cases require the ship to run its full course to see how the person behaved or what the circumstances were in order to actually figure out what happened and what the person's motivations were.

3) There's no way for the system to distinguish cases where #2 is *not* the case to push it through early.

Yeah, it does suck for the new ship where the person got quarantined, but honestly... someone that got quarantined is most likely gonna be someone you don't want on your ship anyway. And the 5% of the time where the person *is* actually being helpful just doesn't outweigh the 95% of the time where the person isn't.
On january 23, 2014
[1384452]

Quarantine is probably done when someone has a record of bad behavior. I believe they'd probably get a warning or sanction first, and the quarantine is a more extreme thing.

Just because someone has been a model crewmember for the first 3 days, it doesn't mean that they play nice. They could be perfectly good, skilled players who have a track record of returning to Sol after the mush are dead. They could be nice for a long period of time, then extremely abusive when someone disagrees with them.
On january 23, 2014
spacekadt
MrMuz

Quarantine is probably done when someone has a record of bad behavior. I believe they'd probably get a warning or sanction first, and the quarantine is a more extreme thing.

Just because someone has been a model crewmember for the first 3 days, it doesn't mean that they play nice. They could be perfectly good, skilled players who have a track record of returning to Sol after the mush are dead. They could be nice for a long period of time, then extremely abusive when someone disagrees with them.

Quarantines are actually fully automatic. When the reports come through, judges assign a point value based on what the person did. When the point values hit certain limits (that we aren't even privy to), the user gets quarantined for a certain number of days. The more points they have, the longer the quarantine period.

We *do* know, though, that it takes a lot of little sanctions or just a few major ones.

Additionally, judges can not see any game history for any user. Not previous ships, not the person behind the character and not any sanction history. Everyone is judged solely on their actions on the ship in question.
On january 24, 2014
[7895906]

Exactly ShuDog, our supposed griefer was doing great, and we decided she should read our logistics expert book. Then bam, she gets quarantined out of nowhere. A functional player lost and all that's left in return is a "ration" that gives 6AP and -4 morale. Thanks for that SDF, what a great trade.

On january 24, 2014
ShuDog

Well, no, I don't, because you're not hearing what we're saying.

I'm not disputing that they need to be punished and removed. I'm saying the act of removal, the way it's done, ruining two games instead of one. What if they're holding items that then fall into the hands of one team or another? What if they're bringing food to someone and it lands in a corridor? Or as mentioned, they've just read a mage book, or they're in a ship that can't come back? What happens if they're the last person alive in expo? What if someone's counting on them to finish something they were doing, and then all of a sudden no one has AP to get to the other side of the ship?

Quarantine has got to be changed somehow, in that everyone knows what it's for within the game (thus punishing them some more), and giving people a chance to adjust to the new situation. Snatching players out of a game without warning does more harm than good.

And like I was saying, that's not a deterrent to someone who wants to do harm to fellow players. Quite the opposite. If I were intent on griefing, you know what I'd do? Rack up the violations on one ship, then join the next ship and keep my head down till SDF plucks me out. Then I laugh and laugh at the two The End screens that I've screwed with.

mario6424

On january 24, 2014
npfan

Honestly, you're making up situations that are so rare, it's like asking what if the sun blows up tomorrow.

For someone to get a quarantine, one of two things must have happened:
That person did something so game breaking that they are a major threat to seriously ruining future games
or
That person has been given a chance to be good after being warned at least once

ShuDogSnatching players out of a game without warning does more harm than good.

In the very rare instance where someone acts good after serious bad behaviour, what do you propose as the alternative? Let them run wild? Not your problem that person screwed up past ships, right? Honestly, if that person were to continue griefing in your ship, you might be asking why we didn't quarantine that person sooner.
On january 24, 2014
[6826491]
TnxxExactly ShuDog, our supposed griefer was doing great, and we decided she should read our logistics expert book. Then bam, she gets quarantined out of nowhere. A functional player lost and all that's left in return is a "ration" that gives 6AP and -4 morale. Thanks for that SDF, what a great trade.

You don't know what they did on their previous ship(s) to earn their quarantine.

Maybe they outed their Mush partner, because they don't like being Mush. Maybe they didn't like how things were going on their ship, so they gave up and committed suicide with the cat. Maybe they turned off death notifications in the BIOS, and started killing other humans at random. Or maybe they (as a human) moved the ship while an expo was in progress, killing as many as six people.

These are just a few examples of things we see in the SDF reports, and as Spacey pointed out, the judges don't see these reports until after the ship is over. This protects the integrity of the ships the judges are on, so that they won't use that information to instantly know who the Mush are. Also, judges get full access to the logs. If they're Mush, would you want them to be able to figure out your Mush hunting strategy, and know who to target next? The judges have far more integrity than that, and that's why they're judges. But it's not just about the potential abuse of power; knowing who is Mush and who isn't would ruin the game for them, too.

So why do some people survive a few days on their current ship before being quarantined? It's because the judges don't see the reports until the ship has ended. Here's an example for you:

A player griefs his ship (we'll call it Ship A) on day 1, and is killed for it. They then jump onto Ship B, and start killing on Day 1 of that ship. They jump onto another ship, and start griefing Ship C. Meanwhile, Ships A and B haven't even finished yet, and so the reports haven't come in yet. When they do, the proverbial book is going to be thrown at this player, but they've now ruined each of these ships. But all you as a player on Ship C or D would see is that they get the quarantine. Well, that's tough for your ship, but it's tougher for the ships they already ruined in one way or another.

Let me make one thing very clear: People who grief on one ship will tend to do so on their next ships, until they're stopped. There are other offenses that don't tend to repeat as often, but as we've pointed out, a few minor offenses can lead to a quarantine, too.
On january 24, 2014
[7895906]
npfanHonestly, you're making up situations that are so rare, it's like asking what if the sun blows up tomorrow.

The situations shudog listed happened on my ship. It's not rare at all.

npfanIn the very rare instance where someone acts good after serious bad behaviour, what do you propose as the alternative? Let them run wild? On january 24, 2014
[6826491]

TnxxWhy can't the SDF peek into the current ship and see how the greifer is doing? If they're being a good crewmember, then let them live in that ship.
You don't seem to understand how this process works, but no. That's never going to happen, for multiple reasons. We trust the judges to do their jobs, but as I already explained, they will never have access to the logs of ships in progress. Furthermore, a judge or mod who was on a ship in which a report was filed, can see the logs after the ship is over, true enough. But they are strictly forbidden from making a ruling. They must recuse themselves in order to prevent any conflict of interest.

The quarantine process is automated; if the player in question earns a quarantine, the system makes it happen, no matter their behavior on their current ship. This was already explained by the judges who responded to you. If they were being a "good" crewmember for the first three days, and then started tossing grenades, most players would probably blame the SDF for not quarantining them before they could do any damage. Keeping tabs on players who grief on multiple ships isn't the job of the judges, mind you. They don't even know who it is they're judging, after all. While it's unfortunate that the person on your ship hadn't had the chance to cause any harm on your ship, they still earned a quarantine...and let me tell you, you have to really work at it to earn a quarantine.

The judges don't have access to ships in progress, and my previous post explains why. When they have access to a ship, it's only after the ship is over, and then they have access to almost everything - except the identities of the players on that ship, and the sanction history of the reported player(s). Every conversation, every PM, and every action taken during that ship's lifetime IS visible to them. Their job is to use those logs to determine whether or not a player who has been reported has earned a sanction. Earn enough sanctions for minor offenses, or commit a few major ones, and a quarantine is earned. I won't give specifics beyond that, at the request of the devs.

Their ruling depends only upon the events on THAT ship, not the ship they're currently on, or the ones past. This prevents a degree of bias from forming for or against specific players. Each case is treated separately by the judges, and IF a quarantine is given, it is given automatically. Quarantines may be appealed, but the best way to avoid a quarantine is to not do anything that will get you reported in the first place.
Also you have to admit some of the "greifing" rules are pretty vague.
No, I don't have to admit that. Surrender and suicide are reportable. So is hiding or holding items before the Mush are chosen. Randomly killing people without cause is also reportable. "Playing against one's team" may be somewhat subjective, but every case is handled differently, based on the specific circumstances of each.

...And then there are very clear cases of griefing. I was on a ship where our human Chao and Terrence tried to kill as many people as possible. They even waited a few days to start this. They turned off death notifications before their attempted spree began, threw at least one grenade, and then attacked whoever they could before we put them down. They did far more damage than our Mush players did, with absolute certainty, and it's obvious that it ruined our voyage. I for one would never want anyone else to have to deal with players who pull that kind of behavior.

I've been on a few dozen ships, and I have personally dealt with many clear cut cases of griefing in that time. You have said that the SDF should let griefers live, if their behavior on their current ship is "good". Most griefers are repeat offenders, and they usually don't learn their lesson after their first sanction.
If I was sanctioned and then all of a sudden quarantined, that would probably turn me towards greifing even more.You're getting the order wrong. Most griefers will grief from ship to ship until they're stopped, sanctions or quarantines be damned. The more one gets quarantined, the longer the quarantines will become. I'm not at liberty to say how long they may be. But again, not everyone gets sanctioned or quarantined due to griefing.
On january 24, 2014
Sagittaeri
TnxxWhy can't the SDF peek into the current ship and see how the greifer is doing? If they're being a good crewmember, then let them live in that ship. Also you have to admit some of the "greifing" rules are pretty vague. If I was sanctioned and then all of a sudden quarantined, that would probably turn me towards greifing even more.

I rather strongly disagree with this suggestion to be honest, for the following reasons:

- Once a griefer, always a (potentially sleeper) griefer. I'll never be able to trust such a person on my ship even if they seem useful at the start, and I'll thank SDF for yanking known griefers out of any ship I'm in.

- It's not practical to demand SDF to continuously monitor every known griefer in all ships. There are a lot of "ideally this should happen" situations, but we're restricted by what's actually possible. I'm thankful we have SDF at all to deal with griefers.

- This suggestion basically protects griefers, ex or not, which is the last thing we need. They do the crime, then they do the time. I honestly have no sympathy for griefers, and I truly believe SDF is doing all of us a HUGE favour by yanking griefers out before they eventually descend into their usual griefery antics.

- It's not SDF's fault if your ship is ruined by the presence of griefers or ex-griefers. Frankly, blaming the SDF for taking action against griefers is completely counterproductive. If you have to be angry at anyone, be angry at the griefers for getting off on ruining your ship.

- If you're able to empathise with griefers (something which I personally and consistently failed no matter how much I try), then you should also be able to see things from SDF's perspective.

p.s. I apologise if I come across as rude or offensive or fanboy-ish.

ringhlothNot being able to communicate in English is against the rules, isn't it?

It can be reported, yes. As long as it doesn't interfere with ship operations, no report should be filed over that.

If they only communicate in another language, that is most certainly reportable.

On january 27, 2014
[1384452]

Can Chao kill starving inactives for glory?
On january 27, 2014
[6826491]
MrMuzCan Chao kill starving inactives for glory?

If there is a reason to suspect them of being Mush, or if they repeatedly log in just to take a title back (but take no action respective to their role,) then it's justifiable. In short, if the usual justified reasons exist, and the crew agrees beforehand, it's fine. If it's only for glory, not so much. There is the morale loss to consider, and that can really hurt the team. It's even more harmful if there is no Shrink/Leader present.

I've also seen Chao players killing active players just for glory, after the Mush are confirmed to be dead. This behavior is highly discouraged, except as noted above, and may lead to sanctions.
On january 27, 2014
[1384452]

There's morale loss if they starve to death anyway and they are causing mild passive harm to the ship by idling on the bridge with logistics Paola.
On january 27, 2014
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

Killing them also takes AP that might be used more intelligently on something else. And there is still a chance that they will die of depression before dying of starvation, and that won't cause any morale loss for the crew (though people usually start to starve at the same time that Paola decodes the Day 5 rebel signal, which means that the inactives' morale goes up).

If they are harming the crew in any way, it is fine to kill them. If they don't do any harm, that kind of behaviour can't be encouraged, because it would let people think that it's fine to do something only for glory, which can be quite harmful.

On january 30, 2014
spacekadt
pkeodIs it OK for a person to reveal that they are a judge or claim that they are a judge while in game?

Judges are allowed to break their own anonymity at any time and in any way they choose.

It's shitty for a judge to say "I'm a judge and I'll report and sanction you!" but saying "I'm a judge and I know the rules to be this way and that we've been sanctioning for this" is totally fine.

We're not allowed to rule on reports from our own ships, regardless of whether we were involved in the report or not. Most of us won't even admit to other judges that we were on said ship until after the report has already been dealt with.
On january 30, 2014
[7742291]

What measures are there in place to stop someone who isn't a judge from saying something like that (for example, a MUSH who claims MUSH tests are bannable)?
On january 30, 2014
[6826491]

It's simple, really. Judges aren't allowed to rule on reports from ships that they've been on. And if they're abusing their authority, the other judges (and mods) have access to those logs. The truth will be there. So it's not in any judge's best interest to claim Mush tests are sanctionable, for example. It's just not true, and the SDF does not support spreading misinformation about the rules. We know the reasons not to use them en masse, and our judges are experienced enough to know why they should not encourage blanket testing.

But the context matters: it IS fair to say that we'll sanction for killing someone, just because they had refused to participate in a blanket Mush test. We also actively discourage blanket Mush testing, because they're difficult to organize, they are quite fallible, and quite costly in terms of time, AP and resources. That, and one of the primary Mush targets for a Transfer is someone who just got tested and cleared.

[7742291]

How can I report someone if I've been silenced/deafened?

[7899692]

On february 3, 2014
[6826491]
jayarseaHow can I report someone if I've been silenced/deafened?

You can use Post it notes to try to get someone else to file the report, or hope surgery will fix your ability to chat again. Alternatively, you can wait until the end screen, and report the player in question at that point. It will be your last opportunity to do so.
agewisdom
How many points will earn a quarantine? Damn, I got my first SDF points for some bad roleplaying... sighWe're not allowed to discuss the specifics of how many points it takes to get a quarantine, at the request of the devs. I'm sorry.

you can also report an general announcement or an mission that has been given to you, if there are any.

On february 5, 2014
[6826491]

It IS an easy way out, no doubt about it. Taking off with the extinguishers and extinguisher BP will doom most ships. Granted, there's Automatic Sprinklers, and they might get another extinguisher BP from Xyloph, but it's still a cheap way to "win". There's no finesse or strategy to it, just like taking off with the Hacker Kit...which is why you're no longer allowed to take off with the Hacker Kit.

And it should be mentioned that there are plenty of human players who will refuse to participate in blanket Mush testing. It should also be mentioned that killing a player just because they refused to participate in blanket Mush testing is something that can be reported. If they've been singled out, and other evidence exists to suggest they may be Mush, that's a bit different. But if no evidence exists, and the Mush testing is being used on everyone in place of an investigation, then killing a player who refuses to participate is sanctionable.
On february 5, 2014

Granted, there's Automatic Sprinklers, and they might get another extinguisher BP from Xyloph, but it's still a cheap way to "win". On february 5, 2014
Pyrrhus

To what extent are self-actualised deaths reportable?
i.e. When a death is inavoidable and essentially slow-motion torture, such as having multiple injuries such as haemorrage and smashed legs which disallows all movement (even using the scooter, as Spazticus suggested) to the medlab and there's no medic or medic magebook, is it wrong to attempt to persuade the rest of the crew to leave you to die instead of waste several AP cycle to cycle healing you such that you're kept alive? If that is okay, is it not okay to use empty threats to persuade them into not healing you?

Also what extent is testy, aggressive or 'discourteous' behaviour a sin?
Asking these questions for clarification after an issue in a recent ship where I ended up asking in the Q&A about possible solutions (due to reasonable paranoia about their actions) to crew-members that were being aggressive when I told them that taking weapons and spacesuits to eject in at the start of the game were suspicious if not selfish. Neither crew-member was otherwise doing damage, so although they became insulting saying I sperged out and was a jackass, and I admittedly reacted and snapped back calling them selfish, I felt it was largely a no-brainer that it wasn't worth it to report/murder them for so little, though advised that their aggression was reported. After I died, they noticed my posts in the Q&A and ended up reporting me for my apparent aggression in game and I ended up with SDF points for having broken 'Netiquette' rules.

Tl;dr What's the limit of 'discourteous' behaviour? Though my own behaviour was also suspect, it was largely reasonable and backed by a fear of mush and griefers ('Oops I had to eject, for the Nth time', 'Oh look the suspicious person which was just touring the storage rooms dirty just knifed someone' ), and begs me to ask if we're supposed to have wholly benign relationships on board a ship, or that human players are only allowed to have lukewarm disagreements to ward against breaking fairly ambiguous rules of netiquette?

Thanks in advance for your time, and apologies for the wall of text!
On february 5, 2014
Nidhoeggr

On february 5, 2014
spacekadt
PyrrhusTo what extent are self-actualised deaths reportable?
i.e. When a death is inavoidable and essentially slow-motion torture, such as having multiple injuries such as haemorrage and smashed legs which disallows all movement (even using the scooter, as Spazticus suggested) to the medlab and there's no medic or medic magebook, is it wrong to attempt to persuade the rest of the crew to leave you to die instead of waste several AP cycle to cycle healing you such that you're kept alive? If that is okay, is it not okay to use empty threats to persuade them into not healing you?

This is kinda tricky since your death is a morale hit to the rest of the crew. If a report came through like this, I expect it would be a lengthy discussion in the judges forum.

PyrrhusAlso what extent is testy, aggressive or 'discourteous' behaviour a sin? {cutting examples because it's long and people read it already}

First thing to note, unless it's EXTREMELY egregious or violates the T&C of the site, a normal language sanction doesn't actually have any points. It's just the only way judges and mods have of saying "hey, you're walking a thin line and should be more courteous to your crewmates!"

However, it does reflect on your account history and mods may or may not see a bunch of language sanctions one day and decide you need some points or a temp quarantine. I don't know the chances of that happening, but it's there.

Normally, expressions of frustration or people using swear words for fucking emphasis (see what I did there? ) or cases like that are going to get cleared. When things start getting iffy is when someone starts insulting other crewmates. Calling someone an idiot for doing something you don't like probably won't get sanctioned. Asking someone if they're "fucking retarded" for doing something you didn't like probably will get sanctioned. Start throwing around racial, gender, religious (etc) slurs and you're probably going to get a T&C violation which does come with points.

We're all grownups here and should be able to handle the occasional "fuck you" or "idiot" and I don't think any of us have any desire to turn this into the ultimate nanny state where we care if you curse. But there is definitely a desire to keep people from being abusive toward others... and if someone isn't sure where that line is, it's probably best not to test it.
On february 6, 2014
pkeod
NidhoeggrHey, I purchased flair items today (both the heart and the heart). I only wanted to buy one, though (damn lags) and now I have two falir items on my character which looks kinda stupid, is there a way to fix it?
Like transferring one flair item to another character?

Go here http://mush.twinoid.com/me

Click My Settings.

You can enable/disable there. The flair will be on all of your characters.
On february 6, 2014
NERON

Is it legal to refuse to take a mush test as a human, knowing that you'll probably get killed for it? Or is it considered suicide?
On february 6, 2014
mario6424

Mush Tests updated Jan 29/14
While Mush tests are allowed it is not just to kill someone who refuses to take one. The player might not have AP, might not want to be sick if the test would make them so or the player might just not want to partake in the test because they don't like them. Refusing to do the test alone is not a valid reason to kill someone. If this is the only evidence you have that someone is Mush, it's not enough and could be seen as an unjustified killing which will net a sanction.

mario6424

No there will not you just refuse to be apart of the mush test.

On february 6, 2014
NERON

What if say, we're in the situation when everyone on Eleesha's list (or the entire ship) has been eliminated as mush by a mush test? Excluding the mush in question, of course. Would it still be illegal to kill the mush for this?

My ship appears to be heading this way, dispite my protest

On february 6, 2014
[6826491]

Well, that's the problem with just relying on the list...Her list only guarantees ONE Mush, and if said Mush is already dead, then it has already done everything it was guaranteed to do. Sometimes it has both Alphas on it, and sometimes it happens to have one or more betas as well (though it can also include Chun...)

But there are a few ways to proactively (and more importantly, voluntarily) prove yourself as human, without being forced pressured into a Mush test, per se. Go on an expo, and if you come back ill, and get cured, that's one way. Another is to assist in the killing of a Mush suspect, and get a psychological illness. I personally prefer these sorts of voluntary measures (that technically count as "tests", granted) but only when they are used in a way that is both immediately helpful and not wasteful of resources.

I'm vehemently against blanket Mush testing, because it's wasteful, not in the spirit of a fair investigation, and it's just brute forcing a puzzle that can typically be solved through patience, careful observation, and...you know, detective work...

It's also true that if you are killed strictly because of your refusal to take such a test, the player(s) who killed you may be reported, and they may see a sanction. Being on Eleesha's list isn't necessarily sufficient evidence, since most of the people on that list will be human. I'd say they need more proof than that: Hiding/holding one or more crucial items; working on projects or research that the team doesn't want yet; being in places one shouldn't be; being dirty without explanation; proof of actions that are interfering with ship operations is what they need... and that's not an exhaustive list. But if they don't have any of that, they don't have more than their suspicions and the list.
On february 6, 2014

On february 7, 2014
[7922882]

Keep in mind it's difficult to sanction inactivity. Unless you outright state "I'M NOT PLAYING ANYMORE BECAUSE I DISAGREE" it isn't possible to create solid proof you are inactive because of a disagreement. "Sorry my internet connection went down, I was busy the last few days and could not log in etc. etc." After all, it is a web game and people's real lives get busy. I'd say there is a very low chance of becoming sanctioned if you simply grow sick of a game and decide to go inactive. The developers have stated they will NOT punish inactives so they can't punish you for doing so in most circumstances.

On february 17, 2014
Azzyquemint

We encourage you not to advance anti-Mush research so that whoever is selected Mush (which could be you!) will have a fair chance at winning. Neutral research examples could be - Ultra-healing Pomade or the NCC Lens. We've also asked Blackmagic to consider having the Mush Sample (needed for anti-mush research) spawn only after the ship is full. Until then, though, this is our best solution.

Maybe I've just had a spree of bad luck, but even when I quote this text in-game I'm seeing more and more non-neutral research happening before the beginning of the game. Was there ever a hard stance taken on this? Is this sanctionable; should I report it?

Edit to add: Is it considered playing against your team, if you've advanced anti-mush research then get chosen to be Mush?

On february 18, 2014
Annette
Azzyquemint

Maybe I've just had a spree of bad luck, but even when I quote this text in-game I'm seeing more and more non-neutral research happening before the beginning of the game. Was there ever a hard stance taken on this? Is this sanctionable; should I report it?

Edit to add: Is it considered playing against your team, if you've advanced anti-mush research then get chosen to be Mush?

Hi! It happens so rarely but if it does, it's up to the judges to decide if a game has been spoiled so you could be sanctioned. Neutral play is best, it's most fair and the best course of action because indeed, you could be Mush and after finishing the Antispore Gas well, that's not fair and you screwed yourself and your Mush partner. So, it's rare to have to many active players working hard and finishing research before Mush are selected it's just best to play neutrally and not do Mush research, no matter, before Mush are chosen.
On february 18, 2014
fearpils

When playing in castings, normal rulea do not apply for example, humans and mush can work together. Is the same true for multi accounts? My main reason for this question would be to test somethings out, but I do not have 31 friends to help me out on that.
On february 18, 2014
Annette

It's never okay to have multies.
On february 18, 2014
fearpils
ScoutIt's never okay to have multies.

Too bad, is it the only rule that remains in castings?
On february 18, 2014
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

Multi accounts are forbidden by the general Twinoid T&Cs. It's different from the rules of Mush itself.

There are still rules in castings, though. Playing differently is allowed (for example human and mush can cooperate on some ships), but only if it is agreed in advance and if everyone agrees. Lots of castings do classic ships, with mush hunt, humans trying to kill mush, mush trying to convert humans, kill and sabotage the ship. On ships like that, the usual rules apply : the mush can't out themselves or each other, and humans can't play against their team either.

And of course griefing isn't allowed. No one can start killing for no reason or sabotage the ship in any way just because it's a casting ship.
On february 18, 2014
fearpils
Peanutz

Multi accounts are forbidden by the general Twinoid T&Cs. It's different from the rules of Mush itself.

There are still rules in castings, though. Playing differently is allowed (for example human and mush can cooperate on some ships), but only if it is agreed in advance and if everyone agrees. Lots of castings do classic ships, with mush hunt, humans trying to kill mush, mush trying to convert humans, kill and sabotage the ship. On ships like that, the usual rules apply : the mush can't out themselves or each other, and humans can't play against their team either.

And of course griefing isn't allowed. No one can start killing for no reason or sabotage the ship in any way just because it's a casting ship.

unless you decide on a free for all last man standing. Or gender team death match. You just need to follow twinoid rules and before the ship start decide what mush rules are void and what new rules you add. Correct?
On february 18, 2014
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

Yes, that's correct. It's just like any game between friends, really. If you play scrabble with friends, you can decide before the game starts that you're going to invent new rules. But you can't start a game and then say "hey, now I'm going to use words that don't exist in the dictionary". It's the same on Mush. You can decide beforehand that the whole ship is going to be a giant battlefield with everyone trying to be the last man standing. But you can't suddenly decide that you're going to kill everyone.

On february 21, 2014
Pyrrhus

When Casting comes into action, will the same general principles that you judge the games now, be applied?
What is general SDF opinion of possibility of ships (in casting) that play against the original point of the game for the sake of reaching the highest count of days and Glory? By which I mean the deliberate mushification of players and other gameplay which is counter to the 'point' of Mush.

How does the SDF feel about deliberate spading?
On february 21, 2014
[6826491]

Castings will allow for friendly Mush, and deliberate mushification, provided everyone involved in the casting agrees to either or both of these before the jump starts. Since castings don't count for rankings like normal ships do, there's much more leeway involved in what you can do, and not all of the standard rules apply.

I haven't participated in them yet myself, but I do know a lot of spading has happened on casting ships on the French server. So I see no reason why we would disallow it here.
On february 22, 2014
npfan
sperbi3. The new question was whether it is ok to kill Chao or whether that is sanctionable (and not whether it is allowed in the rules for a Chao to punch and torture people-which probably also needs a good reason) . And yes, if he is annoying and torturing with too much damage without being able to convince the crew that he had a good reason and the crew is suffering from it they can just kill him. It's Chao's fault if he doesn't use his skill carefully. He shouldn't expect that other people are happy about using lots of their aps always to heal his tortured persons or that tortured people have to hope that someone is healing them before a sheet of metal or even the mush would kill them or before the next expedition is starting.

If you think Chao is too much a threat for the humans, you can kill him. However, you should try to talk him into being more careful with his Torture first.

On february 24, 2014
[6826491]

We can't discuss the specifics, sorry. Reports that get filed don't get looked at until after the ship is over, and we're forbidden from publicly discussing the details of the reports. So I can tell you that the report will be looked at, and if you want to read more about the process, look here. But you won't be informed about whether the person you reported was sanctioned or cleared.

On february 24, 2014
[6826491]

We can't discuss the specifics on how sanctions work. Only the mods know that information, and at the request of the devs, we're not to discuss those details. Again, sorry.

All I can say is that some sanctions may lead to an immediate quarantine, while other infractions will add up, and may lead to a quarantine later.

On february 26, 2014
[7950824]

Hah jayarsea, I kill people I think are griefers faster than I kill people I think are mush.

I wanted to comment my 2 cents on the torture/suspicion/intense limitations stuff.


I haven't played on a ship that tried to do a lockdown and keep tight control of everything and everyone yet, closest I've had was ships were extremely voluntary 'self reporting' was encouraged.

All that AP that a player like that Chao is putting into tortures (and heals? Heals were never mentioned, save that Chao feared to hurt people 'too much' because that would harm expo chances *shiver*) could be considered a waste, and waste hurts ships. The more waste, the more hurt.

And too, 'we' (whomever is on the ship) sort of need to get along and trust and help each other over the long run. That can be hard to do with 'highly hostile to all' play. That sort of play may encourage boredom, dislike of the game, and a desire to do anything other than play mush while on that ship.

Another factor is those tortured by Chao, especially if not healed and publicly protesting the treatment, provide potentially tempting targets for Mush wanting easy kills. Sure doesn't help the anti-mush research get done faster either.

The play quoted in the logs appeared to help lead to the deaths of 2 humans, possibly more. I understand the anger that can lead to a question of 'is it sanctionable'; I also don't think so based on the evidence shown - but as a player on that ship I do believe I'd be doing something about it. Most likely discussing, extremely verbosely, why what Chao was doing was harmful, how it was harmful, and (privately with him, if real communication seemed possible) a better way to do the mushhunt, one that wasted less and did less damage to the ship's ability to form a natural and efficient team.

Because I have been on ships where there was nothing like that level of anti-player hostility, and where the mush got caught. I've been on several ships where Eleesha was inactive, Chao had only shooter, Chun didn't have premonition, and there was next to no way to 'formally mush hunt' as was being done on the ship with quoted logs - and we still caught the mush. There's more than one way to wash a mush down the drain

Good luck and high creativity to all who struggle with these issues and others - may the challenges bring you joy.
On february 27, 2014
Morbidmind

I have a question about how the ship selection process works when choosing a character. As an example, a flatmate and myself both play mush. On multiple occasions we have tried to jump together, and ran into a situation where one of us will have a selection between 1-3 characters, and the other an obviously new ship. When we return to the mush homepage and wait several minutes, and the player with the previously full ship enters character selection they'll now have the 1-3 spread. Is this a measure from twinoid to avoid multi accounting, or freak coincidence?
On february 27, 2014
npfan

Several ships get filled up at the same time, so it's very likely to have you and someone you know get character choices for different ships.
On february 27, 2014
Morbidmind

I'm aware of that I was more wondering if because its the same ip there was a measure in place to ensure you couldn't find the same ship.
On february 27, 2014
npfan

It is possible for people with the same IP to be on the same ship, so I don't think there's any mechanic to prevent that. However, if it is really you and your friend jumping at the same time, it's better you two go on different ships because if by some 'freak coincidence' you end up on the same ship, your IP will be blocked from playing future ships until the mods are convinced you're different people.
On february 27, 2014
Morbidmind

Good to know, and I assure you it is an honest situation. Good lord the sort of person who would multi account in a game like this is a sad sort indeed.
On february 28, 2014
[1820301]

Is there anyway that I can report a person for being outright rude to everyone?.. at first I thought he/she is just roleplaying and I was new.. but then after joining another ship to give the game another try (and thus reading the each character's background) I noticed he/she is just being a douche about it.. I just received the end of the ship report and I can finally see his/her name.. (while looking at his other games I noticed that other people are annoyed at him/her as well)..
On february 28, 2014
[6826491]

If you've already confirmed your death (or ship's end, as the case may be) then no. The end screen is your last chance to report someone. It's possible that someone else may have reported them, however.

Extreme rudeness (insults laced with swearing in particular) can be a major drain on player morale, and thus that negative behavior can be reported. A single isolated incident probably won't see a sanction, but a pattern of hostility and insults probably will.
On february 28, 2014
[1820301]

haha good to know.. I just hoped other people even from other ships with him/her reports his/her behavior.. was my first time playing kuan ti XD now I dont even wanna play Kuan Ti anymore XD
On february 28, 2014
Alyarin

Somebody I know wants to start playing Mush, would there be any way for him to play on the same computer as me (occasionally, mind) without getting either of us banned?
On february 28, 2014
[6826491]

It is possible, but he has to have his own account (As per MT site rules, a person may only have ONE account,) and you have to take steps to not end up on the same ship. Usually this means that you would have to offset your jump times by a day or so, but it's quite possibly less time than that. If the character selection screen for the second person displays someone who is already awake on the first ship, then it's a different ship.

Note that if you do end up getting the Multi-Teamster status, you will have to contact the Mod Inbox in order to get both accounts cleared to play again. This doesn't mean you have done anything wrong per se, but we do have to stop people who try to cheat using multiple accounts.
On march 1, 2014
[6384940]

[7950824]

I'm not a judge (though I do hope to apply someday to become one), and of course I don't know what happened during your game's play (I can see the action logs from the end page, but that's only part of the story) but if you did not break the rules of the game, I do not believe you are wrong when mush to attempt to cause humans to lose through any means which are within those rules.

So, if you broke netiquette in the process of destroying the ship, you probably did it wrong.

Otherwise, you were Alpha mush. You acted to destroy the ship, and you apparently did it with very great efficiency and action, and it appears that you did so in a way that allowed the possibility of fighting back. Maybe you timed it when you knew that most peoples' AP was already very low, maybe fighting back wasn't an option exactly how you acted - that's not against the rules either.

We're allowed as mush to take human-survival-essential items and remove them from the ship; we're allowed to try to destroy almost all the fuel on the ship; we're allowed to rush Pilgred and run for Sol.

Without knowing very specific details as to how you broke the game's very broad rules - I flat out don't understand how you could have broken rules in what you did in this game - unless of course you did so with an attitude or with language which violated netiquette.

On march 4, 2014
[7950824]

But there are reasons, both roleplay and meta, not to rush research before the game is full and the mush have been chosen.

Roleplay-wise: Your characters are unaware that there are mush among you until Neron informs you through the comrades bar.

Here you are, on a ship with:
% a broken main reactor severely hampering movement
% a garden that was supposed to have plants to produce all the food and oxygen the ship needs nearly empty, with most of the pots broken so enough plants cannot even be grown
% attackers in fighters outside the ship
% a broken connection to Sol (not that this should be fixed before everyone is on board either...)
% a breaking down cryotank that will soon become unusable
% an inexplicable scattering, perhaps loss, of a majority of the ship's equipment


Given all of these immediate issues, most of which alone could prove the end of the mission - not even a fool would use limited resources to ignore these immediate issues and instead attempt to research defense against intimate interactions with Mush - there are no Mush on the ship, the closest ones are outside, shooting at the Daedalus. And that's how it is, RP-wise, until that full comrades bar shows yellow.


Out of character wise, the moderator Scout has said:
Scout
You can report pre-game non-neutral research if it has spoiled or made the game unfair, for sure.

You actually are breaking game rules, and may be sanctioned for it, to significantly work on antimush research. I assume minor progress may be ignored, but why even approach rule breaking? Once your ship is full - then sprint through the research if you wish. At that point it is fair, and reasonable, IC and out.
On march 4, 2014
Secondary

Only to disturb the game?! You dont understand mush at all then do you, their point is to kill you and destroy the ship!
On march 4, 2014
[1820301]

I dont think this is a game where you can just chose not to play your role if it happens you were mush/human.. I understand some people have references.. may it be characters or teams.. but if no one wants to play let's say (just for example) chao.. do you think a ship can be completed?.. or what would you feel if someone does not want to play mush like you do.. and every ship they joined as a mush they just go inactive or blitz kill (and you happen to be the first kill).. do you seriously think you will still enjoy the game?..
On march 4, 2014
[6826491]
kretonYes I would, as I do not like to play as a mush anyway.

Yeah, just unilaterally decide that the opinions of those who will play the hand their dealt (or might even enjoy being Mush) don't matter. You don't get to decide to ignore neutral play, just because you want to prevent the Mush from having much of a chance. Sorry, but that's not going to be accepted as an excuse by the SDF, and it absolutely violates the concept of neutral play. Plenty of ships see success with their Mush hunts, and they wait until Mush selection to start the Anti-Mush research. If your ship isn't prepared to wait until Mush selection, that says far more about the quality of the human team than the Mush team.

The reason for neutral play at the start of the game is to maintain a closer to level playing field until the moment Mush selection happens. Whether or not you like to be Mush is irrelevant. I'll go so far as to say if you'd throw the game just because you don't like the team you're on, you deserve whatever sanctions you get, if it is reported.

If you don't encourage neutral play, then you're screwing over your potential Mush partner as well. Not to mention that a ruined Mush hunt takes away a major factor of what makes these games interesting. This is not just a PvE game, it's PvP, and the cat and mouse game is important to a lot of us, regardless of which team we're on. As I've told you before, you have to play for your team. Until Mush selection happens, encourage neutral play. After that point, rush your research all you like, if you're human.

And to the other things you mentioned, they are attacked as early as possile on most of the ships, only pilgred is often a problem but that is something else.

[7950824]

I think we may be being a bit too harsh in how we interpret Kreton's words.

kretonI never said I would do that (in response to going inactive when finding out he is mush) When I was a mush, wich was long time ago, I did what I have to but not having any fun even while there was not much research then.

I don't hear a person saying they're determined to play 'to lose' when they happen to be Mush. I feel sad and worried that Kreton hasn't found the fun in being on the Mush side yet, and might have trouble ever finding it - but that's not a reason to be harsh towards him either. And I'm sad and worried only because it's a loss to Kreton, because a perception change, to view not the ship as his friends and buddies, but his partner as his only real friend and buddy, when Mush to view the humans like he now sees Mush... there can be some really good fun in that, as much fun in fighting the enemy Humans as there is fun in fighting the enemy Mush. Kreton doesn't need to have that fun feeling, but he might like it. Otherwise, it sounds like it's alright.

All Kreton needs, I think, is to understand that there were/are reasons to avoid doing anti-mush research before the game is full of players, and I think Kreton's hearing reasons why now.
On march 4, 2014
[7950824]
Jechtimpet can I get the link from where you got that quote from scout?.. I would like to use it for future ships.. and refer them to this page and to that quote.. tyvm..

Sure thing. Spaz is also a moderator (err, Moderator or Judge? I forgot which!), and has explained even more clearly, the long version here Ask the SDF!

Spazticus

Yeah, just unilaterally decide that the opinions of those who will play the hand their dealt (or might even enjoy being Mush) don't matter. You don't get to decide to ignore neutral play, just because you want to prevent the Mush from having much of a chance. Sorry, but that's not going to be accepted as an excuse by the SDF, and it absolutely violates the concept of neutral play. Plenty of ships see success with their Mush hunts, and they wait until Mush selection to start the Anti-Mush research. If your ship isn't prepared to wait until Mush selection, that says far more about the quality of the human team than the Mush team.

The reason for neutral play at the start of the game is to maintain a closer to level playing field until the moment Mush selection happens. Whether or not you like to be Mush is irrelevant. I'll go so far as to say if you'd throw the game just because you don't like the team you're on, you deserve whatever sanctions you get, if it is reported.

If you don't encourage neutral play, then you're screwing over your potential Mush partner as well. Not to mention that a ruined Mush hunt takes away a major factor of what makes these games interesting. This is not just a PvE game, it's PvP, and the cat and mouse game is important to a lot of us, regardless of which team we're on. As I've told you before, you have to play for your team. Until Mush selection happens, encourage neutral play. After that point, rush your research all you like, if you're human.

Spaz's shorter version here, http://twd.io/e/0MDL0g/439

SpazticusSo breaking the rules isn't wrong, as long as none of the humans disagree with it? No, that's not an acceptable excuse, either. Anti-Mush research before Mush selection violates neutral play. There is no logical way to argue that it doesn't violate neutral play.

And the one you asked for from Scout, http://twd.io/e/0MDL0g/379

ScoutYou can report pre-game non-neutral research if it has spoiled or made the game unfair, for sure.

On march 4, 2014
[7896920]

To all the people that condone anti-mush research before mush selection I look at it this way. If mush were secretly assigned (not shown on comrades bar) before the game starts would you consider it fair if they could start converting crew and trapping shelves while waiting for the game to fill up? I definitely would not. Just because the game mechanics allow you to work on anti-mush research before mush selection doesn't mean that we shouldn't still strive for a level playing field. No system is perfect, and I would rather have the devs work on bug fixes and new features rather than locking things down to prevent unsportsmanlike conduct.

As Impet said there are plenty more useful things that can be done while waiting for the game to fill up. It sucks to land on a ship where you have gas and constipaspore done before mush selection and the hull as it 50%.
On march 4, 2014
Darkfirephoenix

On march 4, 2014
[6826491]
DarkfirephoenixAn easy solution for this fast mush research would be that the sample only spawns when the mush are assigned, like the first mage book. That would be an easy way to ensure neutral play for both sides, in my opinion.

I agree with you, as do the other mods. We hope that it gets implemented as well, but until then...we encourage neutral play for everyone.
On march 4, 2014
[7950824]

The power to control those things which are mine to control
The power to accept those things which are out of my control
And the wisdom to know the difference.

A paraphrased fragment from a semi-famous poem.

We lack the power to control the spawning of the mush sample, in fact we play in a game where it does spawn early and does spawn 'anywhere'. Thus it is in our collective hands, every game, to work together or not, to behave well or poorly, to act fairly or unfairly to our team or the other, both in regards to the mush sample, the research, and every other part of the game which falls under our control.

That is part of the beauty of this game, or 'social experiment', or whatever it is.

And those of us who wish to build a workable, reasonable system, we have the power we need to do so over the long term - we have the power to report, and we have judges and mods to review and correct as needed.

If one game goes bad - even if it is one game after another, simply play and report as needed. Endurance is part of Mush play; it takes a lot of endurance to keep playing each consecutively harder day! Use some of that endurance, as needed, to keep to the spirit of the game, to share that spirit with others, to embrace and uplift your team despite any challenges it faces, and to learn together - so that the next ship, if not this one, has a chance for greater success. Reporting inappropriate, rulebreaking play is part of that work towards a future of greater success, every bit as much as good play from you, team building, trying new things to solve problems, paying attention to each other, and enjoying the game is, and more - ever so many things go into this game, each of the games and the future games, all being a joy to play and each team having higher and higher chances of success, both Mush and Human.
On march 5, 2014
[8101619]

Wait, so is anti-mush research before mush selection against the rules or is it not? I don't see how it can be anything but one or the other.
On march 5, 2014
[7950824]

The mods say that if it changes the balance of the game before the game really starts (before the ship is full) then it is potentially sanctionable if reported. To me, that sounds like yes, it is against the rules.

To quote Spazicus directly: "Anti-Mush research before Mush selection violates neutral play. There is no logical way to argue that it doesn't violate neutral play."

That's very strongly worded, that it breaks neutral play.
On march 5, 2014
Darkfirephoenix

Let's say it that way: If antispore is done on day 1 and mush are assigned on day 1 it's ok, they can still extract 4 spores for the day, BUT if antispore, mushovore and the research wich let's the extraction cost 4 Ap is done BEFORE Mush are assigned it's against neutral play (and that in an hard case). So simply put is: Antispore on the same day as Mush assignment, is ok, AS LONG AS THERE IS NO FURTHER ANTI-MUSH RESEARCH DONE. (OHP, anabolics, drug destiller etc. is ok before Mush assignment)
On march 5, 2014
[7950824]

*grins* I'd be fine in seeing mushovore be completed before we have mush assigned actually... that one requires a dead mush before it can be started. I love making bug reports, so I'd be perfectly happy to see that research rushed, so as to make an even more interesting and amusing bug report (that which does not yet exist can die! Lovecraftian horrors are surely upon us)

Another thing I incompletely agree with Phoenix about -
Darkfirephoenix
So simply put is: Antispore on the same day as Mush assignment, is ok, AS LONG AS THERE IS NO FURTHER ANTI-MUSH RESEARCH DONE.

Err, not how I see it. It's not 'same day' or whatnot, it's 'before mush are assigned'. Once we have mush, even if that's D1C1, if people (mush* or not) want to rush anti-mush research, go for it. Once we have mush, if the ship can and does get all possible antimush up that same cycle, that's simply "wow", not "Foul!"

However it's not alright to do the gas before mush are assigned, because gas is anti-mush, and anti-mush before mush are assigned breaks neutral play.

*Wait, why would it be alright for mush to rush antimush? Well.... they better have a plan that includes appearing utterly human for now, and their character needs to rush research to appear utterly human. To me that's grey area play, and by itself cannot show if a mush is playing for or against their team.... I can see ways to use that to utterly wreck human chances to win (err, it involves deception and being trusted 'too much too soon', but who would think that person rushing anti-mush was mush?... sometimes no one...)
On march 5, 2014
npfan
DarkfirephoenixLet's say it that way: If antispore is done on day 1 and mush are assigned on day 1 it's ok, they can still extract 4 spores for the day

That's only true if the Mush extract all four spores before Antispore Gas is completed.
On march 7, 2014
[1826688]

On our ship we found a sprinter magebook and discussion was underway whether or not Terrence or Eleesha should read it. Stephen picks up the magebook and the knife from the storage room they are in and drops them both in Alpha dorm, then goes to sleep after updating Astropad.

At this point Hua hasn't moved at all from Bravo Dorm since the mush were selected. About 5 minutes after Stephen updates astropad, Hua gets out of bed in b-dorm walks to a-dorm, picks up the knife and magebook, walks to rear corridor reads the magebook, walks back into B-dorm and goes to sleep. Later that cycle Terrence asks her to go collect scrap and she claims she doesn't have any ap.

I confirmed as Eleesha she had only launched once since play began - Terrence and Roland confirmed she had shot down 3 hunters when she did. I run around the ship tracing her movements since play began and it's pretty clear she should have 12ap at this point.

Naturally we assume her claim that she has no ap is either a lie or she has used ap to make spores / spike people and since she is also holding a weapon we kill her. Only to find out she is human.

She was clearly an experienced player using astropad to spot the magebook being placed in a-dorm then immediately go get it as stephen didn't mention he was putting the items there in any thread, so I don't think she could credibly claim it was a newbie mistake.

Is this reasonable grounds to report for griefing and playing against your team? Or would the evidence have to be more substantial?
On march 7, 2014
npfan

On march 7, 2014
npfan
XandarthShe slept till cycle 5 so would have had 12 ap when she launched a patrol ship and shot down 3 hunters, then landed and went back to bed. Even with 3 misses (highly unlikely) she'd have had 2 ap left.

Did you check and see how many charges are left? That should tell you how many times she fired. Of course, if you no longer have that, I would estimate she used about 10 AP. It takes four to take off and land, and it takes on average two shots to kill a hunter, so she should be down to about 2 AP at that point, assuming at most one miss. If Hua actually missed 3 times, I would give that estimate at 0 AP. There's also always the possibility Hua tried to kill a fourth hunter but failed to do so.

Xandarth

The book reading incident happened in cycle 1 day 2. So minimum 10 ap, maximum 13ap when she read the book then claimed to not have ap.

Things could have been way worse. If you have to lose any mage-book hope its sprinter/cook. Just frustrating that I wasted 14 mp tracking her movements, then we wasted another 10ap killing her, lose 1 morale and the magebook only to find out she was human all along and deliberately trying to cause problems.

At D2C1, Hua is likely to have at most 10 AP unless she ate. Reading the mage book costs 2 AP, so now 8. The fact you moved 14 MP to track her makes me think she used at least some AP to move around. As far as what you told me, I think it's unlikely she had 0 AP, but I do think it's reasonable to think she doesn't have enough AP to go out to space, collect some scrap, and land back without taking the chance of being abandoned.
On march 7, 2014
[1826688]

After killing those three hunters the skies were clear. I checked charges 5 cycles after she flew (as D2C2 was when we noticed the read book) and they were full so at most she fired 5 shots and she could have fired as little as 3.

So at D2C1 she had at least 11ap and at most 13ap. Minus the 2ap to read the book and she has between 9 and 11 ap. Now as you say, 9ap is only a marginal scavenging run, but she claimed to have no ap at this point and didn't ask us if she could eat or tell us to wait a cycle.

She also didn't read the book in the dorm she picked it up or the one she went to sleep in but instead in the rear corridor, that makes it hard to claim she accidentally miss-clicked the book. On march 8, 2014
spacekadt

if there are multiple people breaking the rules, you need to report each one of them. judges can only sanction the person that has been reported (or the person doing the reporting if it's report abuse, and that has to be pretty egregious).

even in marginal cases, if you believe someone to be breaking the rules, report them. judges *do* look at the experience level of the player and will go through wall postings and private messages if need be to try to find out what happened. marginal cases aren't going to get you warned for abuse by a long shot... but it may stop a griefer from doing that to future ships.
On march 9, 2014
milanm

Is this the place where i can question my report? When is it ok to call it quits, how many people must be griefers/inactives? If i get a crew member who uses all their AP to cook the rations before the Mush spawn, several message spammers and 4 inactives, i should just "play to the end"? Would it be against rules to suicide if i get 15 inactives? No one could report me then...
On march 9, 2014
[6826491]

To petition a sanction, use the Mod Inbox. You have three days from the time you receive the sanction to contest it. This is not the correct place to discuss your sanction, as the details are never intended to be discussed publicly.

However, suicide is not allowed under the rules of the game, nor is surrender allowed. Even quitting midway through the game can earn a sanction, so don't do that, either. If Pathetic Suicide is what you were sanctioned for, it might be in your best interest to not contest it.

Even if your ship seems to be doomed, play it through to its natural conclusion, regardless of what that conclusion may be. A "pathetic suicide" sanction is given to those who give up on the game via suicide. Even if you had 15 inactives on your ship, which would never happen, suicide still wouldn't be allowed. By the same token, if you have players who intentionally commit suicide on your ships, you should report them for it.
On march 9, 2014
milanm

Thank You for Your fast and detailed response, but i must admit those are some of the silliest rules i have ever heard of. To have a game where you are forced to play a certain way, roleplay in this case, but then give no tools to the players themselves to punish anyone disobeying the very same rules is nonsense. What good is to me if someone *might* be banned after he has already screwed up my game? It's a free game, the account creation process takes no more than a minute, they can continue to do the same forever, yet i must play every game "to the end" regardless of the situation, because i actually don't want to lose my account. Is this the reward players get for supporting the development team? I committed suicide on one ship, after having been on 10 filled with griefers and inactives, i just didn't see the point in playing that game, and now i'm in risk of getting banned? Why is there a no votekick option ingame, if someone is griefing the players vote for the offending player to be removed, xx% agree and he's out, wouldn't that be more fair and useful instead of relying on an external body to glance at a few ship logs and determine who broke the rules, and who did not? Why must i pursue a game where i have 2 human crew members killing half the crew, 2 taking of in a fighter and never landing, with several inactives? If playing it is the only option, at least make it possible to remove the offending players. I was serious about supporting Mush in the future as well, but this kind of decision making makes me think that player experience is nowhere close to a priority for the development team, they'd rather have players focus on following a few written rules that ironically hurt only the rule obeying players.

Sorry for the wall of text, thank You.
On march 9, 2014
npfan
milanmI committed suicide on one ship, after having been on 10 filled with griefers and inactives, i just didn't see the point in playing that game, and now i'm in risk of getting banned?

That's because killing yourself makes you almost as bad as a griefer to the other active players and worse than an inactive because at least inactives don't purposely kill themselves immediately.
To give you an example, I was on a ship where Janice and Chun were inactive for days. Since Janice happened to be standing in a dorm and Chun helped lower morale loss, the rest of the crew made the effort to heal them every few cycles so they don't die from starvation (we already killed both Mush at that point). Imagine someone decided to kill any inactives only because they were inactive and killed Janice or Chun. Or to switch roles a bit, suppose Janice and Chun were active and thought there were too many inactives and killed themselves. Way to doom a ship that could have a chance to win.

milanmWhy is there a no votekick option ingame, if someone is griefing the players vote for the offending player to be removed, xx% agree and he's out, wouldn't that be more fair and useful instead of relying on an external body to glance at a few ship logs and determine who broke the rules, and who did not?

If you have a griefer, you can kill them. There's you 'votekick option' right there. Of course, report that person afterwards so that person will be quarantined sooner rather than later.

milanmIf playing it is the only option, at least make it possible to remove the offending players.

Again, you can kill offending players.
On march 9, 2014
[6826491]

To answer that wall of text: Two wrongs still don't make a right. Report those griefers, and kill them. That's how players are supposed to respond to such asshattery. Then the SDF takes over and sanctions those who break the rules. Quarantines are given if earned, and while yes, it's quite shitty that you had griefers ruin your ships, that still doesn't excuse your breaking the rules in committing suicide. I've been on ships in which griefers have ruined things, but the vast majority of players did not end things in suicide; we kept fighting, and tried to kill our Mush, if any remained.

In short, players don't get to bail on their ship without the risk of consequences...not so they can make a community jump, and not just because the situation is bad. Play the game you're on to its natural conclusion.

If your Mush are dead, and things are getting bleak, it's perfectly acceptable to vote to return to Sol early. However, it's not right (and indeed it's sanctionable) for one person to jump the ship to Sol early when the rest of the crew wants to keep going. We consider that a "suicide" of sorts as well, except that they end up taking the rest of the crew with them in the process - specifically, it's called a "Harmful Return" sanction.
On march 9, 2014
milanm
npfan

If you have a griefer, you can kill them. There's you 'votekick option' right there. Of course, report that person afterwards so that person will be quarantined sooner rather than later.

Again, you can kill offending players.

What kind of an option is that? They already are wasting ship resources, and you need to waste even more to get rid of them? Imagine if in a football game one players breaks the legs of player in the opposite team, and the judge says he's powerless to do anything about it until the end of the game, but the team has the option of breaking the legs of players in the offending team if they want to, handicapping themselves further because no one is paying attention to the goal of the game, scoring. The parallel may not be a good one, but it gets the point across.

On march 9, 2014
npfan
milanmWhat kind of an option is that? They already are wasting ship resources, and you need to waste even more to get rid of them? Imagine if in a football game one players breaks the legs of player in the opposite team, and the judge says he's powerless to do anything about it until the end of the game, but the team has the option of breaking the legs of players in the offending team if they want to, handicapping themselves further because no one is paying attention to the goal of the game, scoring. The parallel may not be a good one, but it gets the point across.

That's a false comparison. For one thing, Mush is a game of survival, not simply a game of scoring. Where breaking the leg of the opposing team would be cheating, killing someone trying to destroy you is not.

milanmWouldn't wasting ship resources and killing more crew count as bad too? What is so bad about removing yourself from the game in a non resource consuming way if the ship is a grief fest? I'd rather spend time playing with decent players, than idleing in an already inactive ship waiting to die...

Killing crew on your side is bad because they're supposedly trying to help you. Killing crew that's technically on your side but practically against your side is fine. It's like killing a traitor that is helping the other side win.
Also, when you say removing yourself in a non resource consuming way, that's only looking at things from your perspective. From the team's perspective, they lost you as a valuable resource when you suicide. Tell me, how is depriving your own side of resources by suiciding any better than a griefer?

On march 9, 2014
[7950824]

Milanm, I believe I understand your frustration. Like many other players, I've faced griefers as well, and had ships severely harmed by them. I believe I understand at least some of the factors why handling it the way it is done were chosen, and there's logic there. It's not a perfect system, but it does appear to be to function as well, or better, than the alternatives I can think of, once all factors I can see are added in.

Sometimes it's clear that someone's a griefer - they're breaking netiquette or they're acting to harm the ship even before mush are chosen - the first is always inappropriate for anyone, the second is inappropriate for anyone before mush are chosen, then appropriate afterwards.... for mush.

If Twinoid had the resources to police all the games, especially from early on, then that sort of griefing could be stopped immediately.

But wait; how many ships are actually in play at any time? I'm not sure, but I strongly suspect there are between 50 and 150 ships flying around at all times. Remember, there's the English, French, and Spanish servers; it's pretty clear (if you try to jump with others) that an absolute minimum of 3 ships are filling at all times on the English server alone.

Think for a moment about the cost to police all of these ships 'in play'; it's a round the clock task for more than one person per server. Think of the additional cost those employees would be - I personally don't believe Twinoid can afford this with the pricing scheme that they currently use.

But not all 'griefers' act in ways that break the rules for everyone, and not all griefers start griefing before the ships fill. Many things griefers do is only griefing if a human does it; it's fair play for the mush. Try to think deeply about what it means to have 'big brother' at hand, in a game of a mix of subtlety and obviousness... We don't want big brother confirming someone is mush or not.

These games also offer something extremely realistic: the way the justice system works is something of a neat mirror of real life policing.

After all, when you experience a crime, it's extremely rare to be able to call the police and have the crime stopped while it's still in progress. While it does happen, the real world process is usually past tense; the harm done is done. It's about prevention, and sometimes punishment, but really, the theif or rapist or murderer is stopped from committing future crimes; it's usually impossible to undo the harm done. So to with the SDF and review.

What you do have, on your ships, is street justice, frontier justice, and the absolute freedom to succeed or fail based on your own strengths and ability to build a team based on your own immediate circumstances, or not. What do you do when it's just you and 15 or fewer others, and there is no outside help, period? That's what this game, as is, is. What do you do, when you cannot turn to a greater power for help or justice? Some people quit. Others rise and shine. The ships may still die, but I attest that the lessons learned in how to make things work on a dying ship with few others struggling to succeed with you.... there's game in that too, a rare form of game indeed, and extremely educational for your future ships.

My early ships were seriously plagued with griefers, I had 1-4 griefers (didn't even bother to count the inactives) per ship for like 10 ships in a row. I also had crazy bad luck; one of my ships found only one O2 planet ever, and the pump jammed on that expo. I'm a way smarter player now; it's darn hard to kill my ships while I survive and I've been to Eden twice now.

Think more broadly, include the cost to implement the fix you ask for, and include the way it would change what the game actually is at its core. Every possible way to fix the griefer and inactive problem actually causes more problems - this is true for the current solution, but it's also true for the solutions you have so far suggested. Which has the least harm, and which form of harm changes the core values of the game the least?
On march 9, 2014
Darkfirephoenix
