But I have to give you right Impet, it would be REALLY hard on the devs to get ppl to constantly check ships (not to mention the costs) and I too got ships like yours (many inactive and some grievers), and in my opinion too those things will make you better (in more way than one way) in this game (and oin online games in general), BUT you have to have a "thick skin" in such aspects in the first place. Most ppl I met in online-games (in general) don't take such stuff easily and will quit right away, so a player should at least be a bit maso in this aspect in my opinion!

On march 9, 2014
[7950824]

*chuckles* Ehh phoenix, just being dominant works too. But no, it's a grand giant game of strategy. For every problem, there's a possible counter. Some counters have to be applied before the problem starts to have a chance to work is all. Every time your ship dies, learn why. Figure out what could have saved that ship, and try to understand when you needed to start that save. Try to understand what the warning signs were - most problems do have warning signs.

It might be that you need to get everyone to report health every cycle they are on, to gather in 3 rooms and have someone online check all those rooms every cycle, to heal injuries from plates dropping like crazy and other random damage. It might require treating having 20 O2 and no likely way to get a lot more soon as a deadly critical emergency; stop everything but planetsearch! It might mean learning to let go of the 'small stuff', the non-critical early problems, and just save up AP to deal with the problem, whatever it is, that your too-silent ship seems to be brewing.

In a football game you play versus the opposing team, Mush in our case, but imagine if half your team is trying to sabotage you too, griefers in our case, instead of helping as they were supposed to, not very fun is it? And while you're "killing" your team, the enemy prospers.

On march 9, 2014
[7950824]

Possibly not perfect, sadly. Many of the same actions that make a griefer a griefer.... is not griefing when done by a mush.

How do you suggest handling the separation of votekicking a griefer versus not actually kicking a Mush?

How does vote kicking handle the variable number of inactives, who are not there to place a vote?

Even when griefing happens, depending on the severity, not everyone on the ship agrees that it should be reported or even that it is griefing. That doesn't matter as is - every player who does feel that someone should be reported can privately and individually report. But a vote-kick could cause additional issues in those situations, drawing a functional line between those who agree to the kick and those who do not.

As this is a free game, the griefer loses nothing if violating, but a rule obeying, possibly even paying player risks losing his account. New griefers just keep on coming, and this system has ZERO chance of doing anything about it, ever! But a votekick has a chance of working, it just needs a few parameters and it could work, even if it has some abuse potential, it would be a platform that can be further improved. There are a lot of other systems that could work, some are a lot better as well, but like i said, the current one solves nothing and never will.

This way you would have several grief ships, but after your honor goes up you'd play with equally honored players, grief free. The votekick can possibly remove a griefer right away, the honor system could potentially match trusted players with other, the current system does neither, as it possibly bans a player that has already ruined a game and does not prevent new players for ruining future games.

What part of 'you can kill griefers' do you not understand?

Now you're just making things up. There is no chance of anyone losing their account unless they broke the Terms and Conditions, such as by having multiple accounts for one person. No one can be punished for following the rules, so your statement there is patently false.

milanmNew griefers just keep on coming, and this system has ZERO chance of doing anything about it, ever! But a votekick has a chance of working, it just needs a few parameters and it could work, even if it has some abuse potential, it would be a platform that can be further improved. There are a lot of other systems that could work, some are a lot better as well, but like i said, the current one solves nothing and never will.

A votekick doesn't do any more to prevent griefers than the current system, and it just gives griefers another tool to use.
On march 10, 2014
[7950824]

And the griefers, understanding the like system you describe, simply like each other and escape it handily.

You're wrong about your blanket statement that the current system does nothing. You're wrong about your hyped up, emotional statement "this system has ZERO chance of doing anything about it, ever!".

You're wrong about possible rule following players losing their accounts; reports lead to judgment, not sanction. Judgment leads to sanction, where appropriate, and if a misunderstanding occurs and a possibly inappropriate sanction is given, that can be further discussed with the mods, and if actually inappropriate, the warnings or sanctions are removed.

One thing you can count on, every ship will be different. Between the RNG and the actual players you are with, they will usually be hugely different.

Sometimes you get ships crammed with inactivity and bad play. But you won't always. If you like the game, keep playing. See how the system as is actually works.

On march 10, 2014
[6826491]

milanm Need I remind you that you committed suicide on more than one ship, and thus broke the rules yourself? You were reported for it, after all, so the system does indeed catch rule breakers. If your griefers are reported, they will be dealt with. Also, a quarantine is a temporary ban from the game, not the loss of the person's account...and you weren't quarantined.

Your argument about others not abiding by the rules holds less weight when you don't respect the rules yourself. See: Your reaction to being told that suicide is against the rules. It's akin to complaining about other peoples' reckless driving, while the complainant is speeding in a school zone. It doesn't mean that the complaint is wrong, per se, it just negates some of its impact.

I should also remind you that the system we have in place does work, and many griefers have been stopped. It may not work to your satisfaction, but it does work. I've personally dealt with many cases of griefing, and many of those players will be away from the game for a considerable amount of time. There will always be griefers, but as long as there are players willing to file reports, and the SDF to deal with those reports, the griefers will be dealt with.

As for the "like" system you suggest? That's what some people already use to determine who ends up in their Casting. Players without a lot of likes don't get to join, simple as that. It's actually a better measure of a player's quality than Glory ever will be, because it purely depends on how useful/entertaining the other players thought you were at the end of a ship. Even Mush get likes from the humans, and vice versa.
On march 10, 2014
[7950824]

Jecht, some of the most helpful, active, and interested players, the sort most likely to earn the most likes and/or glory that you speak of (well, likes, maybe or maybe not glory as it's currently done) are exactly the players most interested in playing with newbies/struggling players.

I know I am, and I tend to get decent likes. Recently when I've been human, my ships have tended to have human wins too. And I random. I don't -want- to be shoved into some pool of 'better players'. Nor do I want to be in some pool of worse-only players.

I want the random. I want the chaos, the chance, building the camaraderie from a pool of 'who knows what'.

As is, I have that here.

But I'm not the only 'decent player' who loves to work with players of all sorts, and who prefers to have at least a few less experienced and not at all experienced players on the ship.

Players that grief don't need incentives not to grief, because griefing is their reward. There's different sorts of players, as a rule we fall into 4 main categories of motivations, with many players affected by more than one category:

Achiever: These players play to get whatever the 'reward' is. They want the best stuff and proof that they achieved it.

Socializer: These players play for the social interactions, they want people to talk to and things to talk about.

Killers: These players play to defeat others, ideally to get strong negative emotions from others. For most of them it's far better to know you've upset someone than it is to simply defeat someone - and for them personally it's terrible to lose.

Explorers: These players play to understand the game, to discover its secrets, to solve its puzzles.

Unfortunately you cannot motivate players without a strong achievement drive by achievements. Killer-type players exist, and the only things you can do with them is remove them as they are recognized or have a game design that prevents, limits, or works around their options to harm others.

Why not limit them, prevent them, or work around them with this game design? Nice dream, but unfortunately, this specific game is designed to enhance, not restrict, autonomy. Few games (that I have found) like this one exist; if games that enhance autonomy are to exist there's not much the game design itself can do to rein in killer-types; removal's the answer.

Or.... increasing the power available to players, period, which this game's design does great with.

Those players who can form a functional team around themselves and who have enough 'explorer' in their personalities to find interesting and inobvious solutions to the problems faced are going to have a great time in these games, and they're going to actually stymie some of the griefers on their ships, either by killing them faster than usual or occasionally by outright preventing the intended griefing. Some of the very best team builders may even have enough 'oomph' or charisma to draw in some of the more borderline griefers and start to sell them on the feel of the team (that's rare, but rarely possible).

But sadly, the griefers are here to grief, the killer-type player is playing exactly for that feel. More/better/different achievements will thrill the achiever-type players (which is also a good thing) but won't do anything meaningful to the primary griefers.

For those who'd like to read more about that system of understanding player motivation and classifying players, this might be very interesting: http://mud.co.uk/richard/hcds.htm

For those who'd like to take a test to see how your personality rates on this scale: http://www.gamerdna.com/quizzes/bartl...
On march 10, 2014
[1820301]

I don't really mind getting stuck in an inactive ship(well as long as there is at least one person to talk to) haha.. what Im asking for is to allow the player to have *options* go to a ship with lesser chance of griefers, help newbies, or just click the random button and it will select it for you like what you guys enjoy (the randomness keeps the game from getting boring)

my other point is if I haven't met my 3rd ship crew I don't think I would even play this game anymore.. first 2 ships were dead.. even as mush I did not enjoy it(it may be just me Im just voicing out my opinion so don't get angry) I don't know what else to say.. because I for one do not enjoy waiting for a ship to fill up for 15 hours waiting for that one last person to pick the last crew member and finding out that the ship is silent.. or a crewmember killing chun even before the game starts.. I hope I did not offend anyone of you and I think the current rules is sufficient, but if it can be improved why not right?..

On march 12, 2014
[7950824]

Nah, I think this is the right thread for this. Or could be at least. Kreton sincerely intended to turn to the people who make and enforce the rules to ask for help to a real problem; he wants good guidance about a solution that will work for players like Kreton (and Kre is not the only one who is like this).

If players like Kreton cannot work with the team, then they really don't enjoy the game much - emphasis on the 'really'; doing something that hurts the goals of the other players, it feels bad, emphasis on the bad. This may sound insignificant to people less affected by this level of empathy and morality, but for some of us the entire point of games like this is the team goal and working with others to achieve the shared team goal in a positive and uplifting way - it's a bit like being a committed anti-griefer (and we all know griefers do it because they are motivated inside to do what they do - it's very much the same for an anti-griefer).

Witness that Kreton mentioned that he felt bad about spiking another player; by itself that's literally nothing but the AP to make and place the spore; he didn't mean the full conversion, even giving one spore was distasteful - and some of that is probably the inefficiency but a huge amount of it is probably the betrayal of trust - as an anti-griefer you just don't do that. You don't want to do it, you can think twice, heck think ten times about it and it still seems 'wrong'. Call of the Team is pretty powerful for some of us.

So, Kreton: There's ways past the guilt, but they sort of involve changing some pretty important parts of yourself; I wouldn't bother with that for this reason.

Instead, I suggest one of two different paths:

First, consider your Mush Partner; if that player is highly interactive and knows what they want to do, it may be possible for you to focus tightly on that actual other player being your teammate. Focus on helping that other person, the same way that you probably sometimes focus on someone in the team to be 'more right' than the rest, if there's leadership issues or a difference in opinion about what to do. If you happen to have a pleasant leader-type as your partner, that alone may be enough to carry you around your distress, that time.

Second, if the first seems to be a poor idea, remember that mush have a lot of ways to win. One of which is to act completely human. A mush doesn't have to do anything mushy to win; they can, with effort and luck, glide to victory with a living-as-Mush at return to Sol or Progression to Eden. Often your partner will accept that this is how you want to play - sometimes your partner will outright help you, setting up an inactive to 'take your place' and timing spiking for you so that you can take anony at the right moment.

I can totally see a mush team, with a player similar to Kreton as one of the alphas, the other alpha converts a third, Kreton acts totally human and has all game; the two go on a berserk run and do what they do, then die; the ship may well accept that the two dead mush were the only mush, greatly easing a mush win and Kreton's quiet, humanlike survival to the otherwise-would-have-been human win.
On march 12, 2014
N_Faker

In that light.
You may stab me dead should you be mush and I human, kreton
I will welcome you into my heart.

Many of us would probably like to be turned by you, despite the frothing mouths and plans of bloody murder while still human. Turn us, so we may abandon our violent ways and join you in spreading peace.

[1820301]

I can somewhat understand Kreton and good explanation Impet.. But think of it like this.. following the Daedalus victory the mush would be eradicated..

And as mush you were born as a small organism which its only hope of survival is to "take control" of hosts.. namely humans/cats( oh yes I wont forget you Schrodinger).. (same as humans only way of survival is to take control of planets in order to survive)

Your mission is to make sure that your species survive at all costs (which is arguable the same as the human's goal).. You and your partner are the chosen ones ( HEROES of your species ).. same could be said for the rest of the Daedalus crew.. they are the HEROES of the human race..
just look at how explorations work.. The humans land on a planet to take all the resources they need.. kill alien life forms(inhabitants) and moving to the next planet.. HOW EVIL IS THAT RIGHT?..

What if there are aliens who actually thinks that we are the plague of the universe.. just look at how humans are compared to parasites consuming resources and infecting other planets (how selfish!!).. Just look at us and our views against cockroaches.. we see them as pests!

From the mush's perspective Humans must be stopped/killed due to their destructive nature and the possibility of wiping them out (The same is true for the Human's perspective, They see the Mush as the enemy which mush be stopped to ensure the survival of our species)..

What makes humans so special.. Both team's goal are to survive til the end and/or prevent the other team from winning..

I respect your views Kreton.. I am just trying to express mine.. hope you don't mind

On another note Quoting from the front page of this thread..

Anonymity
Many find anonymity to be one the best features of this game and chose to keep anonymity at all times. There is no Twinoid fame in Mush, no long time member hero worship and you are free to role play the character you've chosen without anyone knowing who you really are. Because most of us do want to keep our anonymity and not know the identity of others on our ships, we strongly suggest everyone preserve anonymity because it's more enjoyable to play that way.

On march 14, 2014
[7950824]

One option is tell them to fix their mistake, go get the soap and drop it back where it belongs, by the shower in the camera room. If they do that it wastes any spore they trapped a room with; it reduces the harm they caused if human to just the moves to get to where they hid the soap and the 1 AP they wasted to hide it.

If the player is human, and at all helpful otherwise, I'd consider writing that off with a warning and a correction, discuss 'playing against the team' and sanctions, make sure they know what the rules are, and let them live. If they have any interest in seeing a human win and playing many future games, they're likely to cooperate - and if the player is also and mostly doing good for the ship things- you only want the bad behavior to stop, not all the behavior good and bad.

Otherwise kill them, if the person is mostly a problem, and if they are human, report their rulebreaking play. Even 'little things' like hiding the soap, that's playing against the team, and if paired with other hostile behaviors, shows intentional play against the team.

Ask them questions, question 'why this and not that', debate if you disagree - but if someone lacks a plan or has a bad plan - follow them only if you want to go nowhere or to a bad place.

On march 22, 2014
[7950824]

That I know of, it is not reportable, because we are not required by the rules to communicate.

That said, I swear to you I communicate, over communicate if anything, and I support others communicating. And I have talked out the process of killing non-communicators on my ships.

However, I was corrected for reporting someone who failed to speak English and whose actions appeared to make it clear that they did not understand English (I thought it was clear), because it is forbidden to speak other languages, but not forbidden to not speak at all, or to choose not to interact or pay any attention to what others say.

So.... I believe that their incomplete communication does not break the rules. But I would talk to them about it. I think Paola especially should know what projects are 'wasted', that's useful to know if she should focus on Neron Upgrades right then or not. And the whole ship has right and reason to know and care. So do something on your ship about it (I recommend trying to talk it out), but.... for that probably better not to report.
On march 22, 2014
[6826491]

It probably will not see a sanction for that alone. If it's part of a pattern of behavior that is harmful however, then it might be reportable. The projects named are useful, granted...but the real issue here is the lack of complete communication, and things being arbitrarily decided upon without the rest of the crew having a chance to vote.

I suggest you make it a point to say that when a project gets completed, the person who finished it should post all three projects, and what each of them do. Then the crew must vote before any project gets AP spent on it. You don't need everyone to vote, but at least a few of the active players should agree before any AP is spent. I usually do this on my ships, and I don't think I've ever had a "wrong" project completed in the Nexus. I often include this protocol as the first post in the Projects thread, if I'm the one to start it.

This goes back to my Mush mantra, one that I can never stress enough: "Communication is crucial to success."

npfan

He said on his last ship, so I assume it's over. Also, it is allowed but only for certain circumstances. What effectively happens is that someone who was human is dead and the crew could think there's no more Mush, giving a huge relief to the last remaining Mush while shrinking the human team in the process.

Also, it's not a guarantee that the rules are the same in different languages. The base rules definitely are the same (e.g. no suicide, no denouncing your Mush partner, etc.), but how gray area cases are treated may not.

On march 27, 2014
[8147734]

It's been a while since I saw it, and I can't seem to find it again, but is anti mush research before ship is full sanctionable?
On march 27, 2014
[7950824]
SaviourChaoIt's been a while since I saw it, and I can't seem to find it again, but is anti mush research before ship is full sanctionable?

Here's a link for you: Ask the SDF!

Short answer it is fully reportable; non neutral actions (research or other... like hiding stuff) is sanctionable if done before mush selection.

There may be grey area cases where it is not sanctioned, every ship's circumstances are unique.

It's definately reportable though.

The term used seems to usually be 'neutral play before Mush selection'.
On march 27, 2014
spacekadt
SaviourChaoIt's been a while since I saw it, and I can't seem to find it again, but is anti mush research before ship is full sanctionable?

It's not a definable line, really. If something gives one side a distinct and unfair advantage before mush are chosen, it could be sanctionable. If you think there's been too much progress into anti-mush research, it's certainly reportable.

A few ap just to waste them probably won't be sanctioned. But if that's the case, I *highly* recommend researching the pomade or lenses (if Raluca is alive yet so people can use schrodinger for research) if you're itching to do research before mush are chosen.
On march 27, 2014
kreton

How is it with the Mycoscan and Meridon Scrambler? Could that be researched before Mush selection?
On march 27, 2014
[7950824]

I'm neither judge nor Mod, but if I were on the ship, I'd tell everyone discussing making mycoscan before ship was full, 'I think that's a bad idea'.

1) it's not neutral; I'd rather have mycoscan for my mush hunting purposes than mycoalarms.
2) it's going to take a bunch of AP. Unless the ship somehow isn't filling in the next 6 cycles or more... do we really want that many people interested in research to be low or out of AP once the ship is full? Not only might a researcher be mush.... that researcher might be human. Does that researcher really want mycoscan up before antispore gas and constipaspore, especially when that probably means we delay making those two until there's more AP to spend on them?
On march 27, 2014
Secondary
kretonHow is it with the Mycoscan and Meridon Scrambler? Could that be researched before Mush selection?

I would say meridon scrambler could be one of those grey areas, if it was possible to research it at all before mush selection, as mush arent alive before they are selected you cant kill them, which means you dont have a dead mush to research meridon scrambler.
Short answer: you need a dead mush to research meridon scrambler
On march 27, 2014
spacekadt

Meridon Scrambler is impossible... it requires a dead mush before it can be researched.

MycoScan is more grey, but I wouldn't recommend it.

Here's what I'd suggest as a defining line. If you can do the research with nothing or *only* with an item found on the ship (that isn't a mush sample), then you're good to do the research before mush are on board. If it requires a mush sample (which, technically, includes Chun's immunity) and/or Chun to be in the lab, don't do it. Come season 2, though, a lot of this should be fixed with the sample only spawning when mush are chosen.
On march 28, 2014
[8147734]

Is it ok to kill an inactive if they are affecting paola's logistics skill? Or do we need to try and work around that.
On march 28, 2014
[6826491]

If they actually have the inactive status, then yes. If it's just been a few cycles, it's not so acceptable. (Give them the chance to go to school/work/sleep/whatever, since they might come back before they gain the inactive status.)

On march 31, 2014
npfan

Allowing yourself to be cured as a Mush or revealing you have become a Mush before the ship is about to end is considered playing against your (Mush) team and/or attempting to commit suicide, which is strictly forbidden and will not be tolerated.

On april 8, 2014
[7973638]

She does nothing but eat bananas and rations from what I can tell, and never stays in Lab. What sucks is we need her alive because of the low morale overall in ship with inactive Janice.
On april 8, 2014
[6826491]

Honestly, if she's wasting resources (and presumably AP) on that level, killing her might actually increase your long term chances of survival. It's rare when it's the human players who deal more damage to the ship than the Mush, but it happens often enough.

One solution to this problem is the Natamy Rifle. Note that I don't often suggest using this option, as it is almost the equivalent of a Nuclear Option...especially against one who is most definitely human. However, against someone who is griefing, even Chun... It's a fairly reliable, if at times questionable, method.

IF you end up resorting to this option, be very clear why it's going to be used, and make sure it's thoroughly discussed well before you start pulling the trigger. Attacking Chun as a human player can often lead to a sanction, unless you have the crew on your side beforehand.

On april 9, 2014
[6826491]

Contact the Mod Inbox here. You have three days to explain the situation and/or appeal the sanction. Of course, it's possible that the sanction was for a rule you were unaware of, and in that case, the sanction will be upheld.

This seems like a terrible thing to do. It also doesn't seem fair at all. It would make sense to me that when you transfer bodies, your glory should transfer as well.

DAM091
SpazticusIt's working as intended. Glory doesn't actually mean much of anything, unless you count bragging rights and leaderboards.

On april 9, 2014
vidgin

We have Chun with one skill "Nurse". So the crew will lose 2 moral per day with Chun alive. Can I report her as griefer?
On april 9, 2014
[6826491]
vidginWe have Chun with one skill "Nurse". So the crew will lose 2 moral per day with Chun alive. Can I report her as griefer?

That alone is not a reason to report her. Her player may have spent the 5 XP to level up, and may be under the impression that the higher level skills are better ones. Hopefully that player won't make that mistake next time, but it's not evidence of intending to grief. I'm sorry, but unless she takes more harmful actions, she's allowed to make a suboptimal skill choice. Of course, if she is obviously griefing the ship, then take the appropriate steps and report her for that.

You can't avoid the ban by being the nice guy NOW, this person must have done some seriously bad stuff in his/her former ships wich got him reported and the judges said that it was against the rules what he did. I think that such an person won't even CONSIDER helping you btw.

About the quarantine: Nobody really knows when someone get's quarantined, or at what amount of points etc. (the mods MAY know it but won't tell because for obvious reasosn). But if this person has gotten this message shortly before, or right after the start of the ship, it will take at least 4 days or so to get quarantined, because you have some days to try and explain everything to the mods if you think that you are punished without an reason and ofc the mods [or whoever takes care of such stuff] will decide if the punishment is the right thing, or they can stop the punishment if they think that the player didn't do anything that deserved it.

On april 12, 2014
[7950824]

Malin. The basics of how the sanction system works, for those of us who must deal with those who break the rules is this: It's invisible to us. The only effect we ever see is if a severe or repeating offender happens to be on our ship, and happens to get quarentened right then - then they instantly die and leave behind a pile of organic waste.

However, you should know that reports are handled -after- the ship where the report was generated on ends. If that dude gets quarentened while on your ship, it will be because of new offenses that happened since his last ban (if he's being honest about that, even) on ships prior to the current one. There is nothing he can do on your ship to get him quarentened during it - after is definately possible. Likewise, there's nothing anyone on your ship can say to get him quarentened during it, no matter what is reported. - after is again, possible, if his behavior has earned a sanction.


So, why is he telling you what he is telling you? My guess is because he wants to tell you he's a bad dude. If that was a real message and if he actually recieved it, then he has clearly already served his sanction - otherwise he wouldn't be telling you anything, he would have been instantly quarentened and would be dead.

It's up to you and the rest of your shipmates to decide how to handle him. On one hand, he's clearly got a history of bad play and may be intending to play harmfully on your ship as well, with that message being simply a part of it (he is probably aware that Judges read shiplogs if a complaint is made about him - its even possible that he wished to place that into the shiplog to thumb his nose at the SDF he fully expects to soon be evaluating his play once this ship is over). However it is utterly untrue that he is in any danger of sanction -now- for any action he takes on the current living ship. Sanction, if it is earned, comes from things done on now-dead ships.

So, Malin, you and yours need to do whatever you choose to do. Be that offering a link to this post, if you believe he believes what he is claiming and trying to talk to him and gain his cooperation in keeping the ship going, be that reporting him as is for his statement, including the false claim that he cannot do anything, be that killing him because of what you quoted and other things he may say or do as the game continues, or whatever else you and your team decides.

Good luck.
On april 12, 2014
npfan
DarkfirephoenixAbout the quarantine: Nobody really knows when someone get's quarantined, or at what amount of points etc. (the mods MAY know it but won't tell because for obvious reasosn). But if this person has gotten this message shortly before, or right after the start of the ship, it will take at least 4 days or so to get quarantined, because you have some days to try and explain everything to the mods if you think that you are punished without an reason and ofc the mods [or whoever takes care of such stuff] will decide if the punishment is the right thing, or they can stop the punishment if they think that the player didn't do anything that deserved it.

Quarantine happens immediately once deserved. You still have three days to appeal, but knowing how the system works, if you got a quarantine, you deserve that quarantine. I would very surprised if you do get a successful appeal.

Malin1) I believe there is a possibility this player is lying about all the Quarantine thing. He is not doing anything, so I guess he really thinks he can't do anything. But maybe he is XP farming? Or mush? Is this against the rules?

Without going into how I know this, I can tell you that he is lying about the quarantine for himself. If he deserved a quarantine, he would dead and everyone on your ship would know.

Malin2) If we decide to kill this player, is this against the rules? Wasting Logistcs AP really bother rest of the ship, especially Chao His Blaster is loaded

In this instance, I don't think so. Feel free to report him as well.
On april 13, 2014
hippogryph

Someone on my ship, before the Mush were even selected, woke up, and picked up and dropped Schrodinger until he died. Can I report him?
On april 13, 2014
[6826491]

Yes, please report it. That's considered a Pathetic Suicide, and it usually results in a sanction if it's reported. (It doesn't require the cat, but the cat is the most common method. If anyone dies after picking up and dropping an item repeatedly, it's probably a suicide.) There are other circumstances that may lead to a Pathetic Suicide sanction if reported, including a Mush who extracts a spore in a crowded room, takes no other actions, then just waits to die. I won't go into all the possibilities, but those are two of the more common ones.
On april 13, 2014
hippogryph

How can I report him if he has said nothing? Do I have to wait until the end of the game?
On april 13, 2014
npfan

You don't have to report a post he made. You just need to report a post (ideally the most relevant post) and make sure you choose the right character to report when prompted to.
On april 13, 2014
[6826491]

You can report that player's death message. That said, you can report ANY message that isn't a PM, as long as you detail the player's actions in the Explanation. (The reason you shouldn't report PMs is because that creates a bug in the report. Don't report PMs, please. If something rule breaking is stated in a PM, then use another post for the report, and note the PM in the Explanation, please.)
On april 13, 2014
[7950824]

Nope. You just need to report any message, ideally the first message and not a reply. You can use the death announcement, or even make a message like "I am reporting X for suicide." and use that for your reported message. Just be sure to select the correct icon for who you mean to report, and include a few words about what happened in the report you write.

Don't use PM messages for reporting though - while the game will let you, the report will often reach the judges blank, which makes it hard for them to tell what if anything was wrong.
On april 13, 2014
hippogryph

Thank you.

[6826491]

In that case, you can. You've given her plenty of time in which she could drop it, and if you've repeatedly messaged her, then you have to do what you need to do to keep the ship going. It's good that you gave her adequate time, because some players would kill someone if they held onto it for more than a cycle, and that's not acceptable. There's no fine line as to exactly when it's acceptable, but a day qualifies.

In short, have a little patience, but not too much.

On april 20, 2014
kreton

No, It is only one day, you pay for Real days. And before the questions Arrives: If you run out of days while on a ship, you keep your 4 Skill shots untill the End of the ship.

On april 22, 2014
kreton

I've got an Scenario in my mind:

Would it be fit within the rules, that the Humans and an discovered mush form an alliance aginst a griefer and stop fighting each other untill the Griefer is dead? Of course they would start fighting each other again when the griefer is dead.
On april 22, 2014
[6826491]

Good question. That has often happened with Mush that aren't yet discovered - and more than a few human players would be more likely to kill a (confirmed) griefer than a (possible) Mush. There was even a case on one of my ships where a griefer killed someone, and the Mush team actually did all of the investigating; we didn't reveal ourselves as Mush, of course...it would be a human thing to investigate the incident, and report back to the crew! But it was a bit ironic that we did that, given the circumstances.

If it's a discovered Mush in the scenario you laid out? I wouldn't say "teaming up" with the humans would be an appropriate response, or even openly calling for a sort of ceasefire. Humans and Mush aren't allowed to knowingly cooperate with each other, after all. Such collusion could lead to a Mush asking for the serum in exchange, or the humans making an offer to cure them...and both of those actions are strictly forbidden.

Would it explicitly break the rules to have an unspoken ceasefire until the griefer is eliminated? I don't think so.

I think it could be silently acknowledged that the griefer is the greater threat at that very moment, since griefers who go on murderous sprees will kill indiscriminately, and may even ruin the plans of the Mush through that griefing. On the other hand, it is also a prudent Mush action to allow the humans to kill each other, and take advantage of the situation.

Considering all of the above: If the humans agree amongst themselves that the Mush isn't the immediate target, that's fine. The Mush shouldn't offer to "help", and the humans shouldn't ask for any help from the Mush, either. No "alliances" or quid pro quo should be offered, basically. For their part, the Mush can take advantage of the situation, or choose to help if they want to. Both sides have involved risks, no matter what they do.
On april 22, 2014
fearpils

Would the following scenario be allowed according to game rules.

The mush have managed to convert 3 people sneaky and anonymushed so the bar only shows 2/5 mush. One of the mushes takes a hit for the team and dies while one of the other anonymushes is in the inner cycle and proposes a great effort into curing the other one (Raluca, who is having bad ap rates due to mushy stuff and is their prime suspect, but lets say very important due to only tech.)

Now we set the plan up for raluca to go offline (she posts this on the chats, like, wont be very active tommoroww cause of traveling) and log back in at an agreed upon time (in which we know the humans are 99% asleep). We get the humans to cure her and time her conversion with her logging in time so she can take anonymush and only leave a <60s window of a mush back in the bar. We let Raluca tell a story about what she and Kuan did (or didn't do) and have eleesha confirm that she can't print the list.

The main part here is the fact that a mush gets cured as part of the plan but logs on at a by mush agreed time. Playing against team or not?

On april 23, 2014
[8144715]

Given the situation that the mush-hunting-crew has clear evidence of a person being the last mush on board, is it allowed to tell this person not to leave the room it's in or it will die and while the person stays calm there rush the serum and cure it?
In terms of Roleplay I'd consider this as reasonable but of course a bit risky action.
But in terms of rules - will either one - the people who didn't kill but try to cure or the mush who saw he has no chance doing anything more and doesn't want to die - be reportable?
On april 23, 2014
[1820396]

CellarylBut in terms of rules - will either one - the people who didn't kill but try to cure or the mush who saw he has no chance doing anything more and doesn't want to die - be reportable?Humans are okay in this scenario. Killing and curing mush is more or less the same thing according to rules - getting rid of mush.
Potentially cured mush on the other hand... getting cured is the same as getting killed for him in this respect, too. He can "act" being cooperative, but ultimately he can't cooperate, otherwise his behaviour is reportable and sanctionable.
On april 23, 2014
npfan

If you're trying to confine a Mush so you can cure it, you can do that. The Mush cannot knowingly stay confined to be cured. The Mush can choose to stay confined to stay alive if that would ultimately lead to a Mush win.
On april 23, 2014
fearpils
npfanIf you're trying to confine a Mush so you can cure it, you can do that. The Mush cannot knowingly stay confined to be cured. The Mush can choose to stay confined to stay alive if that would ultimately lead to a Mush win.

Or if a win is impossible, a better chance at a kill (saving ap and hoping to kill before the cure is ready.)

Also, guarding a room might be a better detterent to keep a mush in.

On april 23, 2014
Sagittaeri

So, I was in a ship where the Alpha mush had plans to fix PILGRED, convert a bunch of people, and fly to Sol. However, some Beta mushies had other plans and went on a murder spree instead, sabotaging the original plan.

They're both achieving a mush goal...but I think it's not right for the Beta mushies to ruin all the hard work of the Alpha. In fact, going against the original plan should be counted as playing against the team, in my opinion.

In order to prevent this kind chaos in the mush planning team, may I humbly request that a new SDF rule is to be considered:

"All Beta Mush must follow the plan of the Alpha Mush, assuming there's one. If they can't see a plan upon conversion, they should ask for it before doing anything irreversible. If the Alphas did not provide a clear plan in 8 cycles since first asked by a Beta, only then they can execute their own plan."

They're both achieving a mush goal...but I think it's not right for the Beta mushies to ruin all the hard work of the Alpha. In fact, going against the original plan should be counted as playing against the team, in my opinion.

In order to prevent this kind chaos in the mush planning team, may I humbly request that a new SDF rule is to be considered:

"All Beta Mush must follow the plan of the Alpha Mush, assuming there's one. If they can't see a plan upon conversion, they should ask for it before doing anything irreversible. npfan

No.

Beta Mush advancing the Mush cause outside the plans of the Alpha Mush is not playing against their team. Only a Mush acting with the intent of hurting the Mush team is playing against their team.

That's my point. It SHOULD be a new rule, and classified without uncertainty that it's playing against the team.

My reasoning is, if I'm an Alpha Mush who laid the groundwork painstakingly to infect Eden with 50% of the ship converted to mush, and my Beta Jin Su refuses to set aside 2 APs to go to Eden because he wanted death by NERON instead...there must be, or should be, something in SDF to say that's "bad form", you know.

Plus, this will encourage the mush to work together, and at least communicate the plan to all new mushies. It'll be a much more fun game that way for the humans, too.
On april 24, 2014

No.

Beta Mush advancing the Mush cause outside the plans of the Alpha Mush is not playing against their team. Only a Mush acting with the intent of hurting the Mush team is playing against their team.


can it be then classified like the harmful return to sol? unless the majority wanted a bloodbath.. but if it's the other way around.. then it's like the harmful return to Sol scenario right?
On april 24, 2014
[6826491]
SagittaeriThat's my point. It SHOULD be a new rule, and classified without uncertainty that it's playing against the team.

One inherent problem with making the word of the Alpha Mush "law" is that if both Alphas disagree about what the plan should be, it can lead to one or both reporting the other over what might amount to a dispute in game philosophy. Ultimately, that would make cases like this too difficult to judge, because both may have plans that would advance the Mush cause, and both plans may have significant potential to lead to a Mush victory. It's difficult to prove which one was the "better" plan to follow in light of that, even in the final analysis. There are by far too many "what ifs" involved, including what the human team would have done, had the circumstances been a little different.

Unless a Mush was clearly griefing their team in some fashion, denounced themselves or other Mush, or set themselves up for a Pathetic Suicide, it's far more difficult than it sounds to argue that they were intentionally playing against their team. But then again, those cases are easier to judge, because the rules are clear on those matters. The Mush have many more potential paths to victory than the humans do, and they don't need to survive to the end in order to have won. This fact alone makes judging under this proposed rule based more on speculation than investigation, and therefore far too subjective to be ruled fairly to all concerned.

Further, if a beta has a better plan to offer given the current circumstances, they could risk being reported for even suggesting it. Stubborn Alphas might end up ultimately playing against their own team if they come up with a suboptimal plan, and force any betas to follow it unconditionally. You all know what tends to happen to tyrannical humans who do that, and try to force those plans on everyone else. A recent post of mine in the Fail thread illustrated it well enough. This rule would put the Alpha Mush in the same position as those tyrannical human players, but with SDF enforcing their tyranny. That's going to create more problems than it could possibly solve.

The whole idea is a virtually unenforceable can of worms, and I can't in good conscience support making it a rule as presented.
On april 24, 2014
Sagittaeri

Addressing some of Spazticus's concerns...

- I was thinking the discussion of plans is not to be outlawed - only the irreversible actions that sabotages the current plan should be counted as playing against the team.

- If the Alpha Mushies can't agree to a plan, then there is no plan and the Betas can do whatever they want.

- If the Alphas were stubborn and had inferior plans to the Betas, well, then it's unfortunate but due to the ambiguous nature of which plans are "better", I think by letting Alphas have final authority allows us to skip the ambiguity issue.

I understand if you still think it's unenforcable.

Is there any other more enforcable alternative anyone can think of? There are two separate issues I'm concerned about: (1) Plans should be communicated to new mushies. It didn't happen on my ship, and thus the drama. (2) Alpha Mush's hard work shouldn't be able to be undone by a Beta without consequences.
On april 24, 2014
[1820301]

what if the majority of the mushes did not agree with the actions of one beta or alpha?.. but the minority still did it and thus messed up the majority's plan?

If it helps the Mush team, it helps the Mush team. End of story as far as the SDF is concerned.

Sagittaeri- If the Alphas were stubborn and had inferior plans to the Betas, well, then it's unfortunate but due to the ambiguous nature of which plans are "better", I think by letting Alphas have final authority allows us to skip the ambiguity issue.

After one Alpha Mush already dead and one conversion
Other Alpha: Okay, you go get yourself killed so the humans will think both Mush are dead. Then, once the serum is done, I'll cure myself. Follow my plan or I will report you and kill you myself!
Beta: If I follow you, I hurt the Must team. If I don't follow you, I break SDF rules. FML

SagittaeriIs there any other more enforcable alternative anyone can think of? There are two separate issues I'm concerned about: (1) Plans should be communicated to new mushies. It didn't happen on my ship, and thus the drama. (2) Alpha Mush's hard work shouldn't be able to be undone by a Beta without consequences.

(1) It happens with humans all the time. That doesn't automatically mean someone is griefing.
(2) What you're proposing could easily end up conflicting with other rules. There is no rule that says anyone has to listen to anyone else. The rule is you can't play against your team. If the Alpha Mush plans something that can or will hurt the Mush team, forcing beta Mush to comply is unreasonable.

Jechtwhat if the majority of the mushes did not agree with the actions of one beta or alpha?.. but the minority still did it and thus messed up the majority's plan?

Doesn't matter. What matters is if anyone is purposefully trying to hurt their team.
On april 24, 2014
[1820301]
npfanDoesn't matter. What matters is if anyone is purposefully trying to hurt their team.

so it only matters if its the human side and the majority decides to prolong the ship(Minority decides to go to sol but the majority wants to continue.. and the minority hacked the console to return to sol)?.. but if the mush does it by rampaging or doing something else it is allowed?.. so and what if because of the rampage another mush was found out?.. like the humans retraced the steps of the rampaging beta.. like the rampaging beta was proven human before by food tests and such and it now compromised the anonymushed mushs and/or other mushes..

they are not purposefully trying to hurt the team but they were adamant in doing what they wished against the majority amidst the majority's decision and instead of actually contributing to the conversion/destruction of the ship, the remaining mushes are now exposed and hunted..
On april 24, 2014
npfan
Jechtso it only matters if its the human side and the majority decides to prolong the ship(Minority decides to go to sol but the majority wants to continue.. and the minority hacked the console to return to sol)?.. but if the mush does it by rampaging or doing something else it is allowed?.. so and what if because of the rampage another mush was found out?.. like the humans retraced the steps of the rampaging beta.. like the rampaging beta was proven human before by food tests and such and it now compromised the anonymushed mushs and/or other mushes..

It's not necessarily automatic that majority wins. For example, the majority are crazy to try to prolong a ship that will get destroyed soon and the minority want a solid win. Also, the minority's decision in the case of the Sol return affects everyone in the ship. On the other hand, a minority of Mush going against the majority of Mush does not automatically mean the game is over for the Mush. If we created this proposed rule, then you would have to enforce it equally by requiring everyone must follow the plan of the majority of the human or Mush team. So many people would get sanctioned simply because they had a minority viewpoint. You're now asking the SDF to go beyond enforcing basic rules to keep the game as fair and working as possible and to essentially enforce tyranny of the majority.
On april 24, 2014
[1820396]

On topic, from just mine player's angle of view:

I really, really hate the idea, that I would become beta mush and I would be forced to some (for me probably unnatural or unsuitable) way of playing the part. Why should I do what the other guy is telling me, if I'm not comfortable with his plan or if it's downright stupid? Just because he was chosen by RNG to be the Alpha? That sounds just horrible to me.

And no, it's not the same with the human team. When I start the game I have the chance of chosing the character who suits my playing style and which I potentialy could enjoy playing even as mush. Only variable I can't chose is whether I end up being human or mush (and even that can be avoided by chosing Chun). But being forced by SDF to play a way you don't like just because someone chose you (or rather your character - we all know some characters are targeted for infection more then others) as convert, is just plainly bad.
On april 24, 2014
[1820301]
npfanIt's not necessarily automatic that majority wins. For example, the majority are crazy to try to prolong a ship that will get destroyed soon and the minority want a solid win. Also, the minority's decision in the case of the Sol return affects everyone in the ship. On the other hand, a minority of Mush going against the majority of Mush does not automatically mean the game is over for the Mush. If we created this proposed rule, then you would have to enforce it equally by requiring everyone must follow the plan of the majority of the human or Mush team. So many people would get sanctioned simply because they had a minority viewpoint. You're now asking the SDF to go beyond enforcing basic rules to keep the game as fair and working as possible and to essentially enforce tyranny of the majority.

On april 24, 2014
npfan
Jechtdoesn't 1 or 2 mush against a majority like 2 vs 3 affects the game as well if they decide a sol infect instead of the mush enjoying the converting of more humans?.. or killing everyone first then going to sol?..

The goal of the Mush is to end a ship as soon as possible, while the goal of the humans is to survive as long as possible. If the majority of the Mush want to play a certain way, they have to hope the other Mush will comply.

Jechtor when you convert someone and they dont agree with the majority instead of contributing they decided to be inactive?.. or even some people who gets converted and gets pissed off because they got converted in the first place and just idle away?..

That can be reported because then those players are refusing the play as Mush.

JechtI am not saying to follow blindly if someone asks you to do it.. but if people try to talk about it or at least discuss it first before rushing to do something or just doing something else that is against everyone else's decision because they HATE being mush..

There's a difference between doing something because you don't want to be Mush and doing something that's simply different from what other Mush have planned. The former is against the rules because, depending on what the player does or does not do, is playing against the team and possibly suicide. The latter is just something you have to deal with in a social game.

Other Alpha: Okay, you go get yourself killed so the humans will think both Mush are dead. Then, once the serum is done, I'll cure myself. Follow my plan or I will report you and kill you myself!

That's not a "bad plan". That's a plan that's "playing against the mush team". I don't even know what you're trying to prove with this example. I know there will be some subtleties that will need to be ironed out, but this example is not one of them because it's so obvious how to deal with it.

(1) It happens with humans all the time. That doesn't automatically mean someone is griefing.
(2) What you're proposing could easily end up conflicting with other rules. There is no rule that says anyone has to listen to anyone else. The rule is you can't play against your team. On april 24, 2014
sperbi

I think it was almost an unwritten law that the betamushes help the alpha mushes to advance their plan.
Why? Because it sometimes takes a great effort for the alpha mush to get a betamush and they mostly show competence with that. But of course if the alpha doesn't have a good plan, why shoudl the betamush not help him. Just to win, it is important for the mushes to work together, but good players know that already, they don't need a rule...

Most interesting mush victories were only achieved when mush player are capable to create a good plan and are working together and I think most ships have no chance to win against such mushes.
So cooperation is the key of victory, but I don't think it needs a rule.
On april 24, 2014
npfan

One of the biggest concerns players had about the SDF both inside and outside was that it would create rules that would enforce one valid gameplay and not other valid gameplays for whatever reason. That's why members of the SDF agreed that we would not sanction anyone that may be playing suboptimally unless that person is purposely doing so to hurt his team. I understand that you want collaboration. Collaboration is important for success. When you start asking for an authority to do what you want, then you start opening a can of worms. Now you're asking the SDF to enforce that some plans are better than others simply because it was an Alpha Mush that came up with it. If you want to change it from Alpha Mush decides to majority decides, then you have to be careful that you're siding with the majority not because the majority is the majority but because the majority is right and the minority is breaking the rules. Otherwise, you have a systematic tyranny of the majority. Even if you allow exceptions that the majority will be overruled if they are breaking the rules, there still is a problem that nothing in the fundamental rules the admins lay out suggest the minority can't do what they want simply because they're in the minority.

I feel like you're trying to use authority to respond to a short-sighted goal of getting what you want for a particular game. I just want you to take this into consideration:
Suppose you were Alpha Mush on game A and you make beta Mush comply with the plan of the Alpha Mush. The Mush team ends up winning, and all is well.
In game B, you become a beta Mush. The ship is in a situation that is similar to the one in game A, and you propose as the only beta Mush to go with the same plan you tried last time. The Alpha Mushes have a different plan that is a bit flawed but doesn't break the rules. The SDF has the rule in place that you must comply with that plan. The Mush team ends up losing because the Alpha Mush never figured out how to remove that flaw and the humans were able to exploit it.
On april 24, 2014
Sagittaeri
sperbi

I think it was almost an unwritten law that the betamushes help the alpha mushes to advance their plan.
Why? Because it sometimes takes a great effort for the alpha mush to get a betamush and they mostly show competence with that. But of course if the alpha doesn't have a good plan, why shoudl the betamush not help him. Just to win, it is important for the mushes to work together, but good players know that already, they don't need a rule...

Most interesting mush victories were only achieved when mush player are capable to create a good plan and are working together and I think most ships have no chance to win against such mushes.
So cooperation is the key of victory, but I don't think it needs a rule.

While I don't disagree with any of this, the problem is, there's an imbalance of power between the two camps here:

Camp A: Wants a majority mushship to infect Sol/Eden.
Camp B: Wants to rampage and get killed by NERON or hunters.

Because Camp A generally involve a bit of planning and subtlety, Camp B can ruin Camp A's plan at any time with zero consultation. They don't even need to read the Mush Channel or care about communicating with anyone anymore - they can just start the rampage as soon as they became Beta, and Camp A is completely powerless to stop it.

With a bit of modification in the rules, perhaps, I hope that some of this balance in power can be restored, such that there is more consultation and compromise between the two camps, if they both exist on a ship.
On april 24, 2014
Sagittaeri
npfanIn game B, you become a beta Mush. The ship is in a situation that is similar to the one in game A, and you propose as the only beta Mush to go with the same plan you tried last time. The Alpha Mushes have a different plan that is a bit flawed but doesn't break the rules. The SDF has the rule in place that you must comply with that plan. The Mush team ends up losing because the Alpha Mush never figured out how to remove that flaw and the humans were able to exploit it.

In this example, the Alpha Mush took the effort to convert me for their plans. I'm going to respect their plan. If I see a flaw, I'll tell them about it, but ultimately, it's their plan and I will do what the Alpha Mush wants.

Why are we back to "Alpha rules"? I thought I made it clear that I wanted other ideas that's more acceptable for SDF, but still helps alleviate my concerns. Unless, you feel that this idea has merit and you're really trying to refine it by debating it with me? I don't understand your motivation, here.
On april 24, 2014
npfan

Camp A is ruining Camp B's plan by forcing Camp B to risk surviving longer as Mush when Camp B could quickly end the game with a Mush victory.

SagittaeriIn this example, the Alpha Mush took the effort to convert me for their plans. I'm going to respect their plan. If I see a flaw, I'll tell them about it, but ultimately, it's their plan and I will do what the Alpha Mush wants.

That's your choice, and I respect that. Not everyone would be willing to make that choice though, and what you were at least initially suggesting would remove that choice.

SagittaeriWhy are we back to "Alpha rules"? I thought I made it clear that I wanted other ideas that's more acceptable for SDF, but still helps alleviate my concerns. Unless, you feel that this idea has merit and you're really trying to refine it by debating it with me? I don't understand your motivation, here.

I'm actually grouping together Alpha rules and majority rules and making the case that the SDF shouldn't enforce one plan over the other simply because one plan is from Alpha or from the majority unless the other plan violates the rules.
On april 24, 2014
Sagittaeri
npfanCamp A is ruining Camp B's plan by forcing Camp B to risk surviving longer as Mush when Camp B could quickly end the game with a Mush victory.

Which part of "balance of power is skewed over to Camp B" wasn't clear in my post?

- Camp B can screw over Camp A at any time with zero communication, forcing Camp A into switching tactics.

- Camp A on the other hand is powerless in forcing Camp B into doing anything.

This imbalance in power is leaving a VERY bitter taste in my mouth, particularly because I'm usually in Camp A. The "Alpha rules" and "majority rules" ideas are some ways to improve the balance a bit...so at least Camp B will try for a compromise instead of closing communications and going on a rampage despite what the others in the team think.

Basically, what I'm saying is, Camp B right now has a free pass to ruin Camp A's plans. I don't want that. I want both camps to actually discuss for a compromise instead, at the very least. If there's an idea somewhere that helps with that, I'd like to hear it.
On april 24, 2014
npfan

And I dispute your assumption that there is an imbalance of power. Camp B choosing to rampage doesn't necessarily mean a Sol infection is impossible. Also, what you're not taking into account is that circumstances can change to where a Sol infection is no longer viable. In all my times I've been Alpha Mush, I always start with the goal to infect Sol. Including beta season, I've only pulled that off twice out of I guess maybe seven or eight. The main reason is that I recognise when a Sol infection is no longer and a rampage is the way to win. I can easily imagine some stubborn Mush wanting a Sol infection even when that may not be the best plan for the Mush. However, because you have stubborn Alphas or a stubborn majority, an enforcement by the SDF that their plan must be followed could in fact lead to defeat. This is why I fundamentally oppose any rule that would enforce one camp above another that is determined by factors not having to do with whether a plan complies with the rules or not.
On april 25, 2014
spacekadt

Simply put, the game encourages people to play for glory, regardless of what team they're on.

Just like we won't sanction the person that wastes their AP playing with Mad Kube (usually), we're not going to sanction someone for playing the game as it was designed to achieve a mush win with as much glory as they can possibly keep/attain.

I flat out refuse to determine that one way of playing is more valid than another when both are within the rules. If you're an alpha and don't want your plans ruined, be careful who you convert.
On april 25, 2014
Sagittaeri
spacekadt

Simply put, the game encourages people to play for glory, regardless of what team they're on.

Just like we won't sanction the person that wastes their AP playing with Mad Kube (usually), we're not going to sanction someone for playing the game as it was designed to achieve a mush win with as much glory as they can possibly keep/attain.

I flat out refuse to determine that one way of playing is more valid than another when both are within the rules. If you're an alpha and don't want your plans ruined, be careful who you convert.

But, my argument is that the current rules actually does favour one way over another. Take this for example:

1. A new mush goes on rampage and sabotages an established and agreed upon mush plan by the majority. SDF allows it.

2. However, now consider the Alpha who stops them from sabotaging their "Return to Sol" plan, say by killing the rampager (in a ship already dominated by Mush, but PILGRED not yet finished). SDF sactions the Alpha for playing against the team. To clarify, in this example, the humans most likely are powerless to fight back, so the mush are only deciding between NERON death or Go to Sol.

Both paths lead to Mush victory. But only one path is sanctionable. In this example, SDF indirectly favours one path over the other.

But, I agree, making MORE things sanctionable is not good for SDF. How about the opposite? Allow mush to kill the mush on a rampage (assuming it's done to support another mushy plan, instead of just helping humans), regardless of how many humans there are left in the ship. That way, mush planning to go on a rampage will at least communicate with their mush team first.
On april 25, 2014
npfan

It's already allowed for a Mush to kill another Mush if the other Mush is already publicly known to be a Mush. The reason being the first Mush can look like a human killing a Mush. However, it must be clear that a Mush killing the other Mush is more beneficial than helping the Mush. In other words, you need to have a good reason to kill your fellow Mush, just as a human needs to have a good reason for killing a fellow human.
On april 25, 2014
Sagittaeri
npfanIt's already allowed for a Mush to kill another Mush if the other Mush is already publicly known to be a Mush. The reason being the first Mush can look like a human killing a Mush. However, it must be clear that a Mush killing the other Mush is more beneficial than helping the Mush. In other words, you need to have a good reason to kill your fellow Mush, just as a human needs to have a good reason for killing a fellow human.

I feel like my point of "I suggest the rules to be modified a little" is not getting through.

I want to remove the stipulation of "can only kill mush-on-rampage if it's clearly more beneficial to mush team". Which actions are more beneficial is highly subjective.

I think it should be changed to "can only kill mush-on-rampage if it's to help another mushy plan". It's a lot easier for SDF to determine if there's another plan, than it is to weigh the worth of both plans against each other.

So, in the modified rules, only random killings and griefers are sanctioned. But, mush of both camps now have equal power over each other, and they'll have to work things out with each other if they don't want to be killed by their partner.
On april 25, 2014
npfan
SagittaeriI feel like my point of "I suggest the rules to be modified a little" is not getting through.

And I feel like my point of 'You're just trying to change the rules for selfish reasons without consideration of other points of view' is not getting through.
On april 25, 2014
[1820301]
npfanAnd I feel like my point of 'You're just trying to change the rules for selfish reasons without consideration of other points of view' is not getting through.

correct me if I am wrong but I think Sagittaeri's suggestion may be modified so the converted mush can have a middle ground.. like I do not want to sanction players because the only thing they want to do when they turn to mush is to rampage.. or even rampage as soon as mush was selected.. I just think that the SDF can send in a warning to players to at the very least listen to the suggestions of their team and not go berserk as soon as they are converted..
On april 25, 2014

I'm guessing you have not noticed that I've evolved my suggestion multiple times since I began this discussion precisely because of "consideration of other people's point of views".

Unless, you're referring specifically to your point of view, which as far as I can tell is "these are the rules", which in itself is not a refute of my current arguments.
On april 25, 2014
Sagittaeri
Jechtcorrect me if I am wrong but I think Sagittaeri's suggestion may be modified so the converted mush can have a middle ground.. like I do not want to sanction players because the only thing they want to do when they turn to mush is to rampage.. or even rampage as soon as mush was selected.. I just think that the SDF can send in a warning to players to at the very least listen to the suggestions of their team and not go berserk as soon as they are converted..

SDF aren't devs, so they can't code in a popup message in the game, I believe. Unless, you mean after-the-ship warning?

Also, while a warning could help with new players who aren't sure what's going on, I think it won't do anything for experienced players who knows exactly what they want...

Anyway, I've moved away from the "sanctioning rampager" suggestion now, since it's clearly unpopular for a number of valid reasons. If we can't achieve equality by sanctioning, then perhaps we can achieve equality by "not sanctioning killers of rampagers if it's for another mushy plan".

This way both teams have equal power, and are much more likely to be open for discussion. Not to mention the added bonus of having simpler SDF rules (which I hope is more enforcable?). Any thoughts on this suggestion?
On april 25, 2014
npfan

Yes, you have evolved your suggestion, but the fundamental issue is still there, which is you want to have some systematic way of having one legal plan preferred over another. The goal of the Mush is to win. The goal of the Mush isn't that they should attempt Sol infection before anything else. Another aspect that hasn't been discussed is trying to apply the same principle to humans. For example, where do you put the third camera after putting two cameras in the dorms? Some would say the Bridge. Some would say the Lab. Some would say other places. How the humans decide what to do is up to them. Should anyone be sanctioned for, say, moving the camera from one legitimate location to another? Or how about when there are two good NERON projects and the crew is unsure which one to advance? Should anyone be sanctioned if there are two camps trying to advance the project each side believes to be better?

SagittaeriAnyway, I've moved away from the "sanctioning rampager" suggestion now, since it's clearly unpopular for a number of valid reasons. If we can't achieve equality by sanctioning, then perhaps we can achieve equality by "not sanctioning killers of rampagers if it's for another mushy plan".

Replace "sanctioned" with "killed" in what I wrote above and the problem remains the same.

I just think that the SDF can send in a warning to players to at the very least listen to the suggestions of their team and not go berserk as soon as they are converted..
