On april 25, 2014
Sagittaeri

npfan, the irony of you accusing me of trying to legally favour one mush plan over another is that I'm actually doing to opposite. I've already made a detailed post explaining why I believe the current rules is indirectly supporting one mush plan over the other, so please refute those points by all means.

You can't interchange "sanctioning" and "killing" - they're not the same thing. One is about SDF intervention which can lead to account suspension, and the other is about social engineering which can lead to more collaboration. Why would you even claim that it's interchangeable?
On april 25, 2014
npfan
Sagittaerinpfan, the irony of you accusing me of trying to legally favour one mush plan over another is that I'm actually doing to opposite. I've already made a detailed post explaining why I believe the current rules is indirectly supporting one mush plan over the other, so please refute those points by all means.

And I already explained how it doesn't.

SagittaeriYou can't interchange "sanctioning" and "killing" - they're not the same thing. One is about SDF intervention which can lead to account suspension, and the other is about social engineering which can lead to more collaboration. Why would you even claim that it's interchangeable?

You're asking the SDF to allow killings simply because someone doesn't follow a plan. Although no one would get a sanction if that rule change was made, I still find you're trying to find some means of having one legal plan being superior over another legal plan. Again, going to my example, do you really think it would be fair and justifiable to kill someone for, let's say, advancing Automatic Sprinklers over Fire Detector just because someone wanted Fire Detector over Sprinklers?
On april 25, 2014
[1820301]
npfan

And I already explained how it doesn't.

You're asking the SDF to allow killings simply because someone doesn't follow a plan. Although no one would get a sanction if that rule change was made, I still find you're trying to find some means of having one legal plan being superior over another legal plan. Again, going to my example, do you really think it would be fair and justifiable to kill someone for, let's say, advancing Automatic Sprinklers over Fire Detector just because someone wanted Fire Detector over Sprinklers?

I think so.. if everyone agreed to advance fire detector.. and only 1-2 person rush relayed sprinklers against everyone else's plan.. and everyone on the ship agrees to kill them both then why not?

Fixed typo
On april 25, 2014
Sagittaeri
npfanAnd I already explained how it doesn't.

I failed to find the post where you refuted my latest points on this issue. Perhaps you'd like to (re)explain it?

npfanYou're asking the SDF to allow killings simply because someone doesn't follow a plan. Although no one would get a sanction if that rule change was made, I still find you're trying to find some means of having one legal plan being superior over another legal plan. Again, going to my example, do you really think it would be fair and justifiable to kill someone for, let's say, advancing Automatic Sprinklers over Fire Detector just because someone wanted Fire Detector over Sprinklers?

This is a terrible example, because both human camps (Sprinklers vs Fire Detector) are already on equal footing. Both have exactly the same opportunity to screw over the other camp...which is to convince the other camp that they're right, or if it comes to it, finish their preferred project first. Not only that, SDF prosecutes (or not prosecutes) both camps equally with regards to killing. Both camps have the same legal power under SDF.

In the mush victory case, no such equality exists. Camp "Don't go to Sol" can execute their plan as soon as they have the numbers. Camp "Go to Sol" on the other hand had to fix the PILGRED first. There is little doubt which camp's always gonna "win" should both exist on one ship. Not only that, SDF prosecutes Camp "Go to Sol" when they screw over other camp the only way they can: killing them. But the reverse isn't true: SDF doesn't prosecute Camp "Don't go to Sol" when they screw over the other camp by rampaging.

Luckily, equality can be achieved by having less things to sanction. In this case, by SDF not prosecuting a mush for murdering a mush-on-a-rampage for another mushy plans, regardless of merit. The idealistic result of this is, before a mush goes on a rampage, they'll communicate with their team, first.
On april 26, 2014
npfan
JechtI think so.. if everyone agreed to advance fire detector.. and only 1-2 person rush relayed sprinklers against everyone else's plan.. and everyone on the ship agrees to kill them both then why not?

Killing your teammates inherently starts as hurting the team. Killing your teammates is only justified if keeping them alive hurts the team more than killing them. Killing someone just because they disagree with you can easily earn you a sanction.

Sagittaeri , you are relying on a lot of assumptions that aren't necessarily true.

SagittaeriThere is little doubt which camp's always gonna "win" should both exist on one ship.

While it's true you can't stop a Mush that's going to rampage no matter what, a rampaging Mush doesn't mean a Sol infection is impossible. Even if a Sol infection does become impossible, so what? What entitles that camp to win by Sol infection? Who said a Mush has to win by Sol infection? What if a Mush wants to infect Eden? As soon as PILGRED is fixed, a Mush who's Commander or who has the hacker kit can go to Sol and completely disregard Eden infection. Should we then allow Camp "Go to Eden" to kill anyone that favours Camp "Go to Sol" so no one from Camp "Go to Sol" can ruin the plan of Camp "Go to Eden"?

SagittaeriNot only that, SDF prosecutes Camp "Go to Sol" when they screw over other camp the only way they can: killing them.

That's because Camp "Go to Sol" is playing against the team by lowering their numbers and hurting the Mush's chance of winning. Also, there is no need for anyone from Camp "Go to Sol" to kill any Mush. A rampaging Mush is going to be killed by the humans anyway.

SagittaeriBut the reverse isn't true: SDF doesn't prosecute Camp "Don't go to Sol" when they screw over the other camp by rampaging.

If the rampaging Mush has a better chance of winning for the Mush than Camp "Go to Sol", wouldn't it be playing against the Mush to allow Camp "Go to Sol" to kill the people that choose what's best for Mush victory?

SagittaeriLuckily, equality can be achieved by having less things to sanction. In this case, by SDF not prosecuting a mush for murdering a mush-on-a-rampage for another mushy plans, regardless of merit. The idealistic result of this is, before a mush goes on a rampage, they'll communicate with their team, first.

In your pursuit for 'equality', you're proposing policies that can hurt the Mush. You first wanted beta Mush to be forced to obey the plans of the Alpha Mush. As someone pointed out, that allows the RNG to establish an inherent inequality between the Alpha Mush and beta Mush. Then you entertained the idea of majority rule. However, that doesn't address the problem of tyranny of the majority. Then, you say instead of sanctioning those who don't follow the Alpha Mush or the majority, you say allow those that want to infect Sol to kill rampaging Mush. In every single case, you want to pursue some legal means of having things done your way or someone will be punished.
As I said before, killing your teammate is only allowed if it helps the Mush win. In every step of the way, you essentially want to change the rules so that killing your Mush teammate is allowed to punish anyone that disagrees with your way of Mush victory. Are the rampaging Mush killing fellow Mush? No. Are the rampaging Mush making it harder for Mush to win? Not generally. Even if rampaging Mush makes it harder for Mush to win, does that mean having a fellow Mush kill the rampaging Mush be better than letting some Mush continue to rampage? No. You want 'equality', but your solutions boil down to is make Sol infection the default path to victory. What's equal about that? You think rampaging is better? Sorry, you're dead just because your teammate disagrees.
You say it will make SDF's job easier by giving something one less act to sanction. That is a poor excuse for changing the rules. Through that line of thinking, we should just let griefers do whatever they want and just remove reporting altogether. The SDF no longer have to work because there are no longer any rules to enforce. What you've asked for so far, whether you realise it or not, is either to sanction something that can help the team or to allow something that can hurt the team. Both cases violate the fundamental rule of not allowing to play against your team.
On april 26, 2014

In every step of the way, you essentially want to change the rules so that killing your Mush teammate is allowed to punish anyone that disagrees with your way of Mush victory. Are the rampaging Mush killing fellow Mush? No. Are the rampaging Mush making it harder for Mush to win? Not generally. Even if rampaging Mush makes it harder for Mush to win, does that mean having a fellow Mush kill the rampaging Mush be better than letting some Mush continue to rampage? No.

On april 26, 2014
npfan
Jechtit is a good cover if a fellow mush killed a rampaging mush the crew tends to agree that the mush would not kill their own.. if they want a covert infection why not?..

Yeah, it would be fine for a Mush to kill another Mush that has already been publicly exposed as Mush to stay undercover. Although, I don't think that's a good idea unless you're considered suspicious since you're using precious AP while saving the humans theirs, but that's just my opinion. On the other hand, someone simply not following a plan is not justification for killing a teammate. There's nothing wrong with a covert infection. If the Mush can pull it off, great. This is a different issue though about what to do with competing plans.

JechtI dont think so.. the whole point of my argument is so that the minority will at least try to comply or at least hear the ideas of the majority not just acting on their own.. like "hey guys do you have any plans?.. I plan to rampage ASAP but, what do you guys think?" not just rampaging right away.. like killing a person because they are convenient even with two spores on them.. or even one for transfer

Collaboration is always good for optimum gameplay, but the SDF is here to enforce ground rules. Having someone that may not agree with you or act without consulting is just a natural part of social gaming. You're dealing with other people, not AIs. You can't have authorities say players must play a certain way unless the alternative inherently breaks the game.

JechtAre you saying that a raluca and terrence both human rushing pilgred on day 1 that resulted on day 1 sol infection not liable?..

Unless they intended for an easy win for Mush, no. However, the humans do have a reason to suspect they're Mush or griefers and kill them.

Having someone that may not agree with you or act without consulting is just a natural part of social gaming. You're dealing with other people, not AIs. You can't have authorities say players must play a certain way unless the alternative inherently breaks the game.

If we allowed players to kill someone for the sole reason that that person did not follow a plan, it opens the door wide open for legal griefing.

On april 26, 2014
npfan

Not necessarily. Suppose a new player didn't know Gioele with Caffeine Addict gets bonus AP when drinking coffee so this new player takes the coffee to get AP. The rest of the crew is now mad at this player for being inefficient. Are you saying this new player deserves to be killed? Or suppose it's not a new player making an honest mistake but an experienced player who was told to only allow Gioele to drink coffee, but this experienced player thought it would be better to drink the coffee and eat a ration to finish an anti-mush research before day change. Has this player waive the right to live?
On april 26, 2014
[7950824]

I have to say, for me, conversations like this make me feel quite comfortable to be judged (when needed) by the SDF. I'm hearing wisdom in what Npfan's and other's are saying - flexibility and observation, and intelligent assessment too.

I really don't want to be judged by a robot, should I need to be judged. For that matter, I don't really want to play a black and white game, where I can't do something that I decide is sensible because there's a rule that flat out stands in my way, and I have to not take a reasonable, perhaps perceived to be vital action because of that darn rule and blanket interpretations of it.

What I'm hearing is that if I come to be judged, they're going to look at quite a few factors...

I'm also hearing that I cannot control my team, only myself.... well alright, that's sensible, because it means that my team cannot control me then either...

I'm hearing that if I, alpha mush, make a beta mush, I don't get to control them... well, alright, I'm fine with that, I don't really want to be controlled by the alphas when I have the indignity of being converted...

I'm hearing that if I, alpha mush, want to sneak to Eden and think that making a beta could allow a way for my plan to be ruined by that beta, that's not a matter for the SDF unless the beta breaks solid core rules... Alright, it's my choice to make the beta or not, so that's.... quite reasonable, really. Or my partner's choice, but hey, nothing's been stopping me and my partner from talking all this time about who/if/when to convert or whatever...

But really, the overall solid impression I'm getting from this conversation is that the overall policy of the judges who have spoken up is to individually consider reports, to enforce the existing core rules, to not be fast at all to add any new core rules, to explain their reasoning, to interact and discuss concerns of players across a wide range of topics, even when the conversation may be a bit repetitive and abstruse.

Mmm. Intelligent enforcement, without blankets that allow loopholes. Concerns about ethics. Consistency, and patience. Man, this makes me feel like playing more MUSH. Great work, SDF peoples!
On april 26, 2014

On april 26, 2014
[7950824]
Jechtif at that time the "experienced player" explained his actions.. and the majority sided with him.. do you still think he would be killed?.. the whole point of this is to remove the immunity of players getting killed even when they purposely chose sub optimal play or against the majority of players.. if you are the experienced player and you got killed by doing what you think was right then I dont think you would even enjoy playing on that ship in the first place now do you?..

Heh. I dunno about you, Jecht, but I've killed people for suboptimal play - exactly and specifically because of what that play meant to the odds the ship was facing and the odds that player was a mush or a griefer. I usually choose to do that with discussion and teamwork of most of the other active, talkative, and sane-seeming players on the ship, and I tend to seek agreement - because I think that's safe and sane and good for how I want to play.

I hate to ask a grey area question, but are you hinting that you can't kill people you think are playing questionably? The only thing I read in Npfan's answer is that the non-caffiene player drinking a coffee is not necessarily an SDF matter, and he offered two reasons why most players would want to consider not doing a blanket-kill-order on that player.

You can make it an SDF matter, any of us can. Report the drinker! Explain why you think that behavior is against the rules. You can do that with or without killing.

You say that there's an immunity of players getting killed because of sub-optimal play or playing against the majority.

I have to say.... I don't see that immunity. At all. And the rules as are let me deal with Mr. Sub-optimal and Ms Anti-majority however I see fit.

Happily that's more often talking then killing - but then again - that's cause I want it that way. I feel free, empowered, and uplifted by these rules and how they are enforced.

I'd actually like you to explain what you understand you can't do, because the rules stop you from doing it, Jecht. You sound genuinely concerned about what's going on, but other than that beta mush can ruin alpha mush plans and the alpha cannot do anything about it even after carrying out long term plans (I say the alpha mush messed up by converting -that- player... heck, if you -need- to control your beta, befriend them before you turn them, when they think you're human. Talk to them and get to know them so you can estimate their behavior and have their respect before you turn the trick... if you can't work with them when they think you're maybe not mush, great, you know you can't work with them when they know you're both mush.

So what's the problem? What are these rules preventing you from achieving?

Jechtand since I am protected by the rules.. I can voluntarily pick neron's only friend as my only skill as bronze when I pick janice everytime.. or take shrink but never spend my time in dorms.. I wont be killed because I am protected by the rules.. and I do what I want as long as I am not breaking the rules.. I will report everyone who tried to kill me because I think that staying on the lab relaying research is better than giving the ship morale or better yet stand in the refectory and try to solve the madkube every day.. but yes in the end I wont be killed im not breaking the rules and if you kill me you're breaking the rules

Jecht, if you present that attitude on the ship that I happen to be on with you, I might just kill you for it, after some long conversation with you. I'm even more likely to report you - for that attitude of intending to be hostile to your team, that attitude of intending to create an unpleasant game environment.

And you can, I -invite- you, to report me for it. Our conversation and interaction would be studied in the depth it required, and I assure you, one of a few things would happen: We'd come to an accommodation so the ship could flow and feel alright; you're dying with or without a report from me so the ship can then flow and feel alright without the problem attitude you brought to it; and you can report me all you want - but my behavior is not rule breaking, will not be seen as rule breaking, and at -utmost- I would receive a sanction, I would discuss my behavior with one or more mods - and my behavior would -become- completely within the rules for all future ships.
On april 26, 2014
[1820301]
Impet

Exactly!.. that is what I wanted.. I am under the impression that at no cost that you can kill a person on your team as long as they are not violating any rules.. because if you kill them it can be seen as playing against your team like human killing human..

On april 26, 2014
[7950824]
JechtI got the impression that you wont be able to kill anyone just for doing sub optimal play even with everyone else's approval on it (your team) as long as they don't break the rules their right to live is protected by the SDF.. even if you kill them you risk getting sanctioned for it if they report you.. correct me if I'm wrong tho

Explore their play. There's all sorts of levels to this, silly you. This is a social, interactive game.

So somebody is drinking the coffee so the caffeine junkie cannot.

Do I charge up and kill them for it? ... well no. I talk to them. Do they talk back with me? .... maybe, maybe not. What do I do then? More stuff! I get their attention, one way or another. I see what's convenient to prevent them from being a problem to my goals for the ship, and what I understand of others goals that make sense to me.

Are they actually a problem for the ship or not? How bad a one? How likely is that behavior to be that of a mush or a griefer? Can I work around them, and at what cost? What else is that player doing for good or ill? What's the true total value of that player to the ship, is it positive or negative?

... and if it's negative.... we're discussing more than coffee drinking here, you know. Much more.

Because if drinking that coffee's the only thing wrong.... that player is not a problem at all.

Your interpretation of the rules is... wildly off base.

By your interpretation, if someone acts mushy and some people kill them for that behavior, but the person turns out to be human.... whoops, all those killers have just about played their last game.

Nope, you're reading this in a solidly black and white, actually non-playable and non-functional way, and I want to know why!

What happened to get you going like this?
On april 26, 2014
[7950824]

Woo hoo!

Jecht and I took this to PM, so we could sort out how confused I was about what was bothering him.

We're still sorting, but I gots a question based on our conversation:

So it's well established that a human who jumps their ship to Sol when Eden is a reasonable possibility is playing against their team, specifically by 'Harmful return to Sol', with a few grey areas.


What about a mush jumping the ship to Sol, when there's an ongoing and long worked on plan by other mush to try and get to Eden instead of Sol?

Is there -any- form of 'hostile return to Sol' on the mush side of things, because there are mush on that ship that are and have been since becoming alpha fighting like crazy to get mush to Eden, and it actually might be possible save for that one mush's choice?

I know, I am 100% comfortable, that I could report that sol-jumping mush for a hostile return to sol. It's a reasonable report.

But how the heck would it probably be judged?
On april 26, 2014
npfan
Jechtif at that time the "experienced player" explained his actions.. and the majority sided with him.. do you still think he would be killed?.. the whole point of this is to remove the immunity of players getting killed even when they purposely chose sub optimal play or against the majority of players..

Suppose the experienced player did explain his actions and he still got killed, should the killer be immune? Purposely playing suboptimally is very different from playing suboptimally. The former implies malicious intent, so all bets are off.

Jechtand since I am protected by the rules.. I can voluntarily pick neron's only friend as my only skill as bronze when I pick janice everytime.. or take shrink but never spend my time in dorms.. I wont be killed because I am protected by the rules.. and I do what I want as long as I am not breaking the rules.. I will report everyone who tried to kill me because I think that staying on the lab relaying research is better than giving the ship morale or better yet stand in the refectory and try to solve the madkube every day.. but yes in the end I wont be killed im not breaking the rules and if you kill me you're breaking the rules

Any action with the intent of hurting your team does violate the rules, and you then become a free target. Even if you did not intend to hurt your team, you're still not immune from being killed if you do something that gives someone from your team a good reason to believe you're Mush or a griefer. The only difference is that the former will involve sanctions, the latter won't.

Impet

What about a mush jumping the ship to Sol, when there's an ongoing and long worked on plan by other mush to try and get to Eden instead of Sol?

Is there -any- form of 'hostile return to Sol' on the mush side of things, because there are mush on that ship that are and have been since becoming alpha fighting like crazy to get mush to Eden, and it actually might be possible save for that one mush's choice?

I know, I am 100% comfortable, that I could report that sol-jumping mush for a hostile return to sol. It's a reasonable report.

But how the heck would it probably be judged?

Hard to say at this point since that hasn't happened yet nor do I think it will ever actually happen. All I will say about that is it's possible for a Mush who forces a Sol return even though the other Mush want an Eden return could be guilty of a harmful return, but that would require the Mush doing so as a means of pathetic suicide or wanting to 'hurt' his fellow Mush, and not because the Mush thought a Sol infection is better for the Mush than an Eden infection, similar to the case with humans.
On april 26, 2014
Sagittaeri

npfan, you're incapable of seeing that there is an inherent inequality in the rules, protecting rampagers who doesn't collaborate with their team. Thus, you're incapable of understanding that I'm trying to achieve equality with a bit of rule modification - which is the opposite of trying to make one mush victory more "default" than another. You can't seem to see that the current rules is making NERON-death or destroyed-by-hunters mush victory the "default" victory, an outrage you so often express.

With my rule change, both sides can screw over each other. Rampagers can still go on rampage, sabotaging anyone else's plan. Only this time, they are also risking their own neck if they don't get approval first. So both sides have to discuss with each other to prevent any unfortunate misunderstandings. If one side has the majority, then at least their numbers can actually help their cause, instead of SDF artificially protecting the minority from the majority who aren't actually griefers.

Like Impet, I have killed humans over NERON projects, myself. I wanted Blaster Gun, but someone else kept working on Dismantler. At least I believe those were the projects - but what the projects are don't matter, because Dismantler could be more useful in the right circumstances. I couldn't get the rogue human (no more mush on ship) to respond to my communication attempts, so I had him killed after getting the majority to side with me.

I believe I should be able to do the same as mush. If we're going to allow one side to shut communications and do whatever hell they want regardless of the rest of their team, then we should allow a bit of social justice to take place within the ranks of the mush, too.
On april 26, 2014
[7950824]

Sagitteri, here's what I see different about mush, especially beta mush...


You log into the ship and -know- there's 15 other people there, possibly all strangers and potentially 1 or more problem people among them.

You know two will become mush, woo, you're one.

Your partner could be anything, anyone.

But them beta mush, that's different. Sure, there can be random conversions, but even -that- is worked towards. You -choose- to accept having random beta mush if you use conversion methods that can make random betas.

Otherwise, you're handpicking who you offer the honor of joining your team.

Unique, in all of non-casting mush games.... you pick your beta mush partners, pick even if you have any beta mush partners, pick to permit the chance of random betas....

Unique.

So. Before you convert, especially since conversion often takes so long... use that time. Be social, 'interview' your prospective betas, decide if you even want that person to be a mush with you, since you actually can.

Don't infect the unworthy, especially not three times. Don't permit the chance for someone who clearly fails the tests you give as a human to have any chance to join your team, unless you -want- them there.

Someone who seems to like you, who listens to you, makes plans with you and others and cooperates while human, that's an ideal and likely cooperative beta mush. Someone who does their own thing as a human, rarely communicates, isn't a leader or a follower... don't invite them onto your team, and if you do, expect them to behave as they clearly will.

No surprises at all, right?

On april 26, 2014
Sagittaeri
npfanI have...several times now. Rampaging Mush at worst forces Mush that want to go to Sol to change plans. You killing your own teammates ends debate for good and can hurt the Mush team.

End what debate? In the current state, the rampager can shut communications and do whatever they want. Why talk to their team and listen to them when no coordination is needed for their rampagy plans? Only with my proposed suggestion that there will most likely be a debate in the first place. Plus, in my suggested rule, it's not that Camp "Go to Sol" can screw over Camp "Rampage" at any time. You still can't kill mush for simply disagreeing. The mush actually have to rampage, first. It's more of a "if you screw me over, I can screw you over for screwing me over, so we really should talk first" thing.

Both camps can screw each other over. That's what I mean by equality. Right now only one can screw the other over, because the other is protected.

npfanName one ad hominem I made. Name one straw man I made. Name one inconsistent comparison I made. Name one false analogy I made.

If you insist.

Ad hominem i.e. attack the arguer instead of the argument:

npfanI don't know if you feel entitled to win the way you want to as Mush, or if you feel that ends always justify the means,

You've also called me selfish a number of times.

Straw man i.e. argument based on misrepresentation of arguer's position:

npfanYou can refine your suggestion all you want, but it ends up boiling down to how can I force other Mush to follow my plan to infect Sol, regardless of the merit.

This is after I repeatedly said I seek equality so that there will be a discussion for a compromise within the mush team. But you keep arguing as if you genuinely believe I'm trying to force every ship to Sol no matter what when I'm mush by murdering everyone who disagrees.

Inconsistent comparisons and false analogies:

(1) Killing a human over NERON projects choice vs killing a mush over mush victory choice. You ignored the main part of my argument entirely (equality) in this comparison.

(2) SDF sanctioning vs social justice killing. Last I checked, you still stand by that comparison as a valid one.

(3) Also, from the beginning of the debate: Alpha forcing Beta to follow their mush goals (go to Sol or rampage or etc) vs Alpha breaking the rules to force Beta to kill themselves for selfish reasons.

(4) Read below:

npfanYou also never addressed the scenario of whether a Mush that wants to infect Eden should have the right to kill a Mush that wants to infect Sol because that Mush could ruin the plan for an Eden infection.

Again, not the same comparison, because if a mush already have PILGRED fixed and they want to go to Sol, no amount of social justice can stop them from clicking the "Go to Sol" button. This is more of a "Harmful Return to Sol" SDF sanctioning, which is an entirely different suggestion, and probably deserves a separate debate.

Unless, you really meant to say the opposite? Where the Mush who wants to go to Sol kills the Mush (who so happens to be the commander) who wants to go to Eden? Sure, I believe that they should be allowed to kill the commander that's blocking their Sol victory...but given that there's also the issue of whether or not the Eden victory is "better", this again this falls into the separate debate of "Harmful Return to Sol".

One last point I should address:

npfanIf you want a reason to kill a rampaging Mush as a Mush, I already made several examples of legitimate reasons to do that. Why must it be that you should be able to kill a rampaging Mush for and potentially hurt the Mush team just because that Mush didn't follow your plan?

Recall your exact wording was "...only if it clearly benefits the mush team". Given the subjective nature of what's ultimately beneficial or not to the team, and given SDF's unwillingness (fairly and correctly) to judge which plan is better and which is worse, this rule is not going to make a difference in my case. Hence I'm suggesting we remove that ambiguity.

Perhaps, if it sits better, maybe the wording can be "...only if it doesn't clearly hurt the mush team"? Of course, given the subjective nature, in my opinion this is the same as my previous wording, which was "...regardless of merit". But, I can be convinced otherwise.

npfan
SagittaeriAd hominem i.e. attack the arguer instead of the argument:

Making observations is not the same as basing an argument based on the arguer. For example, I'm not basing my argument on what you believe, I'm basing my argument on the effects of the rule modifications you want, the complete opposite of ad hominem.

SagittaeriThis is after I repeatedly said I seek equality so that there will be a discussion for a compromise within the mush team. But you keep arguing as if you genuinely believe I'm trying to force every ship to Sol no matter what when I'm mush by murdering everyone who disagrees.

Showing why what you're seeking isn't truly equality and that it has an effect different from what you intended is not making a straw man.

Sagittaeri(1) Killing a human over NERON projects choice vs killing a mush over mush victory choice. You ignored the main part of my argument entirely (equality) in this comparison.

If one project is easier to finish than another but both are equally good for the ship, does that not bring some inequality and thus get to the question of is it justified to kill someone for promoting something for the team that may not be part of the plan?

Sagittaeri(2) SDF sanctioning vs social justice killing. Last I checked, you still stand by that comparison as a valid one.

So are you saying when you initially suggested SDF sanctioning, it was not for the goal of social justice?

Sagittaeri(3) Also, from the beginning of the debate: Alpha forcing Beta to follow their mush goals (go to Sol or rampage or etc) vs Alpha breaking the rules to force Beta to kill themselves for selfish reasons.

You only asked that beta Mush must follow Alpha Mush plans. I took that broad statement and asked what if Alpha Mush plans to do something that's against the rules. I did not ask that to say going to Sol is equivalent to planning to break the rules, but I made that argument since based on what you asked for at the time, both would be legal. That was the point. When you then said having the rules be hierarchical, continuing that argument would be futile since now it is established the latter is still against the rules.

SagittaeriAgain, not the same comparison, because if a mush already have PILGRED fixed and they want to go to Sol, no amount of social justice can stop them from clicking the "Go to Sol" button. This is more of a "Harmful Return to Sol" SDF sanctioning, which is an entirely different suggestion, and probably deserves a separate debate.

It seems like you're arguing that there is no equivalent to the scenario you've set up and that any argument that shows why that line of thinking is flawed by applying it to similar situations in addition to the situation at hand must be invalid because it's not the exact same situation. If that's the case, we're going to go nowhere because you refuse to look at the broader implications of what you want.

SagittaeriUnless, you really meant to say the opposite? Where the Mush who wants to go to Sol kills the Mush (who so happens to be the commander) who wants to go to Eden? Sure, I believe that they should be allowed to kill the commander that's blocking their Sol victory...but given that there's also the issue of whether or not the Eden victory is "better", this again this falls into the separate debate of "Harmful Return to Sol".

There's is just as much an issue whether Eden victory is better than a Sol victory as there is an issue whether rampaging is better than a Sol victory. As I said before, you're relying on assumptions that are simply not necessarily true. You keep treating your assumptions as fact even though I show why your assumptions cannot.

SagittaeriRecall your exact wording was "...only if it clearly benefits the mush team". Given the subjective nature of what's ultimately beneficial or not to the team, and given SDF's unwillingness (fairly and correctly) to judge which plan is better and which is worse, this rule is not going to make a difference in my case. Hence I'm suggesting we remove that ambiguity.

And several of us in the SDF has said no because you're essentially asking the SDF to make the go to Sol camp a special case, one that is not held to the same standards as any other case, by saying we should allow the go to Sol camp to kill rampaging Mush. Rampaging Mush would still be unable to kill the go to Sol camp. No other camp would still be allowed to kill any other Mush that puts forward their plan to reach the goal. If you still fail to see how your solution is an injustice in itself, we're not going to go anywhere.

SagittaeriPerhaps, if it sits better, maybe the wording can be "...only if it doesn't clearly hurt the mush team"? Of course, given the subjective nature, in my opinion this is the same as my previous wording, which was "...regardless of merit". But, I can be convinced otherwise.

Killing someone in your team already hurts the team. The question is whether it would have been better to kill your fellow Mush or leave him alone.

I'll conclude with one last example I want you to consider. Since you refuse to consider simple cases of similar situations, I'll use a very specific case of the same situation.
Suppose there are three Mush and seven humans. Those three Mush are Roland, Jin Su, and Raluca, with Raluca being the third Mush. All members of the Mush are active. PILGRED is at 20% and Raluca has Physicist and Technician. No one else in the Mush team or the human team has Technician or Physicist, Paola has already gotten skill books neither of which give PILGRED repair a bonus, and everyone except Raluca is under camera. Jin Su has Anonymush, so the humans will think there are still two Mush. It is Day 5, and Eleesha has print The List. On the list is Jin Su, Chun, and two humans that are already dead. Now the humans know Jin Su is a Mush. Jin Su, knowing that Eleesha has printed the list with his name on it, goes on a rampage and starts killing Janice. Jin Su, Roland, and Raluca could have gotten together and finish PILGRED. Roland sees Jin Su attack Janice, but instead of helping Jin Su, he kills Jin Su. The reason? For going on a rampage without consulting with the crew. Janice is still alive since Roland killed Jin Su before Jin Su can kill Janice. Roland could have let Jin Su finish killing Janice, and he could have killed Chun and cripple the rest of the ship in terms of morale. Instead, everyone now knows there were actually three Mush. Eleesha figures out that Roland and Raluca are the Mush because she knows only Jin Su, Roland, and Raluca have been in the Engine Room, and no one else could have possibly gotten three spores (people always cooked food, Chun moved all the items as needed, people rarely went to the Nexus, etc.). Both Roland and Raluca are dead, the seven humans are still alive, and they slowly were able to fix PILGRED and go to Sol.
Question: Did Roland play against the Mush team by killing Jin Su for not following the plan? If so, why should he be immune?
On april 26, 2014
Sagittaeri

This is getting too big for this thread, npfan. Let's continue via PM. Unless you prefer not to?

I'll respond to the example first, either way.

npfanSuppose there are three Mush and seven humans. Those three Mush are Roland, Jin Su, and Raluca, with Raluca being the third Mush. All members of the Mush are active. PILGRED is at 20% and Raluca has Physicist and Technician. No one else in the Mush team or the human team has Technician or Physicist, Paola has already gotten skill books neither of which give PILGRED repair a bonus, and everyone except Raluca is under camera. Jin Su has Anonymush, so the humans will think there are still two Mush. It is Day 5, and Eleesha has print The List. On the list is Jin Su, Chun, and two humans that are already dead. Now the humans know Jin Su is a Mush. Jin Su, knowing that Eleesha has printed the list with his name on it, goes on a rampage and starts killing Janice. Jin Su, Roland, and Raluca could have gotten together and finish PILGRED. Roland sees Jin Su attack Janice, but instead of helping Jin Su, he kills Jin Su. The reason? For going on a rampage without consulting with the crew. Janice is still alive since Roland killed Jin Su before Jin Su can kill Janice. Roland could have let Jin Su finish killing Janice, and he could have killed Chun and cripple the rest of the ship in terms of morale. Instead, everyone now knows there were actually three Mush. Eleesha figures out that Roland and Raluca are the Mush because she knows only Jin Su, Roland, and Raluca have been in the Engine Room, and no one else could have possibly gotten three spores (people always cooked food, Chun moved all the items as needed, people rarely went to the Nexus, etc.). Both Roland and Raluca are dead, the seven humans are still alive, and they slowly were able to fix PILGRED and go to Sol.
Question: Did Roland play against the Mush team by killing Jin Su for not following the plan? If so, why should he be immune?

No, Roland did not play against the team, because this is an example of a misunderstanding that resulted in a bad call.

Jin Su failed to explain to his team what's going on, and Roland made a call based on the limited information he had, which to him, it looked like Jin Su is ruining the agreed upon plans with no explanation. He could have made a better call had he known more about the situation, but he wasn't afforded that privilege.

Of course, in the hypothetical mush universe where rampaging without an explanation could turn your mush team against you, a good Jin Su would have said something to his team, first, so his team can make the best decision with all the information they have. If Jin Su failed to communicate, then it's not his team's fault for reacting to what seemed like "sabotaging your team's plan" to them.

It's like saying: I suspect Eleesha is mush for a number of valid reasons, and I kill her quietly without telling anyone. She turns out to be human. Another human kills me for killing Eleesha, thinking I must be a griefer. Was anyone "playing against their team" in my example? No, since apparently being horrible at communicating with your team doesn't count as "playing against your team" (even though I wish it does).

On a note unrelated to the substance of your example: it's Day 5 - it's possible for Jin Su to convert Raluca all by himself. Roland could still play off the innocent, especially using his newly obtained "I killed a mush" cred, if he's good.
On april 26, 2014
npfan
SagittaeriJin Su failed to explain to his team what's going on, and Roland made a call based on the limited information he had, which to him, it looked like Jin Su is ruining the agreed upon plans with no explanation. He could have made a better call had he known more about the situation, but he wasn't afforded that privilege.

I probably should have made clear the list was publicly known, but I thought that was going to be implied. Roland knew Jin Su was caught. However, he chose to punish Jin Su instead of helping the Mush win. That's the crux of the matter.

SagittaeriOf course, in the hypothetical mush universe where rampaging without an explanation could turn your mush team against you, a good Jin Su would have said something to his team, first, so his team can make the best decision with all the information they have. If Jin Su failed to communicate, then it's not his team's fault for reacting to what seemed like "sabotaging your team's plan" to them.

I don't think that's relevant, but okay. What if Jin Su did say something like, 'Damn! Got caught by The List! I'm going to start killing now, it's our best chance to win,' and Roland chose to punish Jin Su anyway because Jin Su was not following the Go to Sol plan? Does Jin Su supposedly trying to sabotage a way to victory by using another way to victory give the other Mush the right to hurt themselves in such a way that they lose when they could have won just by changing plans?

SagittaeriOn a note unrelated to the substance of your example: it's Day 5 - it's possible for Jin Su to convert Raluca all by himself. Roland could still play off the innocent, especially using his newly obtained "I killed a mush" cred, if he's good.

I don't want to diverge too much from the main point, but let's say Roland and Jin Su visited the Engine Room a total of three times and Raluca never left the Engine Room. Chun delivered food to her, and humans don't mind Chun visiting the Engine Room.

On april 30, 2014
Borz

Just a quick question: assuming you play as mush, if you throw 2 grenades in a dorm full of people (including your mush partner) but end up killing only your partner (killing him by injuries caused by grenades) could you be sanctioned for working against your team, even if the original target was someone else? or would it just be considered an accident?
On april 30, 2014
spacekadt
BorzJust a quick question: assuming you play as mush, if you throw 2 grenades in a dorm full of people (including your mush partner) but end up killing only your partner (killing him by injuries caused by grenades) could you be sanctioned for working against your team, even if the original target was someone else? or would it just be considered an accident?

Personally, as long as there were others in the room, I'd consider that Collateral Damage. Though generally, it's a good idea to warn your partner enough in advance that they have time to get out of there.
On april 30, 2014
[6826491]

I'm going to say that it depends on the circumstances.

Was the partner inactive for days? (If yes, then it's collateral damage, and a candidate for the Fail Thread...though justifiably not intentional.)

If your partner was active, did they consent to this plan, and if so, were they given adequate opportunity to move? (If they weren't given adequate time to move, and/or didn't consent to the plan, it could be seen as playing against the Mush team. Not guaranteed, but the potential is there.)
On april 30, 2014
Borz

Thank you both for your fast and clear reply, spacekadt and Spazticus

Unfortunately, I don't know the entire circumstances, as I am actually playing on the human side, but I know that the mush that died from the injuries was active, while the other was inactive.
I suspect the moment the inactive woke up he just went ahead and throwed the grenades without telling anything to his partner, but again, this is just conjecture.
I will make sure to report this case so that you can shed light on the matter.
On april 30, 2014
[6826491]

Sounds good, and thanks for asking us. We'll take a look at the circumstances when the ship is over.
On may 3, 2014
kreton

Out of curiosity because I'm in a Situation like that:
What do the rules say to this:
An experienced Player (who happens to be a mush right now or is choosen as one, however) sees that another player is very new to the game and starts a private conversation with the new one. Now he helps the new one with advices what the new one has to do in his role. Is this allowed even when the new ones Job would consit of finding out who the mush are/killing them/however?

And because we are in this topic: Is it forbidden to give new human players wrong advices when you are mush?
On may 3, 2014
[1820301]

I think it is allowed.. it would make the new player's experience on the game much better.. and he/she will trust you more thus he/she will not be suspicious of you either works both ways.. I would rather have a greater challenge than misinforming a newbie

On may 3, 2014
[6826491]

To the first question, it's allowed to give advice to a newbie player, even if you're on opposite sides (and they don't know it yet.) You're pretending to BE human, after all. The smartest way to play it is to be helpful, but not too helpful. It's a difficult line to walk, but it is a viable path, provided the advice you give isn't playing against your team.

For example, you could feasibly limit your advice to "General things that won't make the newbie look like a Mush", without explicitly saying things like, "If you see Finola cuddle the cat, she must be Mush." (While you have Finola as a partner.) Someone else might say things like that no matter what you say, so follow this mindset: "I may teach you everything you know, but that doesn't mean I will teach you everything that I know." You can afford to hold back some of what you know, and let them learn on their own.

As for the second question: Don't steer them into potential griefing territory; that's sanctionable - we consider it inciting someone to spoil the game. It might be tempting to get them to kill the other humans for you; but if they get reported for random killing, it's not cool if they end up getting a sanction over it, especially as a new player.

So it's fine to teach them as long as you're not playing against your team, or intentionally leading them to play against theirs.
On may 4, 2014
DarkTheRaven

wait... wait... for absolute clarification for dark the slow avian animal... If I am a mush and I convince a human that another human is mush repeated amounts of times, and they still listen after multiple non-mush kills influenced by me (The mush) I can be sanctioned??? If this is true why am I punished for either choosing a clever path of misleading, or finding a human willing to listen to someone after saying "kill these 5 people they could be mush" and each one being non-mush and still willing to listen to my obvious murder of crew mates?
On may 4, 2014
npfan

We're talking about when you're purposely telling a new player to do something completely wrong. For example, telling a new player who's human to fix the microwave and cook all the rations or telling him Chun is always the enemy and must be killed as soon as possible.
On may 4, 2014
[6826491]
DarkTheRavenwait... wait... for absolute clarification for dark the slow avian animal... If I am a mush and I convince a human that another human is mush repeated amounts of times, and they still listen after multiple non-mush kills influenced by me (The mush) I can be sanctioned??? If this is true why am I punished for either choosing a clever path of misleading, or finding a human willing to listen to someone after saying "kill these 5 people they could be mush" and each one being non-mush and still willing to listen to my obvious murder of crew mates?

If you tell a newbie to kill anyone who is dirty, because "if they're dirty, they must be Mush", and they do it, you're responsible for planting that seed, and turning them into a griefer. I had one of those players on this murdership, and it completely ruined the game for both teams. She was directly responsible for three murders before we put her down, and we had a total of ten people dead in about a day. Five of those were suicides due to the sheer morale loss, all dying in a single cycle...and that's no exaggeration. Being dirty is not enough reason to kill someone on their own, and if you were human on that ship, you'd probably want that random killer to be sanctioned.

So why would you be liable for something like that on your ship? It's for the same reason that the human team can't offer the cure to a Mush.

If the Mush accepts, they can be reported and sanctioned for surrendering, but the human player who made the offer is also guilty of inciting someone to seriously spoil the game, and should be reported as such. Why would it be right that a Mush gets enticed to surrender, and then gets sanctioned for it, while the player who knowingly made the offer has no repercussions? It wouldn't be right; that's the point here.

You want to get them to kill each other? Sure. You can do that. Just get the humans to make honest mistakes, without turning the newbies into shitty players/outright griefers in the process, because they might take that warped knowledge into future ships, and end up griefing there, too.

I had to sanction a Mush player today for suggesting (in a PM) that if the humans repeatedly pick up and drop the spored cat, they'll become Mush too and the game will get "more interesting". This player insisted repeatedly that "the SDF would never find out." Well, we did, genius. That behavior will never be tolerated. Not only is that serious inciting of someone to spoil the game, the player also revealed themselves as Mush when they did it.
On may 4, 2014
[1820301]

I think the topic at hand was a newbie asking for help.. so social manipulation is ok

On may 4, 2014
[6826491]
JechtI think the topic at hand was a newbie asking for help.. so social manipulation is ok

Sure, to a point. There's a difference between "Does this behavior seem suspicious to you?" (planting seeds of doubt/fear.)

vs.

"This person is a Mush, and you should kill them immediately." (giving them an "order", with a sense of urgency to follow it.)
On may 4, 2014
[1820301]
Spazticus

Sure, to a point. There's a difference between "Does this behavior seem suspicious to you?" (planting seeds of doubt/fear.)

vs.

"This person is a Mush, and you should kill them immediately." (giving them an "order", with a sense of urgency to follow it.)


well if a person is clearly a newbie I make sure he knows what is up.. may I be mush or human.. but if I am mush and I am pretty sure that person is not a newbie I dont have any problems saying the second option..

last thing we need is a newbie thinking of just killing someone just because they think they are mush.. trying to promote diplomacy in a game and prevent trigger happy newbies

On may 4, 2014
spacekadt

I actually disagree with you guys.

A mush's goal is to make people die, by any means necessary. MT has even put a notice at the top of the judges page that mush are only to be sanctioned in the cases of anti-mush play or language.

I personally would not sanction a mush for getting a human to kill other humans.

It doesn't make the newbie a griefer any more than it's anti-mush play. I wouldn't sanction either person in this situation.
On may 4, 2014

I for myself gave our Newbe Eleesha (her second ship) just yesterday advices about how to do her job (wich is finding me). It may collides with my intrests as a mush to help her to know what she has to do but helping her to have fun with the game is more important to me.
On may 4, 2014
[6826491]
spacekadt

I actually disagree with you guys.

A mush's goal is to make people die, by any means necessary. MT has even put a notice at the top of the judges page that mush are only to be sanctioned in the cases of anti-mush play or language.

I personally would not sanction a mush for getting a human to kill other humans.

It doesn't make the newbie a griefer any more than it's anti-mush play. I wouldn't sanction either person in this situation.

The human players will probably report a newbie who causes a death spiral, though. It doesn't matter that they were enticed to play against their team, the fact is that they did it. If they kill people randomly like the Eleesha did on the ship I linked, it's griefing, without question. Two of the killed players were dirty before the game started, and one of them had only been offline a few hours after finishing the tutorial at the time he was killed. There was no warning or discussion beforehand, and no explanation given other than a half-assed, "If they're dirty, they're probably Mush."

Basically, if they're taught that it's acceptable to act this way, they screw up their current ship, get killed over it, AND then they probably end up with a quarantine on their next ship. And some of them might not even wonder what the hell they did that was so wrong, even after a sanction.

If it's an experienced human player, that's fair game. Mind games are fair, and so is misdirection; that's not really in question here. Newbies are a different story, if only because they're far more prone to griefing behavior, and they shouldn't be encouraged to ruin ships in their...enthusiasm...over the Mush hunt.
On may 4, 2014
DarkTheRaven

So it's fine to convince an experienced player to kill half the crew, but newbies are off limits? That kinda sucks... convincing experienced players is so much harder

On may 4, 2014
kreton

Tell me, why shouldn't new players, maybe even first time players be of limits?
On may 4, 2014
npfan
DarkTheRavenSo it's fine to convince an experienced player to kill half the crew, but newbies are off limits? That kinda sucks... convincing experienced players is so much harder

That's not exactly it.

If you tell a newb that someone who's dirty could be Mush, that's fine. If the newb ends up killing someone based on that alone, that's the newb's fault. If you tell a newbie that only a Mush is able to pick up the soap, and then the newb goes and kills because he actually believes that, and then repeats his actions on future ships until is told otherwise, then it's the Mush's fault. While it is true that the Mush is helping the team (at least on this ship), he is inciting to spoil the game, which is against the rules.

It's similar to if a human randomly kills someone, and that someone just happens to be a Mush, the human is still guilty of spoiling the game.
On may 5, 2014
spacekadt

There are tutorials galore. There's this whole huge VERY active community in the forums. There are stickied threads with helpful how to play links, including mushpedia.

If a judge sanctions a new player for listening to and getting sucked in by a mush, that's on the judge. (Though it's one more reason I'd really like a warning that comes with 0 points that basically says "hey, you'd normally get in trouble for this, but you're brand freakin new to the game so we're letting you off this time" )

A new player has a slew of resources at his disposal. Eventually a crew is gonna say "wtf, why you are you killing people?!?" and he's gonna say "Raluca told me to!" and discussion will happen.

I will never vote to sanction a mush solely for accomplishing his goals. Never. To the point that MT has even said "Mush should never be condemned except in the case of insults and explicit exposure by crewmates." (and even insults is a grey area... really sick of seeing reports from people who can't handle being called an idiot for doing something stupid... but that's a whole other rant)

On may 6, 2014
[7950824]

Do something. Anything you can to make it more difficult, more costly to kill you. If you can get off ship, do, take stuff with you if you can. Make it hurt to take you out.

If you have no AP or moves left, then there's little you can do. But stay watching, maybe they'll miss a lot. maybe they weapon-fumble, maybe you can grab it when a critical miss makes them drop a knife or gun. Use what you have, do the most harm you can find any way to, especially if stealth is no longer an issue.

On may 7, 2014

On may 7, 2014
kreton

And if I don't want to and jjust want to die to be a human again? On my current ship we had a stephen/Jin Su who thougth that he had to rampage (the lowest move a mush can du in my eyes) he killed some of us and Im still angry at him. Ruined my game with it.
I just want to know if you have to rampage or if you can just give up (because I doubt that I would ever rampage).
On may 7, 2014
[7950824]

Surrender is sanctionable. Mush are there to try to defeat the humans, through any means that does not break the rules (and almost no means a mush can do that can defeat humans breaks the rules.... the only one that comes to mind is teaching a newbie human to act like a griefer because it's good play to do that stuff).

A mush that kills humans is doing what mush are allowed to do, and arguably supposed to do. They don't -have- to, it's also perfectly legal for a mush to act completely human and hide that they are mush for the entire game, sneaking to Sol with the humans believing all mush are dead even - that's perfectly legal and a mush win even if the mush doesn't do a single mushy thing all game.

However giving up/surrendering/just dying so you can play your next game, hopefully as a human... That's expressly forbidden by the rules. Try to ensure your team wins, be you mush or human. That's what the rules ask you to do.

You may decide that a mush that kills humans is playing like crud, but the rules do not agree with you. But you surrendering/just suiciding were you chosen mush, that is bad play, and the rules say so and a lot of players agree.
On may 7, 2014
kreton

It's understandable that suicide is forbidden but be honest, what is the use of mush doing stupid rampages in the cycle they where choosen, becomming inactive imedeatly or just playing without any real effort just to pass the time untill they die? Because all 3 things happen. I do understand as well that let people choose to be mush or not mush is not perfect as well.
On may 7, 2014
[1757645]

The thing about a MUSH rampaging is this: The humans may say it's boring or whatever, but that's just their opinion.
However, your MUSH partner's opinion on the matter, is a whole different thing. If you rampage, and your partner wanted to stay hidden (say to try to move the ship and destroy the Icarus) then you are effectively leaving your partner in the lurch.

If you are a lone MUSH (in reality or because your partner is inactive) then how you try to hurt the humans is completely up to you. No matter how 'lame' it might be.
On may 7, 2014
Vince

The other team will often cry "lame" especially when what you do was effective. Humans can take precautions against "lame" mush tactics... or fail to do so. So unless it is your own teams saying that about your playstyle, I would not worry too much.

On may 9, 2014
[7950824]
TodosLocosIt is forbidden speak in other language that is not English?

On the main channels, yes. A single sentence, maybe a mistake, isn't really bad, but one or more people repeatedly talking in other-than-English on the English server is against the rules - the one exception appears to be in a private channel with everyone in the private chat agreeing that they are fine with the other language.

Heh, I had fun one game with someone who barely spoke English - I used Google translate to help her talk to the ship and the ship to talk to her, all in a PM, I put everything into both English and her language and translated what others said to the other language. Was fun, -once-.

On may 9, 2014
spacekadt
Impetthe one exception appears to be in a private channel with everyone in the private chat agreeing that they are fine with the other language.

Here's the deal with this one. Obviously, you're probably not going to be reported for this because everyone in the PM agrees to said language. But if you get reported for something else, you risk a sanction from:

- a judge seeing this and sanctioning for not using English (I doubt this would happen though)
- a judge not knowing what the hell is going on because you're speaking another language with other people on the ship

Especially if you're particularly chatty, I cba to translate everything you and your friends said to figure out if whatever you did is legit or not. Even when I do feel like translating, you're relying on Google to get shit right. We all know how well that works sometimes.

The only place it's truly ok to use a foreign language is on a casting ship (that we don't currently have) where everyone on board agrees to the rule at the start of the ship.

On may 19, 2014
[8247402]

Hey I kinda have a question. I was recently in a game where I was playing as Alpha Mush, and I made too many mistakes that would've gotten me caught and killed very soon, so when asked why I wasn't where I said I was, I saw that I was out of AP and MP and knew that the evidence was gonna come back and hurt me, so I confessed like so:

I made too many mistakes, I can only hope my partner does a better job than me.

I'm pretty sure this is a sanction-able offense, and as such I didn't mean to commit it. But I said it because I saw no way of escaping the situation any time soon.

So I guess my question is: Is there anything I should've done or not done? Am I in trouble now?
On may 19, 2014
[7950824]

Definitely not in terrible trouble, I'd say. The judges have seen a lot of newbies, and are very interested in stopping people intentionally playing to ruin the game, but really not interested in getting involved in peoples' learning. Many of us don't quite know what to do or how to do it when we start, and that's not a crime.

As far as should goes, just consider having a cover story for the future. Know that every ship is different; you may or may not be closely watched, but if you can find a way to intermix doing your mushy stuff with doing cover activities, it can help you hide better. But never be scared to try, or to keep observing what them humans and mush do on your ships as you keep playing.
On may 19, 2014
npfan
SergeWolfSo I guess my question is: Is there anything I should've done or not done? Am I in trouble now?

You should never confess. Even if the evidence is mounted against you, there is always a chance you can get away with depending on the people you're dealing with. Even if you have a very high chance of getting killed, you should do your best to lower that chance as much as possible instead of guaranteeing your death by confessing.
On may 19, 2014
spacekadt

Additionally, "my partner" indicates there's only one other mush left on board. If you're totally caught and there's just no getting out of it, play mind games with them. Let them think you're a beta mush... or that you created a beta mush (or two or three). Make them hunt for more mush and kill some humans along the way. It's especially effective if you can take out Eleesha or if she's already printed the list... then there's no surefire way to make sure there are no anonymous mush running around.

I'm not sure if I'd sanction for confessing in that situation... and even if I (or anyone else) did, it'd be a very minor one at that. Certainly not worth worrying about if you generally play within the rules.
On may 19, 2014
[8247402]

Thanks for the information. I admit, that I wasn't thinking when I confessed like I did, I was mostly just really defeated in that situation, and kinda still panicked from the super obvious mistakes I had made earlier. Looking back on it now, I probably could've done something, if anything to sow more dissent before my death. But thanks for answering the question.

On may 21, 2014
DarkTheRaven

So on a ship I had a while ago, basically all the researchers woke up first, and Janice had told them to begin research, before mush selection had even ended they had a mycoscanner up, and by day 3 they had nearly every anti-mush research available, for my future reference, would the mycoscan build during a period considered "neutral play" be sanctionable?
On may 21, 2014
npfan

Personally, I don't think so. The Mycoscan doesn't affect the Mush as far as mechanics are concerned. It's like getting all the cameras installed before Mush are selected.
On may 21, 2014
[7950824]

Yes, but it's also no longer possible to do - this season has a few changes and one is that the mush sample, which is needed to do any of the anti-mush research, does not spawn until the ship is full. This neatly prevents players from doing anti-mush research early.

The concept of 'neutral play' before mush selection still is enforced. There's still stuff players can do before mush selection which only a mush should do; that's still quite wrong to do at that point since no one is mush, so clearly would be griefing.
On may 21, 2014
npfan

You only need Chun in the Lab to complete Mycoscan, so that is still possible to research before Mush selection.
On may 22, 2014
Elentari

is there a new bug? i cannot invite people and no...nobody has 3 open channel.
On may 23, 2014
1412
Elentariis there a new bug? i cannot invite people and no...nobody has 3 open channel.

This is more a question for the Q&A thread. But yes, there is a bug. You cannot use the invite button to invite anyone to a pm while it is possible to trade. If there is a trade ship, you can't do it. If there are hunters too, you're fine. Same as with no trade ship.
The whisper button still works though.
On may 24, 2014
DarkTheRaven

Do SDF points wear off? If so, when?
On may 24, 2014
[6826491]

They don't wear off. Your best (and basically only) option is to not accumulate more of them.
On may 24, 2014
DarkTheRaven

That's like telling someone to hold a bomb that was meant for you then running away
On may 24, 2014
[7950824]
DarkTheRavenThat's like telling someone to hold a bomb that was meant for you then running away

If you don't understand how you gained those points or believe there was a misunderstanding, there's an appeals/discussion process.

If you understand how you gained those points and intend to continue behave in that fashion, then predictably you're likely to gain an ever increasing number of them, until you or others who have power over your play decide that you're not going to play anymore.

If you understand how you gained those points and have no intention of behaving in a rule breaking fashion again - you have nothing to worry about. If you do accidentally break a rule in the future, start talking about it fast. Explain what happened to the ship and why it happened, which also will be part of the log for the judges to see as they figure out what happened and if it is something that should be punished or not - should you be reported for the error. Continue to behave well into the future and it doesn't matter how many points you have.

That bomb won't explode unless you decide to ignite it.
On may 24, 2014
DarkTheRaven

Wile a bomb may be ignited, can it not also be defused?
On may 24, 2014
npfan

You defuse it by never misbehaving again.
On may 24, 2014
[7950824]

The bomb's in your head, really.

See, there's no way most of the players can even know if you have points or not, unless you choose to discuss it. The SDF folks won't. Heh, I just had a ship end and someone got a quarantine on D11 of it - a person who hadn't done a single thing I thought was questionable, let alone wrong at all, all game. I'd love to find out what he'd done on some earlier ship - I'm never going to find out unless he or she decides to tell me - there's no one else I can possibly ask who would answer.


If you don't take action that is against the rules (or at least may be against them, as our good Judges do sometimes misunderstand things or get frustrated about bugs or outright make mistakes) Whether you explode or not is actually entirely under your control. But no one else can even tell you've ever done anything wrong, unless it goes so far that you actually get quarantined.

Even highly trained psychologists often are completely unable to defuse the bombs in others' heads. You can talk with someone, encourage them, offer support.... but you dealing with your perception of your SDF points is something that no one but you can control.
On may 24, 2014
DarkTheRaven
npfanYou defuse it by never misbehaving again.

On may 24, 2014
[8206731]

I just have some questions on reports and points.

I have seen someone get quarantined saying it was because of being reported as a griefer when he was a transfer victim on his last ship. Isn't that more disrupting to play if someone gets mistakenly reported and removed from a ship before the reports have been looked into? (i'm just asking this as reporting someone are treated as no big thing, but if every group of reports gets someone removed from their next ship that is really disruptive.)

Also you say that you never lose points, but what happens if you gain points because you brake the rules, (by accident, or on purpose but then decide to play fairly from now on) but then get reported again, mistakenly this time and banned? is there a way to dispute the report that banned you, or is your account permanently blocked?

Finally (and probably most relevant to the current discussion), what happens if you accidentally break the rules several times over the course of a long time. A drivers licence for example, something that stays with us for years, every one makes mistakes and so points degrade over time as long as you are not a constant problem. Some misunderstanding in RP that someone took offense to, an accidental suicide because you didn't know you lost moral for something, a message typed in public chat which was supposed to be in mush chat, using a friends internet connection when they are on the same ship by accident. A lot of things could accidentally get you points but they will have to stay with you because they are against the rules. Is that fair that those mistakes stick with you forever even though you have learned from them and try to never break that rule again?

I think you guys at the SDF do a good job with controlling things, but i kinda agree with dark on this one. Rules can be accidentally broken in a number of ways, and as long as someone is not a continuous problem (breaking 3 rules in 3 months or something like that), the points should probably degrade like a drivers licence. Even Youtube had a massive problem with their three strike system as a bunch of big names had to make new second accounts because they had two strikes on their original account (mostly through reports made about music or video samples which fell under the fair use policy) and didn't want to lose the videos.

On may 24, 2014
DarkTheRaven

You can try to appeal the ban through a link that is given to you in any sanction message from the SDF

But yeah, personally I think so long as you aren't being a constant pain in the SDF's rear the points should start to go down, or at least be able to do something that removes them
On may 24, 2014
npfan
RodRoy1I have seen someone get quarantined saying it was because of being reported as a griefer when he was a transfer victim on his last ship. Isn't that more disrupting to play if someone gets mistakenly reported and removed from a ship before the reports have been looked into? (i'm just asking this as reporting someone are treated as no big thing, but if every group of reports gets someone removed from their next ship that is really disruptive.)

The logs show if someone is a victim of Transfer or not, so anyone who got reported because of something that character did before the transfer are supposed to be cleared. I'd be very surprised if a victim of transfer got mistakenly punished knowing how the system. Also, no one gets removed from a ship before a report is looked into.

RodRoy1Also you say that you never lose points, but what happens if you gain points because you brake the rules, (by accident, or on purpose but then decide to play fairly from now on) but then get reported again, mistakenly this time and banned? is there a way to dispute the report that banned you, or is your account permanently blocked?

A report by itself doesn't do anything. Only SDF people can decide to impose a ban. Any decision can be appealed if you believe you were wrongly judged.

RodRoy1Finally (and probably most relevant to the current discussion), what happens if you accidentally break the rules several times over the course of a long time. A drivers licence for example, something that stays with us for years, every one makes mistakes and so points degrade over time as long as you are not a constant problem. Some misunderstanding in RP that someone took offense to, an accidental suicide because you didn't know you lost moral for something, a message typed in public chat which was supposed to be in mush chat, using a friends internet connection when they are on the same ship by accident. A lot of things could accidentally get you points but they will have to stay with you because they are against the rules. Is that fair that those mistakes stick with you forever even though you have learned from them and try to never break that rule again?

Any act done by accident or in good faith is usually not punished. However, it's hard to imagine anyone making mistakes over and over again without doing it on purpose.

RodRoy1I think you guys at the SDF do a good job with controlling things, but i kinda agree with dark on this one. Rules can be accidentally broken in a number of ways, and as long as someone is not a continuous problem (breaking 3 rules in 3 months or something like that), the points should probably degrade like a drivers licence. Even Youtube had a massive problem with their three strike system as a bunch of big names had to make new second accounts because they had two strikes on their original account (mostly through reports made about music or video samples which fell under the fair use policy) and didn't want to lose the videos.

As I said, accidents are usually not punished. However, you don't want to create a system where a griefer can 'legally' grief once every x amount of time, so that's why points aren't removed unless you've successfully appealed your case.
On may 24, 2014
DarkTheRaven

But a griefer would be a constant pain in the rear of the SDF, what we're suggesting is if I for example got a sanction, after a few months (ideally 6) the points would start falling, but if i were indeed a griefer who gets sanction after sanction they would either take much longer to fall or just never fall at all. It just doesnt seem like the most ideal thing where if i break a rule 3 years ago and never do anything again then break another somehow, shouldnt 3 years of good behaviour mean something at least?
