Its not like its asking the world to be forgiven for breaking the rules once after six months has past is it? I doubt a griefer would grief and then wait six months to grief again, that seems a bit nonsensical unless they had 183 accounts to grief every day of the year or something silly like that.
On may 25, 2014
[7950824]
DarkTheRavenshouldnt 3 years of good behaviour mean something at least?

Why do you think it doesn't?

There's a lot we're not told about the sanction process. The game hasn't even been around 3 years yet. Really, it sounds like you've decided there's a problem where - really, I don't see a problem. What you're discussing doesn't even exist; if it starts to exist we can react to it then and our SDF folks will make changes then. So far they've done a really nice job keeping the game's enforcement reasonable and fair - to the limits of my knowledge and to my standards. Nothing's perfect, but their policies do a real nice balance act between all the pitfalls.

I'm aware of some people who have made horrendous mistakes, ruined the game they were currently playing level of mistakes, and who continue to play without problems - I'm one of them. Learn the rules. Follow them. When and if you recieve a warning, heed it. If there is -any- doubt in your mind as to how you earned that correction and what behavior change is being asked of you - start talking to one or more mods about it. Ask them to explain what you did wrong. Make sure you understand the explanation. Cooperate. Enjoy the game. Seriously, these points are an issue in your head far more then they are in reality or to the perceptions of most of the people you share this game with.
On may 25, 2014
[8206731]

We were just told that they don't wear off, that's why we are discussing it. Your right, for those people who have points, they should heed the warning, but the thing is that players which get closed to being banned after a couple of sanctions will not enjoy the game as much anymore because they will be in constant non stop fear of being banned. I was just trying to say that the pressure on them to be good should lay off a bit after a period of time so they can again enjoy the game for what it is. They have served their time for bad behavior, let them once again be free from that worry (god i'm starting to sound like Ian ).

There is a way to punish a child using their allowance, every time they do something bad you take 10p or so off their allowance for that week, if they keep doing bad things they get no allowance. It teaches them a lesson on what not to do, and then its done with, the punishment finished with after a week, and the child reward for good behavior is their full allowence. The thing is we are not as quick to learn as young children, so the punishment should last longer (3 months, 6 months, 1 year ect) but there should always be a reward for good behavior, be it only removing the points from the account and therefor saying you have earned it, as you have learned to act within the rules.
On may 25, 2014
[6826491]

I answered the question as it was asked. They don't wear off. The question of why they don't wear off has also been explained.

Yes, they can be appealed, but once the time to appeal has past, they're on your record permanently. (Note that it can take more than three days to have your appeal request dealt with, but the key here is getting it filed within 72 hours.) And of course, there is no guarantee that an appeal will make the points magically become overturned. In most cases, the ruling is upheld.
On may 25, 2014
Irishpolak

Going to change the subject a bit here, sorry. I believe this May have been mentioned before, but is it true you look though past games on a reported person? Anyone can look at my profile and see I suicided in my second game, but I guess I wasn't reported for it, the crew kind of gave up. I do my best to play by the rules now that I'm aware of them, but obviously this would be a huge black mark if a future report were to occur. If I get sanctioned for this, fair enough, I broke the rules, ignorance is no excuse, but it's just something I'd like confirmation on.
On may 25, 2014
DarkTheRaven

To my knowledge, no they don't look through past ships, unless you were reported on that particular ship and they just took a while to get to it
On may 25, 2014
[6826491]

Irishpolak, I'll confirm that the mods can see the logs of past games, if you were reported on that ship. We can also pull up your ship history from your profile, and see how you died. That said, the judges do not have access to that same information when they are judging a case. It's highly unlikely to be considered a strike against you, in this particular case.
On may 25, 2014
spacekadt
RodRoy1The only conclusion i came to from that is that he was quarantined immediately before someone looked into the logs.

That's literally impossible. The system doesn't make any decisions for itself and reports that haven't been looked at by judges or mods have no effect.

If your friend was quarantined quickly, it probably means a moderator themselves looked at the report since they count as all three judges. Otherwise, they system needs three different judges to look at the report and make a decision. If there's no agreement by at least two of them, my understanding is that it waits for more judges until there's an agreement between at least two of them.

RodRoy1There is a way to punish a child using their allowance, every time they do something bad you take 10p or so off their allowance for that week, if they keep doing bad things they get no allowance. It teaches them a lesson on what not to do, and then its done with, the punishment finished with after a week, and the child reward for good behavior is their full allowence. The thing is we are not as quick to learn as young children, so the punishment should last longer (3 months, 6 months, 1 year ect) but there should always be a reward for good behavior, be it only removing the points from the account and therefor saying you have earned it, as you have learned to act within the rules.

Except (to follow the analogy), no one's taking away money/allowance. You're being given a time out. A rather small one at that that increases over time. If you honestly get to a point where your timeout is an excessive length of time, you *are* the hopeless griefer that you guys are trying to prevent.
On may 25, 2014
DarkTheRaven
spacekadtThat's literally impossible. The system doesn't make any decisions for itself

That's what they said about sky net
On may 25, 2014
[6826491]

Spacey's right, though. No player gets sanctioned or quarantined without the report being judged.
On may 25, 2014
Sorveevur

Is it possible to report people after a ship is finished? A person on one of my previous ships admitted in their last words that they played against their team but I can't find any info on how exactly to go about reporting them. I was thinking I could send some details and the Honours Screen link from the ship to the moderators through the support site but I am not sure if this is the correct process. Can anybody help, please? (I'm so sorry if the answer was in a rule I missed. I blur the line between man and sloth. )
On may 25, 2014
[6826491]

The final opportunity to report someone is on the end screen where you give likes and leave your last words. You can still report a player from there...but the moment you confirm your last words, you can no longer report someone.
On may 25, 2014
DarkTheRaven

If i'm a Janice mush, and I still give the humans constant moral am i playing against the mush?
On may 25, 2014
[7950824]

Most mush strategies require you to appear to be human until/unless it is time to act as a mush; acting human is necessary for most mush strategies. Mush are even allowed to attempt to completely seem to be human, trying to pretend to be human and staying alive all the way to Sol or Eden. If they succeed and are alive at that point, it's a mush win.
On may 26, 2014
kreton

DarktheRaven: This is not playing aginst you team. As a mush Janice you have to give the humans morale or you would make yourself extremely fast very suspicious and would be killed.
On may 27, 2014
DarkTheRaven

So... I've got a situation that I think will need an actual judge to answer, it's not exactly typical. On a previous ship I learned about from a friend IRL. The mush hatched quite the devious plan, they spored a banana and brought it to another human who was converted by the banana, one of the alpha mush then confessed to being mush in general chats, but that was part of the plan, they wanted the humans to believe that they only had 1 Alpha mush when they had 1 Alpha and 1 Beta, now... would this be sanctioned for suicide and confessing to being mush, or would it be a situation where it aids the mush enough to warrant a forgiveness?
On may 27, 2014
[6826491]

It could potentially lead to a sanction, but it might also be possible to get it cleared afterward via the Mod Inbox. I'm not advocating its use, because there are oh so many ways it can lead to a Fail Thread post afterward...but the plan DOES ultimately further the Mush cause. (It's in a similar vein as one Alpha dealing the final blow to the other Alpha, after the second was caught in the act. That allows the killing Alpha to seem less suspicious.)

Simply put though, you can't confess. It's treated as a surrender, most of the time. If you've already been caught, and they're clearly calling for your death publicly, that's when you're allowed to try and mislead them about how many Mush are left, as per the strategy you laid out. Just deny, deny, deny, until the very moment all reasonable doubt has been removed. But if they never call for the proverbial pitchforks and torches, you have to assume that there's a chance of not being a suspect...even if the plan is to get caught.

So what one can do to execute that sort of plan, AND avoid the sanction, is to slip up in another way, without confessing. Make it seem like the action was a genuine mistake, but have the plan all worked out in a PM beforehand with your Mush partner. That does two things:

1. It shows that this was part of a grand plan, and that both Mush consented to the plan; the judges can read that in the logs.

And 2. It greatly reduces the chance of a sanction, IF it's pulled off according to said plan. You'll also have something to point to in the Mod Inbox if the judges mistakenly sanction for it.

As I said, I'm not advocating its use, just because if things go horribly wrong, they are guaranteed to be disastrous. But the concept itself isn't rule breaking, if you tweak it the way I laid out.
On may 27, 2014
npfan

If the actual goal was to was to make the humans think there was only one alpha left, then that's okay as per the rules. The problem is that I can't imagine a scenario where that's the best strategy a Mush could do. Therefore, while you can sacrifice yourself for the good of the team, you would have to convince the judges that the reason you state isn't just pretext for a suicide. Another way to look at this is that the whole team has to believe it was a good idea for one of the alphas to expose himself.

Edit: When you consider that a dead Alpha Mush means

  • one less member of the Mush team
  • powerful research gets unlocked, such as Pheromodem
  • if the humans are lucky, they can print The List with the dead Alpha Mush not on it
    It would be a huge stretch for the judges to believe a Mush outing himself ultimately benefits the team.

The list had already been printed by a griefer Eleesha

SummerMcLovin

Obviously I'm not a judge, but have a suggestion anyway. Do anything else Mushy other than just confess. You've chosen literally the laziest option, whereas you could out yourself by rampaging, heading down to spike Raluca or anything really - if you're setting yourself up for immediate death then you've got AP to use for the benefit of the Mush, rather than just a 'free' message.

Plus, what are the humans going to think? They're probably going to mass report the guy for ruining the spirit of the game, but it's a not-very-subtle ploy unless they assume the guy simply is bored and wants to suicide. If the message makes that pretty clear, you're going to look even worse in the Judges' eyes.
Of course, this is just "your friend" so I'm not really shouting at you It's more fun for everyone if you make it more interesting though.

On may 27, 2014
kreton

Is there any way to withdraw a Report?
On may 27, 2014
terrem

no... only thing you can do is repent!


)))
On may 27, 2014
[6826491]
kretonIs there any way to withdraw a Report?

No, you can't withdraw a report. But if for example, you report someone for what you think is griefing, and they turn out to be Mush, then the report will usually just get cleared. (Unless they're griefing before Mush selection, or playing the Mush team, of course.) This sort of thing happens a lot when Transfers are involved, because the humans will often think they killed a griefer.

As long as you had a justified reason to report someone at the time you did, you shouldn't have to worry about getting a Report Abuse sanction. If it does happen, it would be a warning, with no points attached.
On may 29, 2014
DarkTheRaven

Are EXP farmers reportable? A bit more detail: we have a crew member who is literally just keeping himself alive, he's not doing anything, he sits in bravo dorms, eats any rations we drop in there to keep himself from starving and relying on signals to keep him alive, he's not mush (he got a disease from us killing someone in BD) and we know he's active because earlier today we shunted him out of bravo dorms so we could kill him without incident and he walked back in, is this sanctionable?
On may 29, 2014
spacekadt
DarkTheRavenAre EXP farmers reportable? A bit more detail: we have a crew member who is literally just keeping himself alive, he's not doing anything, he sits in bravo dorms, eats any rations we drop in there to keep himself from starving and relying on signals to keep him alive, he's not mush (he got a disease from us killing someone in BD) and we know he's active because earlier today we shunted him out of bravo dorms so we could kill him without incident and he walked back in, is this sanctionable?

report it and we can take a look at it. it's generally really hard to prove, but yes... if it's truly just eating not to starve and doing *nothing*, it could very well be considered playing against your team.

On may 30, 2014
DarkTheRaven

If a mush is cured would they be allowed to reveal the identities of the other mush (beta)? or would that be going against the point of the game?
On may 30, 2014
[6826491]

They're human now, so they can reveal if there are any Mush left. The humans went to the trouble of getting the cure, and using it on a Mush, rather than going the "easy" way of killing them.
On may 31, 2014
DarkTheRaven

Another question regarding the serum, If someone just grabs the serum and jabs it in someone and they actually turn out to be right but can't actually give a justification why they suspected that person, is that sanctionable?!
On may 31, 2014
[6826491]

Probably not. You'd have to have proof that they intended to waste the serum, given that there is only one dose, and it's consumed upon use. But typically, the only ones who'd want to waste the serum would be Mush, who would try to inject it into a confirmed human, before it can be used to cure them.

It's actually quite rare to be wrong about who gets cured, barring any Mush intervention.

On may 31, 2014
spacekadt
DarkTheRavenAnother question regarding the serum, If someone just grabs the serum and jabs it in someone and they actually turn out to be right but can't actually give a justification why they suspected that person, is that sanctionable?!

Without a lot more context, that's one of those "so grey I can't answer" zones.

However, if they turned out to be right, the chances of them getting reported are slim and they'd probably get cleared because there was no actual harm to the human team.

If they were wrong, I'd want to see pm trails, wall posts, actions of injectee and go from there. It would have to be a pretty blatant attempt to play against one's own team to get a sanction, I'd think.
On may 31, 2014
zasper

If my ship has little oxygen left, can I keep some O2 Capsules to keep myself surviving? Even if it might cause the death of other people? I'm a human so I can be selfish right?
On may 31, 2014
1412
zEd_If my ship has little oxygen left, can I keep some O2 Capsules to keep myself surviving? Even if it might cause the death of other people? I'm a human so I can be selfish right?

Pretty sure you're wrong there. If you're Mush, it's fine.
On may 31, 2014
[6826491]
zEd_If my ship has little oxygen left, can I keep some O2 Capsules to keep myself surviving? Even if it might cause the death of other people? I'm a human so I can be selfish right?

1412 is correct. As a human, it's generally considered playing against your team to withhold O2 capsules. Mush can do this, since it's their job to speed up the deaths of the humans.

I say generally, because I was in one situation where there were two living Mush, and they already had O2 capsules they'd withdrawn. There were only a few humans left as well, and leaving any O2 capsules in the tanks would have guaranteed a Mush win. Our goal was to keep us alive long enough to try to kill the Mush - it was less about being selfish, and more about giving the few humans left a fighting chance. Under most circumstances, you don't want to go to this extent.
On may 31, 2014
Secondary
Spazticus

1412 is correct. As a human, it's generally considered playing against your team to withhold O2 capsules. Mush can do this, since it's their job to speed up the deaths of the humans.

I say generally, because I was in one situation where there were two living Mush, and they already had O2 capsules they'd withdrawn. There were only a few humans left as well, and leaving any O2 capsules in the tanks would have guaranteed a Mush win. Our goal was to keep us alive long enough to try to kill the Mush - it was less about being selfish, and more about giving the few humans left a fighting chance. Under most circumstances, you don't want to go to this extent.

Another reason to get the oxygen capsule is if you have 1 oxygen left, thats useless as you will lose someone anways next cycle, so its better to just have the most important person take it, usualy an astro if you are so low on oxygen, or an pilot otherwise if you dont have astros or very few pilots. We were gonna do this on our last ship but a mush took it instead , but we still got him killed, Janice logged in right in time to turn nets off so we could move and kill him as he was in space and then we could return to Sol
On june 2, 2014
kreton

It's considered playing aginst the Team if someone pretends to be a mush who announced himself (while beeing human), so that the humans waste the cure on him, right?
On june 2, 2014
[6826491]

Yes, it would be sanctionable. It's considered playing against the team to claim to be a Mush while one is actually human. More than a few human players have been sanctioned for saying something along the lines of, "I'm a Mush. Kill me." In the case they are actually killed over saying that, it can even be considered a Pathetic Suicide.

In short, one should be VERY careful about even implying that they're Mush, at least while there remains a possibility of any Mush. You never know who might take such a claim seriously.
On june 2, 2014
DarkTheRaven

So... If a crew member jokes around in the pheromodem/mush thread and says "hello, I'm character the mush" is that sanctionable (assuming that the person they're imitating is actually human) It was kind of a running joke on our ship that a specific character was mush but it was within the mush hunting group, so when someone was joking around 1 of the 2 non confirmed humans took it a bit seriously and slaughtered Janice...
On june 2, 2014
[6826491]

And that's why you shouldn't joke about it until after you've confirmed that the Mush are dealt with. It's not necessarily sanctionable to joke about it, assuming those people are all in on the joke, but when the consequences can lead to someone getting killed...

Hell, I wouldn't even joke about it when our remaining Alpha has been cured, and we have any inactives. The chance of one of them coming back, seeing only one dead Mush on the Comrades bar, and panicking could lead to disastrous consequences.

On june 4, 2014
[6826491]

Yes, she's still subject to it. If say she's holding onto the weapons before Mush selection, and doesn't make them available, then that may violate neutral play.
On june 5, 2014
[7897487]

I'm sure this has been asked somewhere in 83 pages, but would an inactive commander who keeps coming back just often enough to grab the title again when it changes hands, but has NEVER communicated with the crew, be worth a report for playing against their team? Since they keep coming back to stop anyone else getting the title.

2 of the people in line for commander were doing this, one's already been killed and was human.
On june 5, 2014
spacekadt

You can report it and we'll take a look at it, but there are valid reasons that someone could be doing that (i.e. they can only log on once a day). If they are intentionally being dicks and trying to hoard the title, yes, that's playing against your team. *Usually*, we can tell the difference just by looking at when they do stuff and what they do when they log on.

Or advice... or anything? I've explained the situation to them and I just need some confirmation for my comfort

On june 6, 2014
spacekadt
DarkTheRavenSo i'm in a bit of a predicament... there's a huge storm rolling over for a few days now and it's been constantly causing power outages upwards of 9 hours so far, I'm a bit concerned that if the power goes out for an extended bit of time I could be reported for it, any insight? Or advice... or anything? I've explained the situation to them and I just need some confirmation for my comfort

Tell your ship what's going on and depending on which character you're playing it may be advisable for you to wait in a storage room for trading or something (basically if you're a title holder). But even if you get reported - ESPECIALLY if you mention in the chat what's going on - you shouldn't actually be sanctioned. Generally there are clues to whether people are going idle as a means of suicide versus life just happening.

Question: I know the circumstances vary depending on the case, but about how long does it take for the SDF to investigate reports on a ship? Are they done by report or by ship? (This is purely a curiosity question, so no need to be delicate about wordings to avoid hurting my feelings or message me asking for the specific details of my case)
On june 10, 2014
Yolando

would love to get an answer from the mods via pm but it seems like they are way faster in distributing bans (1/2 day from last ship) than answering tickets (waiting for more than one day now) asking what was "wrong" or lead to this ban. since theres no explanation given in any judgement ecxept that last line which says "Judge Module 12 here, NERON should remember that "hello" is not an insult in and of itself." and if that should tell me anything i dont get it.
On june 10, 2014
spacekadt

mods don't directly do quarantines, judges do after 3 of them have judged a case. mods directly deal with the appeals and are very busy. it sucks that it takes some time to get to, but I think the last estimate I saw was that it was taking a few days for the mods to get around to some of the messages in the in box.

as far as what "passive negativity" means - it could mean a million things. as far as "griefing" goes, we have only a few different options for what to call a sanction. mostly they break out like this:

spoiling (+1) - this is usually a very minor infraction of the rules.

passive negativity (+3) - this is a little more serious. you probably killed someone on your own team with no reason that the judges could find, or you were an actual detriment to your team in some way or another (and this can include being such a jerk in chat that you affect other players' desire to actually play the game - it's one thing to express an unfavorable opinion, it's another to be so consistently mean that no one wants to log in at all)

active negativity (+5) - as serious as a single sanction gets (from non-mods, anyway). you likely killed multiple people on your own team and/or went for "high value" targets like chun or janice. if you're truly griefing a ship, this is where you'll land.

note that these are as generic as explanations get. I don't know your case and even if I did, I no longer have access to logs (I'm not a mod, just a judge) so I couldn't go digging and tell you what you did. these exact explanations may or may not apply to you specifically, but it's a general guideline and may mean nothing more than "we didn't have a more specific reason to apply here so went with what we think the point value should have been."

there are a few other reasons, but those are more specific, both in purpose and explanation.
On june 10, 2014
spacekadt
IsidarthQuestion: I know the circumstances vary depending on the case, but about how long does it take for the SDF to investigate reports on a ship? Are they done by report or by ship? (This is purely a curiosity question, so no need to be delicate about wordings to avoid hurting my feelings or message me asking for the specific details of my case)

You mean to judge reports? Oh lordy...

First thing to consider is that judges don't even see them until the ship is dead.

Then it needs 3 judges to review the case and decide on a judgement... and that's where it can get hairy. We're all human and we all have lives (to some varying degree). When a lot of cases come in or if we take a day or two "off", they tend to pile up quickly which makes it harder to work through the cases. If it's a simple report, it'll get dealt with quickly. If it's a more complex or if it involves a lot of log-reading or worse yet, has little or no explanation or why it was reported, it could take a while for 3 different people to sit down and focus and try to figure out what happened and why. And when you consider that we're pretty thorough and will try to figure out *why* someone did something (since that matters), a single case can take half an hour or more... and a lot of us don't have time to sit down and go through multiples of those.

Sometimes reports are dealt with near-immediately if they're easy... some have sat there for entirely too long in the past.

And reports are dealt with individually. Each report gets its own "ticket", even if there were multiple reports on the same ship. The only exception is that multiple reports against the same person are combined.
On june 10, 2014
Yolando

my main problem is that i did nothing realy different in that ship than i did in others (this one was more pleasent so i would say i was even nicer). so i might get reported and banned frequently without knowing what the real problem is.
the only thing that i could see on that ship was the rp thing. im not realy into that kind of stuff so my answer to a "crew! do we want to build a majestic shield to protect our hull or do we want a heroic sink to stay clean on dangerous expedition?" might be a "yeah go for plasma shields". but that cant be a thing.
On june 10, 2014
spacekadt
Yolandomy main problem is that i did nothing realy different in that ship than i did in others (this one was more pleasent so i would say i was even nicer). so i might get reported and banned frequently without knowing what the real problem is.

the only thing I can tell you is to wait for the mods to get back to you - and they will, it just may take a few days.

And I can properly appreciate the exasperation that prompts some of the posts asking people to please not report something that isn't actually an issue, like a single incident of name calling.

On june 11, 2014
spacekadt

I'm adding on to npfan's answer:

Judges can't answer your question because we have no idea which case is yours and it's likely we don't even remember the details. We don't have access to the logs once we judge the report (or once 3 other people have judged it).

Even if we did, this thread is not the place to discuss sanctions and the reasons behind them.

If you have a question about a sanction you received, contact the mods here: http://twinoid.com/tid/groupDiscuss
On june 15, 2014

On june 15, 2014
npfan

Exploring a planet alone is usually seen as a suicide attempt, unless the planet is completely safe. My guess is that the person who reported her and judges saw her as trying to commit suicide, which is strictly forbidden. Although, given she was quarantined, she would either have a history of breaking the rules or did something much worse than just going on a solo expo.
On june 15, 2014
spacekadt

Hua would have been quarantined for an entirely different ship. We don't get reports from any ship until after it's finished... then there's time to view the report and decide on it and it often takes at least a day to get 3 people to see it and judge it.

Unless something is seriously, seriously, seriously over the top and it comes directly to a moderator's attention, there's nothing that can be done against someone on a ship while it's currently going. That situation is so incredibly rare that I'm honestly not sure it's ever even happened.
On june 15, 2014

personally I hope his account was completely removed

[6826491]

Even then, it's very safe to assume that the player was reported for similar behavior on a prior ship (or ships, as the case may be).
On june 17, 2014
DanielMercury

On june 17, 2014
DarkTheRaven

doesn't hurt to try I suppose, if it's a repeat offence the judges will probably do something about it
On june 17, 2014
spacekadt
DanielMercuryIs it possible to report a Mush companion because once he's chosen as a Mush he pretty much reveals himself with a stupid action (dismounting camera, being dirty and still) and then waits for his dead?

You can report it. There are generally a few clues when it's done as a method of suicide that we can pick up on and go from there. They may or may not get sanctioned, but if you truly believe it's a suicide, go ahead and report it.

That said, judges have no way of knowing if someone's a repeat offender. All reports are completely anonymous. We have no idea who the players are behind the characters and we have no access to the player's history. Only mods see that and they don't generally dig that deep to make the decisions since each ship is meant to stand alone anyway.
On june 17, 2014
[8281354]

Would the judges and mods prefer that we report inactives (and I mean the truly braindead, finished-the-tutorial-and never-moved-again ones) or just let them be? If there's no punishment, we'll continue to see a lot of braindead characters with important roles or skills, but if you don't generally look into the records on them it'd just be giving you more work for nothing.
On june 17, 2014
npfan

Please don't report inactives unless you have to believe they're doing it on purpose.
On june 17, 2014
spacekadt

Inactivity is not against the rules.

And beyond that, we have no way of even looking into the records so to speak, since we don't know who the player is and can't tell if it's a repeat thing.

As far as the ones that just finished the tutorial and never came back, what good does reporting them do anyway? They'd come back to a sanction and it'd just drive them away from the game entirely.

So yes, what npfan said. Please don't report inactives.

On june 18, 2014
spacekadt
zeebok

Is it okay to report "apparently experienced" inactives, on the basis that if they are gold or silver, or if they published an astropad link, then they should know their business and be active?

[edit: nevermind, I just noticed this last reply. I take it as a "no"]

I'm answering anyway

If there's something that makes you truly believe they're only there to farm xp or that they went inactive intentionally, go ahead and report them.

But barring some very strong evidence, there's an inherent assumption that "life happened". There's any number of things that can make a person go inactive for a few days so we don't automatically lean toward any one particular scenario,

On june 22, 2014
[8296864]

Is being active but 100% silent reportable? Someone doing stuff here and there, sometimes relevant, sometimes not... but not really "playing against his team". Just zero message whatsoever, so we never know what they're up to.
On june 22, 2014
[6826491]

It is not...not on its own, anyway. If you have reason to believe that they are actively harming the team, then by all means report it, and we'll investigate. I've been on ships with non-communicative players; a few of them were Mush, just playing silently to make them harder to track. On the other hand, you do get some newbies who aren't used to the chat system, miss messages, etc. and you have to work around them as best you can.

Naturally, those that don't communicate will be under a greater degree of scrutiny, and their actions/motives are "easier" to call in to question, or outright misinterpret, for that matter. But if they can't/won't tell you what their motives are, and they end up killed over those actions, it's hard to find fault with their killers.
On june 22, 2014
[8296864]

Oh. I might have over-reported then
I waited till the end of the ship, to see if the character in question was mush. I was almost sure he was, but no-one on board had the resources to kill him. Actually he wasn't. Maybe his actions will show he somehow plaid against his team... I'll never know precisely what he was doing.
On june 22, 2014
[6826491]

I doubt you'd get a report abuse sanction for that, though. Granted, the total lack of communication led to your suspicion, so you had a genuine reason to report. Without having looked at the report yet, the player in question might be cleared of any wrongdoing.

Report abuse violations tend to be of the "reporting someone for something they clearly didn't do" variety, and occasionally of the "repeatedly reporting people for things that aren't even against the rules" variety.

As an example of the latter, I had someone report me, simply because I bought a consumable after Mush selection, and it coincidentally proved my humanity. I would have bought it even if it didn't prove my humanity, because we needed to get things done, and I needed the AP. There has never been any rule against someone voluntarily proving their humanity, and there never will be.

On june 22, 2014
[1820396]

It's a problem when your intentions are something else then waht you claim. Whenever you claim something what is violation of rules you can be reported and as long as you donẗ state your real intentions in some private chat or mush channel, mods and judges don't have any way how to find out that you actually didn't want to violate the rules.
That's why, whenever I get converted or chosen as a mush, I make my own private "chat" channel. Aside from other useful things (keeping track of things like my supposed morale, spores on humans and such - I know I should make spreadsheet for this, but I am too lazy to use out of the game devices to track things from the game) I also keep summary of my plans and intentions there. This way, whenever something similiar to your experience happened to me, I could always hope that mods will find that I actually didn't want to play against the rules.

On june 25, 2014
[6826491]

Items can't be hidden before Mush selection; the option was disabled this season. A player (likely one who isn't communicating) may be holding onto it, though. If they managed to find and hide it right after Mush selection, that's considered fair play, assuming they're Mush.

Annette
Yolandowould love to get an answer from the mods via pm but it seems like they are way faster in distributing bans (1/2 day from last ship) than answering tickets (waiting for more than one day now) asking what was "wrong" or lead to this ban. since theres no explanation given in any judgement ecxept that last line which says "Judge Module 12 here, NERON should remember that "hello" is not an insult in and of itself." and if that should tell me anything i dont get it.

I know this is a little late but yeah, mods don't ban (unless it's obvious and blatant griefing which is rare), bans are automatic based on how the judges rule. Each sanction sends a PM with report and ship #s and a link to PM the mod in box with any questions you might have. You will have an answer within a few days. We will also read the logs and talk it out. We know the sanction messages you get aren't always explanatory, if at all.

On july 13, 2014
[4950627]

If a mod were in a game with someone griefing / multiteamster would they be able to downright quarantine them? If not quarantine then what punishments ?

P.S I want an answer from the mods to clarify so don't give me theories or thoughts.
On july 13, 2014
[6826491]

In short: No, we can't do that, for two reasons.

The first is because mods and judges are explicitly forbidden from making a ruling on a ship in which they were present. Regardless of whether we personally filed a report, were the target of a report, or were dead long before the report was filed, it's considered a conflict of interest.

The second is that reports aren't seen until the ship is over.
On july 13, 2014
NERON

Recently, we had to do an expo with mush somewhere on board so we had someone guard the FC. Despite the +10 posts on the subject right at the top of the public channel, he misses the posts, questions why FC is guarded, then immediately attacks the person, not even bothering to wait for our explanation 4 mins later. He didn't even acknowledge he did anything wrong and went as far as to say it was the crew's fault for not getting his consent because he was 'trapped' on the bridge even after we told him to move repeatedly. The guarding person is obviously not mush by not visiting BD ever and doing all the research on the ship. He survived by 1

It's only against the rules if that someone is doing it to hurt his team, not just because he's incompetent or has little understanding of how the game works.

On july 27, 2014
[6826491]
PatrykSzczescieBut can I kill Chun before return to Sol, because I don't like her?

No, that's not a good enough reason. If you kill someone without a good reason, e.g. "they're annoying", or "they insulted me", then you might get sanctioned if it's reported. That's considered to be the same effect as a random killing; it's playing against the team, unless you are removing a player who presents a threat to the ship.

To justify killing someone, you have to have evidence of them possibly being mush, or evidence of griefing, if you know they're human. "Not liking someone" is proof of neither. That said, if you have someone on your ship that outright refuses to work with the team, is hostile to everyone, and/or their attitude is severely reducing player morale, then you can report them for it, and kill them if absolutely necessary...just put it to a vote, first.

As an example, I (as Janice) once had to kill a Jin Su just minutes after Mush selection, because:

1. He threatened to kill me for using a bed, which I had used before half the crew was even awake.
2. He ordered that we only work on Nexus projects he chose, and he threatened to kill anyone who disagreed with him. Of course, by the time he woke up, we'd already started voting, and he was the only one who wanted something else worked on. Was he going to kill seven crew before we killed him? I didn't want to wait around to find out.
3. He didn't take Leader, but he did take Cold Blooded. That indicated that he was willing to kill the only Shrink on the ship, just because I burned all my AP before Mush selection, and had the audacity to use a bed for a few cycles.
4. He was severely abusive about this, and brutal enough with what he considered RP, to justify removing him as an immediate threat to the safety of the ship.

I took the knife barely a few minutes after Mush selection, and ended his life as quickly as I could. It didn't matter whether or not he was Mush, and I didn't discuss it beforehand. If I didn't kill him, he would have killed me. I later found out this was a player who killed a confirmed human on another ship...just because the coffee had been taken for that day. This is the sort of player you can justifiably kill, not because you don't like them, but because they're toxic to the health of the ship and the morale of its players.
On july 27, 2014
[4950627]

Moderators do you hate it when your on a ship and someone is asking about whether something is breaking the rules and they completely disagree with you What do you do? Tell them your a moderator so that they will finally believe you or what?
On july 27, 2014
[4950627]

Also if someone gets dirty and washes without reporting and you asked them multiple times why and they completely ignore the subject, and its a character that rarely gets dirty (Janice, Paola, Frieda etc), can you just kill them if they fail to explain?
On july 27, 2014
[7950824]

About rulebreakers; moderators and judges playing are players; they have no powers beyond that of any other player, they report rulebreakers as they see them, and other judges/mods, not on the ship, after the ship is finished will examine the case and decide if rules were broken, the same as for any other complaint.

About dirty, sounds like a grey area. Maybe, maybe not. Could they be offline now? Could they be unable to talk for any reason? Are you likely to be reported for such a kill?

Talk to your team is the best advice I can give you. If many on your ship agree with the kill, odds are it's a reasonable action.
On july 27, 2014
[6826491]
RedTigerModerators do you hate it when your on a ship and someone is asking about whether something is breaking the rules and they completely disagree with you What do you do? Tell them your a moderator so that they will finally believe you or what?

Good question. It's allowed for us to reveal that we're SDF, whether we're mods or judges. If we're doing it to clarify/enforce the rules (hell, sometimes I find I have to quote myself, just to prove the point) then it's considered fair. We don't use our position to compel others to "do what we want" in terms of Research/Projects, when to return to Sol, etc. - that would be an abuse of authority. In case you're wondering, a member of the SDF who abuses their authority could find themselves quickly removed from their position.

I don't typically need to reveal that I'm a mod, though it does have to happen on occasion. Even when I was a judge, it would be revealed when needed. It most often comes up for me in regards to Neutral Play, when someone insists on not following it. Other times, I have to clarify the rules regarding what a cured Mush can or can't say, for example. It's those sorts of things. After revealing myself, I'll usually get asked for clarifications of other rules for the rest of the voyage, which I certainly don't mind.

One other point to mention: If we do reveal ourselves, we'll never say something to the effect of "If you do that (or keep doing that) I will sanction you." It just doesn't happen, because we're explicitly forbidden from ruling on reports from our own ships. That's regardless of whether we filed the report, had a report filed against us, or got killed before the report was filed.

RedTigerAlso if someone gets dirty and washes without reporting and you asked them multiple times why and they completely ignore the subject, and its a character that rarely gets dirty (Janice, Paola, Frieda etc), can you just kill them if they fail to explain?

Being dirty isn't enough of a reason to kill someone, on its own. You would have to have some other evidence to lend weight to your suspicions. Consider that they might be a victim of Slime Trap, for example. But if they've given you other reason(s) to be suspicious of them, put it to a vote before you kill them, just in case there might be evidence others may have that will clear them.

npfan

On july 27, 2014
[6826491]
PatrykSzczescieBut Eleesha already printed and I can't prove I'm human except food-testing which I refuse.

You have the right to refuse to be Mush tested, however if they have sufficient reason to believe that you're Mush, they can still kill you. They can't kill you just for refusing to volunteer to be tested...not if the refusal is the only evidence they have. And there's the catch: If they have evidence and reason to suspect you, then a voluntary test is probably your only way to avoid being killed. (Another one is if you randomly get an illness, but that highly depends on luck, if you're not eating spoiled food, or food that has causes an illness.)
